A GEOGRAPHICAL DISTRIBUTION LIST OF INSECTS AND MITES
ASSOCIATED WITH COCOA, DERIVED FROM LITERATURE
PUBLISHED BEFORE 2012

By M. Bigger
Updated March 2012

INTRODUCTION

3

INTRODUCTION
The origins of cocoa
The genus Theobroma occurs naturally as an understorey component of neotropical evergreen forest from
Mexico to the southern limits of the Amazon forest. It comprises 22 species of which only T. cacao is widely
grown in cultivation.
Three main types of T.cacao have been proposed by Cheesman (1944), namely criollo, forestero and trinitario.
Criollos are characteristic of the cocoa cultivated in Central America together with some Colombian cocoa.
Forestero was derived initially from wild South American cocoa and includes Amelonado among its grouping
which has been extensively cultivated in Brazil and West Africa. Trinitarios arose as a cross between criollo and
forestero and are not known in the wild.
Analysis of food residues found in ceramic vessels from an archeaological site in Belize has shown that
chocolate was consumed by Mayans as early as 600BC (Hurst et al 2002) and it is clear that cocoa held a ritual
significance for Mayan people, evidence for which can still be found in their descendents living today in eastern
Guatemala and western Honduras (Kufer Grube & Heinrich, 2006).
There has been much debate as to whether the Criollo cocoa domesticated in Central America, had its origin in a
wild population already present or from material imported from the Amazon basin in South America. Recent
DNA analysis of Central American criollos including a population of cocoa growing wild in the Lacandona
forest in Mexico suggests that their origin was South America (Motamayor et al 2002).
Cocoa first came to the attention of Europeans when Columbus encountered a trading canoe off the coast of
Honduras in 1502, and once Central America had been successfully colonized, the Spaniards found scattered
cocoa orchards under cultivation from Mexico south to Costa Rica and cocoa beans being used for currency
(Bergmann 1969)
Following their invasion of Yucatan and Mexico from 1517-19, the Spanish seem at first to have been repelled
by chocolate as a drink (Coe & Coe 1996) but by the beginning of the 17th century the settlers in Mexico had
clearly become habituated to the drink (Ferry 2006) and a taste for the drink was beginning to develop with the
aristocracy in Spain (Coe & Coe 1996). At this time there was a fall in production of cocoa in Mexico and
Guatemala with the result that the price in the Mexican market rose sharply and Spanish colonists in South
America took full advantage of this opportunity.
The settlement of Guayaquil on the coast of Ecuador was founded in 1538 and here the Spanish found wild
forestero cocoa growing in the surrounding forests. By 1635 cocoa plantations had been established using these
trees and a flourishing trade developed with Mexico (Coe & Coe 1996).
Similar plantations were developed in the vicinity of Caracas in Venezuela which was colonised in 1567. There
is no reference to cocoa growing around Caracas before 1607 and yet by 1650 it had become the chief item of
trade (Ferry 1989). It was a criollo cocoa and the indications are that it was derived from trees growing wild in
the forest. During the 17th and much of the 18th century Venezuela was the chief source of cocoa for the
burgeoning European trade.
During the 17th century Jesuit missionaries in Brazil exploited stands of wild cocoa growing along the banks of
the Amazon river and sent gangs of Indians into the forests to collect the harvest of the low grade forestero
cocoa (Coe & Coe 1996).
Jamaica was occupied by the Spanish in 1509 and when the island was acquired by the English in 1655 they
discovered established cocoa plantations. These were wiped by a ‘blast’ in 1670, which Wood & Lass (1968)
think was probably caused by Ceratocystis wilt. A similar ‘blast’ devastated the cocoa industry in Trinidad in
1727. Forestero cocoa was imported to Trinidad from Venezuela by Capuchin friars in 1757 and this was
interbred with the local criollo to produce the hybrid Trinitario which formed the basis of the successful cocoa
export trade of the 18th and 19th centuries (Bekele 2004). Wood and Lass (1968) mention another importation of
criollo cocoa from Venezuela to Trinidad in 1678 at which time the crop was also introduced to Martinique and
Haiti.
Surinam, after many years of conflict between the Dutch and British finally became a Dutch colony in 1667.
Initially plantations were of sugarcane and tobacco and cocoa did not become important as an export crop until
the 18th century. However, Surinam was visited in 1699 by the naturalist and artist, Maria Sibylla Merian. She
painted illustrations of many indigenous crops and the insects found upon them and her ‘Metamorphosis

INTRODUCTION

4

Insectorum Surinamensium’ published in 1705 contains an illustration of criollo cocoa and is attendant insects,
including Spodoptera eridania (Stal) and a species of Automeris, and is the earliest account of the entomology of
the cocoa plant.
Criollo cocoa was taken to the Philippines around 1600 and was probably introduced to Sulawesi and Java from
there (Wood & Lass 1968).
Cocoa was introduced to Sri Lanka about 1819 but sytematic cultivation did not occur before 1878 (Macmillan
1962). The situation in India was similar, with serious cultivation beginning during the 19th century although
there is evidence that criollo cocoa was introduced from the Moluccas in 1798 (Ratnam 1961).
The important introduction of cocoa to Africa happened at around the same time. The Portuguese brought
forestero cocoa from Brazil to Sao Tome in 1824 and from there to Fernando Po in 1850 (Coe & Coe 1996).
In 1859 Basel missionaries made an unsuccesful attempt to introduce cocoa to Ghana with seedlings imported
from Surinam. They managed to propagate a single tree which produced enough seed to distribute among their
mission stations but for various reasons did not succeed in interesting local farmers.
In 1878 the Ghanaian Tetteh Quashie brought some pods back from Fernando Po and established a lucrative
trade supplying seed to local farmers. In 1886 the government realised the potential of cocoa as a small holder
crop and obtained further cocoa pods from San Tome. These were used to set up a nursery at the Aburi Botanical
Gardens and served as a source of seedlings for the phenomenal spread of cocoa cultivation throughout southern
Ghana which took place during the next 30 years. The firm of Cadbury began to purchase Ghananian cocoa in
1906 and by 1911 Ghana was the worlds largest exporter (Dickson 1969). It continued to hold this position until
1981 when it was overtaken in export production by Ivory Coast.
The insects of cocoa
Because cocoa is naturally adapted to grow as an understorey plant, traditionally it was grown under thinned
forest shade or under planted shade tree cover. In more recent times it has been shown that it can be grown
without shade cover and under these conditions may crop more heavily, but there is good evidence that the life
span of the tree is reduced.
Because of its intimate association with reduced forest cover there has been interchange of fauna between the
crop and the shade cover in most places where the crop is grown resulting in a very rich faunal diversity.
Entwistle included around 1400 species in his 1972 list of species feeding on cocoa. Although this list includes a
number of ant species which are not strictly feeding on cocoa but tend Homoptera on the tree, it does not include
natural enemies nor pollinators, although many of these are mentioned in the text of the book.
The present list, which does include natural enemies and pollinators as well as mites and some species which are
probably casual visitors to cocoa, has expanded the number to nearly 3200 of which around 500 are natural
enemies.
Hemiptera – Heteroptera and particularly Miridae are found feeding on cocoa in most countries where the crop
is grown, with the exception of the West Indies, and include some of the most important pests of the crop. They
are primarily pod feeders but many cause feeding lesions on green shoots and in some cases their feeding can
lead to severe die-back.
Of the Miridae, the genus Monalonion with around seven species is found in South and Central America. This is
replaced in Africa, the Indian subcontinent, South East Asia and New Guinea by the similar looking Helopeltis
of around twenty one species. Species of Helopeltis have been known as pests of cocoa for over 100 years and
damage was recorded on cocoa in Sri Lanka by H. antonii as early as 1863 (Wright 1907). The most damaging
members of the family, Sahlbergella singularis and Distantiella theobroma, are found in West and Central
Africa. These can cause severe shoot die-back which if not checked can produce multiple branching and stag
headed trees and can be fatal at times. Damage tends to be concentrated in ‘pockets’ involving several trees and
once initiated these are self perpetuating as more and more fresh shoots are destroyed.
Other important Heteroptera are the Pentatomid, Bathycoelia which attacks pods in West and Central Africa and
the Coreids, Pseudotheraptus in both East and West Africa and Amblypelta in New Guinea and the Solomon
Islands.

INTRODUCTION

5

Among the Hemiptera-Homoptera, species in the family Coccidae, which can be devastating pests on coffee, do
not cause much damage on cocoa although the two crops share many species. Of far greater significance are the
mealybugs in the family Pseudococcidae which act as vectors of virus diseases.
Cocoa Swollen Shoot Virus (CSSV) disease is a devastating viral disease in West Africa and particularly in
Ghana where it was first noticed in 1934. Despite intensive research over several decades no practical measure
has been devised to control the vectors apart from ruthless eradication of infected trees together with a cordon of
surrounding healthy trees. Many million trees have been destroyed in this way in Ghana at considerable
expense, but the infection still persists. There seems little doubt that Swollen Shoot Disease was a significant
factor in the replacement of Ghana by the Ivory Coast during the 1980’s as the world leader in cocoa production.
The severity of the CSSV attack in Ghana together with damaging attacks by Mirids led to the setting up of a
cocoa research station in 1938 which in 1944 was expanded by the inclusion of a Nigerian station, to become the
West African Cocoa Research Institute. The mealybugs have a complex relationship with ant species which
solicit them for honeydew and the study of this relationship has led to extensiveecological investigations.
Arboreal ants form a very visible and important element of the forest canopy in West Africa and it was
inevitable that their relationship with cocoa living insects other than mealybugs on the crop growing below this
canopy should eventually be investigated. General ecological studies of cocoa insects has been extended to
many other parts of the world and continues to expand to this day.
Cocoa is host to a large number of leaf feeding Lepidoptera but of more significance as pests are pod feeders and
wood boring species. The cocoa moth, Conopomorpha crameralla is a serious pod boring species found in
South East Asia and New Guinea. It was first reported from Sulawesi in 1860 (Jansen 1860) who reported
sightings as early as 1841 and from Java by Zehntner in 1900 (Kalshoven 1950) but its range continues to
expand and it is by far the most significant cocoa pest in the region.
Important lepidopterous wood borers are found in the Cossidae and include species of Zeuzera in South East
Asia and Eulophonotus in Africa.
The order with the largest number of recorded species is the Coleoptera which is a reflection of the intimate
relationship between cocoa and its shade trees. Among the Cerambycidae are several important wood borers
including Myoxomorpha breve (previously Steirastoma) of the West Indies and South America, several species
of Glenea which are branch borers, principally in New Guinea and Tragocephala branch borers in West Africa.
Species of the genus Pantorhytes in the Curculionidae are important branch borers in New Guinea and the
Solomon Islands.
The Scolytidae are well represented on cocoa and 135 species are included in the present list. Many in the genera
Xylosandrus and Xyleborus bore into trunks or small branches causing die-back and are particularly dangerous
as pests of nursery plants. Xyleborus species and particularly X. ferrugineus are associated with the fungus
Ceratocystis fimbriata which causes wilting and death of branches or even the whole tree principally in South
America and the Caribbean although the disease also occurs in other parts of the world.
Adult Coleoptera in several families feed on foliage but generally speaking do not cause serious economic
damage.
The present list
As mentioned above the present list comprises around 3200 taxa including pests, natural enemies, and some
casual visitors which have been recorded in the scientific literature from over 80 countries.
The database has as a starting point the list included in Appendix 2 of “Pests of Cocoa” by P.H. Entwistle
published by Longman in 1972 which is the definitive text on cocoa entomology. Other records, particularly of
natural enemies, which were not included in the Appendix have been gleaned from the text in the book.
These records have been augmented by a search through the Review of Applied Entomology Series A which
began in 1913 and its successor the Review of Agricultural Entomology continuing up to the present day. In
addition, several sources not reviewed by RAE have been consulted.
The bibliography is not complete, in that only a single reference has been included for the presence of a
particular taxon in any country. An exception is made where only a generic name without a specific epithet has
been given by different authors.
The list of natural enemies associated with a particular insect are also incomplete in that only those are included
which have a specific reference to their occurence on cocoa.

INTRODUCTION

ACARI

ACARI ACARIDAE
Rhizoglyphus setosus Manson
Status: Feeding on leaves
Disitribution: Cuba (Suarez 1991)

ACARI CHEYLETIDAE
Cheyletus sp.
Status: Predatory on the eggs of Araecerus
Disitribution: Colombia (Cabal-Concha 1956)
Predator of: Araecerus coffeae Fabricius, Colombia (Cabal-Concha 1956)

ACARI CUNAXIDAE
Armascirus albiziae Den Heyer
Status: Presumably predatory on other mites
Disitribution: Zimbabwe (Den Heyer 1978)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Zimbabwe (Den Heyer 1978)

ACARI ERIOPHYIDAE
Aceria reyesi (Nuzzaci)
Synonyms: Eriophyes reyesi Nuzzaci
Status: Causes hypertrophy of leaf buds
Disitribution:Brazil (Soria Da Cruz & Milanez 1991) Cuba (De la Torre & Martinez 2004), Venezuela
(Dorete et al 1975)

Floracarus theobromae Keifer
Status: Feeding on buds
Disitribution: Venezuela (Dorete et al 1975)

ACARI ERYTHRAEIDAE
Leptus sp.
Status: Predatory on thrips.
Disitribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Predator of: Helopeltis bergrothi Reuter, Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

ACARI PHYTOSEIIDAE
Amblyseius vasiformis Moraes & Mesa
Status: Probably predatory on other mite species
Disitribution: Colombia (De Moraes Mesa & Braun 1991), Ecuador (De Moraes Mesa & Braun 1991), Peru
(De Moraes Mesa & Braun 1991)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Colombia (De Moraes Mesa & Braun 1991), Ecuador (De Moraes Mesa & Braun
1991), Peru (De Moraes Mesa & Braun 1991)

Paraseiulella plumipilis Denmark
Status: Probably predatory on other mite species
Disitribution: Nicaragua (Denmark 1994)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Nicaragua (Denmark 1994)

ACARI SARCOPTIDAE
Monieziella sp.
Status: Predatory on the eggs of Araecerus
Disitribution: Colombia (Cabal-Concha 1956)

ACARI TARSONEMIDAE
Excelsotarsonemus kaliszewskii Ochoa & Naskrecki
Status: No record of status
Disitribution: Costa Rica (Ochoa Naskrecki & Colwell 1995)

Excelsotarsonemus kimhansenae Ochoa & Connor
Status: No record of status
Disitribution: Costa Rica (Ochoa & O'Connor 1998)

ACARI TENUIPALPIDAE
Brevipalpus phoenicis (Geijskes)
Status: A scarlet mite feeding on the underside of the leaf under a web. It feeds only on the younger leaves
which at first turn whitish and finally dark brown. As the attack develops the tree may be almost denuded of
leaves. There are many alternative hosts including coffee.
Disitribution: Honduras (Evans Cromroy & Ochoa 1993), India (Gupta 1985), Malaysia Sabah (Lim 1992)

ACARI TETRANYCHIDAE
Allonychus reisi Paschoal
Status: Feeds on lower leaf surface
Disitribution: Colombia (Urueta Sandino 1975a)

Eotetranychus tremae De Leon
Status: Feeding on leaves
Disitribution: Colombia (Urueta Sandino 1975a)

Eutetranychus banksi (Mc Gregor)
Status: Feeding on leaves
Disitribution: El Salvador (Baker & Pritchard 1962), Nicaragua (Baker & Pritchard 1962)

Oligonychus biharensis (Hirst)
Status: Feeding on leaves
Disitribution: India (Gupta 1985)

Oligonychus gossypii (Zacher)
Status: Feeding on leaves
Disitribution: Colombia (Urueta Sandino 1975a), Ecuador (Mc Gregor 1955)

Oligonychus mcgregori (Baker & Pritchard)
Status: Feeding on leaves
Disitribution: Costa Rica (Baker & Pritchard 1962), Cuba (Suarez 2004), Honduras (Baker & Pritchard 1962)

Tetranychus mexicanus (McGregor)
Status: Feeding on leaves
Disitribution: Brazil (Costa 1977), Cuba (Suarez 1991)

Tetranychus nakahari Baker
Status: Feeding on leaves
Disitribution: El Salvador (Andrews & Poe 1980), Trinidad & Tobago (Baker & Tuttle 1976)

ACARI

Tetranychus piercei McGregor
Status: No record of status
Disitribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Tetranychus sp.
Status: Feeding damage is probably similar to that caused by Polyphagotarsonemus latus, ie irregular ridges
produced on upper and lower leaf surfaces
Disitribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

ACARI TROMBIDIIDAE
Allothrombium sp.

Disitribution: Ghana (Donald 1956)

Formicococcus njalensis (Laing), Ghana (Donald 1956)
Planococcus citri (Risso), Ghana (Donald 1956)
Pseudococcus concavocerarii James, Ghana (Donald 1956)

Status: Feeding on cocoa beans in store
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1977)

Lasioderma serricorne Fabricius
Status: Principally a pest of tobacco in store but is a major storage pest of cocoa and occasionally of coffee
Distribution: Brazil (Nicol 1941), Ghana (Nicol 1941), Grenada (Nicol 1941), Indonesia Java (Van der Veen
1940), Jamaica (Brooke Breese & Mcfarlane 1962), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Sivapragasam et al 1992), Nigeria
(Golding 1941b), Philippines (Ulrichs & Mewis 2000), Sao Tome & Principe (De Gouveia & Da Sousa 1968),
Trinidad & Tobago (Nicol 1941), Venezuela (Nicol 1941)
Predators: Tenebroides mauritanicus Linnaeus, Nigeria (Riley 1969b)

Protheca flavitarsis Fisher
Status: Adult feeding on leaves
Distribution: Puerto Rico (Wolcott 1936)

COLEOPTERA

COLEOPTERA ANTHICIDAE
Anthelephila sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Indonesia Sulawesi (Bos Steffan-Dewenter & Tscharntke 2007)

COLEOPTERA ANTHRIBIDAE
Acorynus calcaratus Jordan
Status: Larvae bore in old wood and particularly old stumps and do no economic damage
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Acorynus geometricus Jordan
Status: Larvae bore in old wood and particularly old stumps and do no economic damage
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Acorynus punctatus Jordan
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Araecerus coffeae Fabricius
Synonyms: Araecerus fasciculatus (De Geer)
Status: An important pest of coffee both in the field and in store, on cocoa it is a storage pest.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1923a), China (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997), Colombia (Cabal-Concha 1956),
Equatorial Guinea Bioko (Alvarez Aparicio 1943), Ghana (Cotterell 1927c), Indonesia Java (Koningsberger
1908), Malaysia Sarawak (Sivapragasam et al 1992), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941), Nigeria (Lamborn
1914), Peru (Wille 1952), Sao Tome & Principe (De Gouveia & Da Sousa 1968), Taiwan (Li Wang &
Waterhouse 1997), Tanzania (Ritchie 1931), Zaire (Mayne 1917)
Primary parasites: Anisopteromalus calandrae (Howard), Colombia (Cabal-Concha 1956)
Apanteles araeceri Wilkinson, Indonesia Java (Wilkinson 1928)
Cephalonomia gallicola (Ashmead), Colombia (Cabal-Concha 1956)
Plastanoxus sp. , Colombia (Cabal-Concha 1956)
Predators: Cheyletus sp. , Colombia (Cabal-Concha 1956)
Monieziella sp. , Colombia (Cabal-Concha 1956)

Araecerus sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Directarius subplagiatus Jordan
Status: Feeding on beans in store
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Epicerastes subcostalis Quedenfeldt
Status: Adults often found on trunks or branches of cocoa trees but do not seem to do significant damage.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Gulamentus sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Gynandrocerus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Habrissus fasciatus Jordan
Status: Feeding on beans in store
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Hyphantus uncinatus Desbrachers
Status: No record of status

COLEOPTERA

16

Distribution: Brazil (Bovi Coral & Parra 1977)

Litocerus sp.
Status: Collected from dried pods.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Mecocerus disparipes Imhoff
Status: Found on the trunk and shoots of cocoa. The larvae lives in dead wood and in leaf litter at the base of
the tree. On occasion the adult may chew the shoots but does no serious damage.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Mecocerus mechowi Quedenfeldt
Status: Found on the trunk and dry branches under loose bark often in association with other wood eating
insects such as termites, Scolytids etc.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Mecocerus rhombeus Quedenfeldt
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Mecotropis pantherinus Thomson
Status: Found emerging from broken dead tree
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Bourke et al 1971)

Phaeochrotes pictus Jordan
Status: Collected from dried pods.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941)

Phloeops platypennis Montrouzier
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

Phloeotragus hottentotus imhoffi Boheman
Status: Found on old wood
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Platystomos ornaticollis Jordan
Status: Found on old wood and the adults may damage young shoots but not seriously
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Tropideres securus Boheman
Status: Collected from dried pods.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941)

Xylinada sp. near compar Jordan
Synonyms: Xylinoides sp. near compar Jordan
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

COLEOPTERA ATTELABIDAE
Parapoderus clivicollis Marshall
Synonyms: Apoderus clivicollis Marshall
Status: The adult rolls the edge of the leaf into a tube within which it shelters
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Parapoderus flavoebenus (Thomson)
Synonyms: Apoderus flavoebenus Thomson
Status: The adult rolls the edge of the leaf into a tube within which it shelters
Distribution: Ghana (Cotterell 1927a), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

COLEOPTERA

17

COLEOPTERA BOSTRICHIDAE
Apate monachus Fabricius
Status: The adult beetle bores a short tunnel (8-10cm) upwards into the trunk of young trees starting low
down on the tree usually during the dry season. There are many alternative hosts including coffee, mango and
guava.
Distribution: Cameroon (Aulmann & La Baume 1912), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Golding 1935),
Sao Tome & Principe (Navel 1921), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Apate terebrans (Pallas)
Status: The adults attack living trees during the dry season making a tunnel 20-25cm long upwards into the
trunk. There may be several tunnels in one tree. Larval development takes place elsewhere. Alternative hosts
include coffee.
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Jamaica (Gowdey 1921a), Nigeria (Entwistle
1972)

Bostrychoplites productus (Imhoff)
Status: Adults make galleries in the stems. Usually associated with dead or dying wood. Also recorded from
coffee.
Distribution: Cameroon (Aulmann & La Baume 1912), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Sinoxylon atratum Lesne
Status: The adult beetle will tunnel into green wood but the larvae are usually confined to dead or dying
sapwood.
Distribution: India (Abraham et al 1970)

Xylopertha lifuana (Montrouzier)
Status: Boring into trunk and branches
Distribution: Fiji (Knowles 1916)

Xylopertha minuta (Pascoe)
Synonyms: Xylopertha castanoptera Fairmaire
Status: Boring into trunk and branches
Distribution: Fiji (Knowles 1916)

Xyloperthella crinitarsis (Imhoff)
Synonyms: Xylopertha crinitarsis (Imhoff)
Status: Adults make galleries in the branches. Usually associated with dead or dying wood.
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (Lesne 1924), Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Xyloperthella picea (Olivier)
Synonyms: Xylopertha picea Olivier
Status: Boring into wood of unhealthy trees. Also recorded from coffee
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Xyloperthella scutula (Lesne)
Synonyms: Xylopertha scutula (Lesne), Xylopertha scutula Lesne
Status: Adults make galleries in the stems. Usually associated with dead or dying wood.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Xyloperthodes nitidipennis Murray
Status: Boring into wood
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Xylopsocus radula Lesne
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Xylothrips flavipes (Illiger)
Status: A minor borer, mainly in dead wood of the stem and branches. Alternative hosts include mango,
rubber and cashew.

COLEOPTERA

Distribution: India (Beeson 1919), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Xylothrips religiosus (Boisduval)
Status: A minor borer in sapwood of moribund trees. Also recorded from coffee.
Distribution: Solomon Is (Lever 1968)

Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

Status: No record of status

Distribution: Vanuatu (Risbec 1937)

Hemicordus plagiator Kleine
Synonyms: Cordus plagiator Kleine
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Hypomiolispa sp.
Status: Feeding on foliage
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Microtrachelizus aethiopicus Calabresi
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Orfilaia vulsellata (Gyllenhal)
Synonyms: Eupsalis vulsellata Gyllenhal
Status: The beetle is reddish brown and 12-18 mm long. It is frequently found on cocoa foliage but has not
been recorded damaging the plant.
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Orphanobrenthus picipes Olivier
Synonyms: Pseudoceocephalus picipes Olivier
Status: The beetle is reddish brown and 13 mm long. It is frequently found on cocoa foliage but has not been
recorded damaging the plant.
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Podozemius kolbei (Kleine)
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Prophthalmus tridentatus Fabricius

Storeosomus rissi Labrouise

Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Zemioses porcatus Pascoe
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

COLEOPTERA

20

COLEOPTERA BUPRESTIDAE
Agrilus sp.
Status: Larvae tunnel just beneath the bark
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Chrysochroa bicolor Fabricius
Synonyms: Catoxantha bicolor Fabricius
Status: Adult is 70-75 mm long and metallic green with a white elytral spot. The full grown larva is up to 15
cm long. It tunnels beneath the bark commencing close to the ground the tunnel eventually reching 100 cm in
length. Circular holes are cut to the exterior from time to time through which copious amounts of frass are
ejected. Damage can kill the tree.
Distribution: India (Beeson 1919), Indonesia Java (Koningsberger 1908)

Chrysochroa fulminans Fabricius
Status: Damage is similar to that of C.bicolor but is mainly a pest of leguminous trees and is only occasionally
recorded from cocoa.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Koningsberger 1908)

Euchroma gigantea (Linnaeus)
Status: A large metallic green and bronze beetle 55-65 mm long ofetn observed on foliage but not appearing to
damage it
Distribution: Brazil (De Abreu & Silva 1972), Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

Sphenontera (Hoplisture) sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Trachys sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

COLEOPTERA CARABIDAE
Craspedophorus tetrastigma Chaudrey
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Ghana (Majer 1975)

Orthogonius hopei Gray
Status: No record of status, presumably a predator
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Pentagonica sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Ghana (Majer 1975)

Velindopsis panagaeoides Burgmeister
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Ghana (Majer 1975)

COLEOPTERA

COLEOPTERA CERAMBYCIDAE CERAMBYCINAE
Aeolesthes induta (Newman)
Synonyms: Pachydissus frenchi Blackburn
Status: A brownish black very rugose beetle with golden pubescence about 30 mm long. Larvae bore into
trunk at first under the bark but later into heart wood
Distribution: Philippines (Dammerman 1929)

Alloeme rubra Thomson
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Allophyton duffyi Lepesme
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Callichroma elegans (Olivier)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: No locality (Duffy 1960)

Ceresium discicolle Gressitt
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Ceresium sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Bourke et al 1971)

Chlorida festiva (Linnaeus)
Status: Larvae tunnel deep into the heartwood. Alternative hosts include mango and guava.
Distribution: Colombia (De Franco 1958), Sao Tome & Principe (Duffy 1957)

Chlorophorus carinatus Aurivillius
Status: No record of status but on other hosts the larva makes galleries just beneath the bark
Distribution: Tanzania (Duffy 1957)

Chrysoprasis sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Cordylomera spinicornis Fabricius
Status: Larvae bore into old trunks
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Diaspila bipunctatus White
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Dictamnia sp.
Status: Larvae bore into branches
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Froggatt 1938)

Marthmaria catherinetta Lepesme
Status: Adults feed on foliage, larvae boring into branches
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Mecosaspis subvestita Bates
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Phrosyne brevicornis (Fabricius)
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown

21

COLEOPTERA

22

Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Plocaederus basalis Gahan
Status: Larvae bore into old trunks
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Plocaederus viridipennis (Hope)
Status: The larvae make tunnels just beneath the bark in sapwood with holes to the exterior at intervals. When
about to pupate the larva excavates a chamber deeper into the wood.
Distribution: Zaire (Aulmann & La Baume 1912)

Sphallenum setosum (Germar)
Status: The larvae feed within the stems of leguminous creepers climbing up the cocoa trunks where they
cause swellings in their host. However, when about to pupate, the larva makes a short upward sloping tunnel
into the wood of the cocoa tree.
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1988a)

Trachyderes succinctus (Linnaeus)
Status: The larva which reaches a length of around 40mm and 8.25mm in maximum diameter is a wood borer.
Duffy doubts whether cocoa is used as a host plant. It has been recorded from Erythrina which is used
extensively as a shade tree over cocoa. Also recorded from citrus and guava.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1922), Trinidad & Tobago (Guppy 1911a)

Xystrocera festiva Thomson
Status: Larvae bore into the stem.
Distribution: India (Beeson 1941), Indonesia Java (De Haan 1933)

Xystrocera globosa (Olivier)
Status: the larva tunnels in the inner bark until ready to pupate when it excavates a tunnel into the wood either
upwards or downwards.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (De Haan 1933)

Xystrocera laevis Jordan
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

COLEOPTERA CERAMBYCIDAE LAMIINAE
Acalolepta australis (Boisduval)
Synonyms: Dihammus australis (Boisduval)
Status: No record of damage but the larvae of Acalolepta species tunnel just below the bark only penetrating
the wood to pupate and are generally confined to moribund trees.
Distribution: Vanuatu (Duffy 1963)

Acalolepta cervina (Hope)
Status: Larvae bore stems
Distribution: China (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997)

Acalolepta marianarum (Aurivillius)
Synonyms: Dihammus marianarum (Aurivillius)
Status: No record of damage but the larvae of Acalolepta species tunnel just below the bark only penetrating
the wood to pupate and are generally confined to moribund trees.
Distribution: S. Marian Island (Gressitt 1965a)

Acalolepta rusticator (Fabricius)
Synonyms: Dihammus fistulator Germar, Dihammus rusticator Fabricius, Monohammus fistulator Germar
Status: Dead trees are usually attacked but damage to living cocoa trees has been recorded. Larvae bore just
beneath the bark only penetrating into the wood to pupate.
Distribution: India (Beeson 1919), Indonesia Java (Koningsberger 1908), Malaysia W. Malaysia
(Dammerman 1929), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961), Philippines (Entwistle 1972)

COLEOPTERA

23

Acalolepta sp.
Synonyms: Dihammus sp.
Status: No record of damage but the larvae of Acalolepta species tunnel just below the bark only penetrating
the wood to pupate and are generally confined to moribund trees.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Acalolepta strandiellus Breuning
Synonyms: Dihammus strandiellus Breuning
Status: No record of damage but the larvae of Acalolepta species tunnel just below the bark only penetrating
the wood to pupate and are generally confined to moribund trees.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Acanista alphoides Pascoe
Status: Larvae observed boring into trunk
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Bourke et al 1971)

Acmocera conjux Thomson
Status: The larva tunnels just beneath the bark, penetrating deeper into the wood to pupate.
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Acridocephala bistriata Chevrolat
Status: Larvae bore into branches
Distribution: Cameroon (Mbondji Mbondji 1984)

Alcidion bispinum Bates
Status: The larva is a wood borer. The reference to cocoa cites damage to pods presumably caused by the
adult.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Alcidion simillimum (Melzer)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bovi Coral & Parra 1977)

Anauxesida cuneata Jordan
Synonyms: Anauxesida aureolineata Hintz
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Ancylonotus tribulus (Fabricius)
Status: Larva bores stem.
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975), Guinea (Zacher 1921), Sao Tome & Principe (Duffy 1957)

Apomecyna flavosuttulata Aurivilius
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Aristobia testudo (Voet)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: China (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997), Taiwan (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997)

Armatosterna buquetiana White
Status: A trunk borer
Distribution: Ghana (Cotterell 1927c)

Batocera nebulosa (Bates)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Duffy 1963), Vanuatu (Dumbleton 1954)

Batocera sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

COLEOPTERA

24

Batocera thomsoni Javet
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Bixadus sierricola (White)
Synonyms: Metissa sierricola White
Status: Eggs are laid in cracks of the bark of the stem close to the ground. Upon hatching the larvae at first
burrow beneath the bark but later tunnel deeper into the heartwood both downwards into the roots and upwards
into the stem and lower branches. The larva pupates in a chamber at the top of the tunnel.
Distribution: Nigeria (Lamborn 1914)

Cacia sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Vanuatu (Risbec 1937)

Callia criocerina Bates
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Callia sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Callimetopus albata (Newman)
Synonyms: Euclea albata Newman, Niphonoclea albata Newman
Status: Said to be a serious pest. Beetle is black mottled with patches of buff scales and 24 mm long. The adult
ring barks shoots and lays a single egg. As a result of larval burrowing the shoot dies back.
Distribution: Philippines (Uichanco 1931)

Callimetopus capito (Pascoe)
Synonyms: Euclea capito Pascoe, Niphonoclea capito (Pascoe)
Status: Said to be a serious pest. Beetle is black mottled with patches of buff scales and 21 mm long. The adult
ring barks shoots and lays a single egg. As a result of larval burrowing the shoot dies back.
Distribution: Philippines (Uichanco 1931)

Ceroplesis adusta (Harold)
Synonyms: Moesta adusta Harold
Status: Larvae bore in branches making extensive galleries which can kill the ends of the branch. Can at times
be serious. Adults have been recorded gnawing the bark.
Distribution: Cameroon (Aulmann & La Baume 1912), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Ceroplesis bicincta Fabricius
Status: Larvae make longitudinal tunnels in branches
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Cerosterna sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Lim 1992)

Cerosterna sp. near pollinosa Buquet
Status: The larva burrows down the trunk from the jorquette causing extensive damage and death of tree.
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)

Chariesthes bella (Dalman)
Status: Larvae bore in shoots and branches.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Lepesme 1953)

Chariesthes fairmairei Aurivillius
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Colobothea bisignata Bates
Status: No record of status

COLEOPTERA

25

Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Colobothea distincta Pascoe
Status: Larvae tunnel at first beneath the bark of branches of dying cocoa trees but later penetrate into the
wood.
Distribution: Costa Rica (Lara & Shenefelt 1966)

Coptops aedificator (Fabricius)
Status: A grey beetle about 15-20 mm long. Larvae are commonly found boring in branches of forest trees and
only occasionally found on cocoa
Distribution: Cameroon (Duffy 1957), Ghana (Majer 1975), Guinea (Zacher 1921), Ivory Coast (Alibert
1951), Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Corus sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Cypriola tincturata Pascoe
Status: Larva found boring into bark
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Dichostates collaris Chevrolat
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Dichostates flavopictus bimaculatus Bates
Status: Adults feeding on leaves. Larvae tunnelling in branches
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Dihammus sp. near trigonus Gressitt
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Diochares sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Duffy 1968)

Drycothaea viridescens (Buquet)
Synonyms: Hastatis viridescens Buquet
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Drycothea spreta (Bates)
Synonyms: Nyssodrys spreta Bates
Status: The larva is a wood borer. The reference to cocoa cites damage to pods presumably caused by the
adult.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Ecthoea quadricornis (Olivier)
Status: Adults ring-bark stems of young plants. Also recorded from coffee.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1959), Trinidad & Tobago (Guppy 1911c)

Epepeotes luscus (Fabricius)
Status: Adult beetle is 25 mm long and grey brown marbled with marbled specks and with a black spot on the
anterior face of the elytra. Commonly attacks weakened trees
Distribution: India (Beeson 1919), Indonesia Java (Koningsberger 1908), Malaysia W. Malaysia
(Dammerman 1913)

Epepeotes meridianus Pascoe
Synonyms: Epepeotes spinosus (Thomson)
Status: Boring weakened trees
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1919)

COLEOPTERA

Estola sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Eumimetes haroldi Quedenfeldt
Status: Larvae boring into trunk and branches
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Eunidia sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Euthima rodens Bates
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Exocentrus echinulus Gahan
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Exocentrus ortmansi Gahan
Status: Adult is black with grey pubescence. A branch borer
Distribution: Zaire (Gahan 1918)

Exocentrus sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Frea curta (Chevrolat)
Status: The larvae bore into branches of forest trees. They are often found in old cocoa branches and may
cause the death of the branch but are not generally of great importance
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Frea haroldi Quedenfeldt
Status: The larvae bore into branches of forest trees. They are often found in old cocoa branches and may
cause the death of the branch but are not generally of great importance.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Glenea ?algebraica Thomson
Status: The larva feeds beneath the bark
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Glenea ?stellata Thomson
Status: The larva feeds beneath the bark
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Glenea adelpha Thomson
Status: Adults feeding on leaves. Larvae tunnelling in branches
Distribution: Cameroon (Mbondji Mbondji 1984), Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Glenea aluensis Gahan
Status: The larva feeds beneath the bark and eventually ring-barks the branch which then drops off
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961), Solomon Is (Lever 1968)

Glenea celia Pascoe
Status: Larva is a bark borer
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Wood & Chung 1992)

Glenea divergivittata Breuning
Status: The larva feeds beneath the bark
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

26

COLEOPTERA

27

Glenea extensa Pascoe
Status: Only the adult damages cocoa by feeding on leaves, the larvae are found in forest trees. The damage is
superficial.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Lever 1953)

Glenea fasciata (Fabricius)
Status: The larva feeds beneath the bark of old damaged trunks but is not important.
Distribution: Zaire (Duffy 1957)

Glenea funerula Thomson
Status: Only the adult damages cocoa by feeding on leaves, the larvae are found in forest trees. The damage is
superficial.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Lever 1953)

Glenea giraffa (Dalman)
Status: The larva feeds beneath the bark of old damaged trunks but is not important.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Glenea lefeburei (Guerin-Meneville)
Status: The larva initially burrows beneath the bark of the trunk but later penetrates the wood to pupate. Stems
may be girdled. The larva is bright yellow.
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs 1965), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)
Primary parasites: Xanthocryptus vesiculosus (Brulle), Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs 1965)

Glenea mephisto Thomson
Status: Adults feeding on leaves. Larvae tunnelling in branches
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Glenea novemguttata Castelnau
Status: The larva burrows beneath the bark and can do considerable damage.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Koningsberger 1908)

Glenea quinquelineata Chevrolat
Status: Adults feeding on leaves. Larvae tunnelling in branches
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Glenea sp.
Status: The larva feeds beneath the bark
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Anon 1912), Zaire (Ghesquiere 1921)

Glenea sp. near iridescens Pascoe
Status: The larva feeds beneath the bark
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Glenea sp. near virgata Gahan
Status: The larva feeds beneath the bark
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Gnoma boisduvali Plavil'schikou
Status: Adults collected emerging from larval channels
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Bourke et al 1971)

Graciella pulchella (Klug)
Status: Larvae bore into shoots and branches.
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975), Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Heteroclitomorpha punctata Gahan
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Hippopsicon victoriae Breuning
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

COLEOPTERA

28

Hylettus coenobita (Erichson)
Synonyms: Hylettus vindex Lacordaire
Status: Adults are grey brown with a dark brown lateral patch on the elytra and 11-12 mm long. They feed on
leaves
Distribution: Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

Ischioloncha ?lineata Bates
Status: Larvae bore into branches
Distribution: Colombia (Urueta Sandino 1975b)

Lagocheirus araneiformis (Linnaeus)
Status: The species is particularly a pest of sugar cane. The larvae feed beneath the bark eating out a circular
chamber 20-30mm in diameter. When ready to pupate a tunnel is made deeper into the wood. The circular disc
of bark is pushed out by the emerging adult leaving a characteristic circular scar.
Distribution: Colombia (De Franco 1958)

Lagrida rufa Jordan
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Lasiopezus marmoratus (Olivier)
Synonyms: Baraeus marmoratus Fabricius
Status: No record of status, presumably a wood borer
Distribution: Guinea (Zacher 1921)

Lasiopezus sordidus (Olivier)
Synonyms: Baraeus sordidus Olivier
Status: No record of status, presumably a wood borer
Distribution: Guinea (Zacher 1921)

Leiopus convexus Melzer
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bovi Coral & Parra 1977)

Malloderma sp.
Status: Larva recorded boring into branches which are killed. Considered to be a serious pest but only occurs
on a small scale.
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Metopides occipitalis Pascoe
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Microcymatura antennalis Breuning
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975), Ivory Coast (Lavabre Decelle & Debord 1963)

Milothris irrorata (Fabricius)
Status: The species is a primary stem borer of leguminous trees. Not of importance on cocoa.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Von Faber 1909)

Mispila venosa Pascoe
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Monochamus adamitus Thomson
Synonyms: Quasiochamus adamitus Thomson
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Monochamus holotephrus (Boisduval)
Synonyms: Acalolepta holotephra (Boisduval), Dihammus holotephrus (Boisduval)
Status: Larvae bore beneath the bark of trunks of large trees.
Distribution: Vanuatu (Risbec 1937), Western Samoa (Dumbleton 1954)

COLEOPTERA

29

Monochamus lateralis Guerin-Meneville
Status: Larvae bore beneath the bark initially
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Monochamus nigroplagiatus Breuning
Status: Larvae bore beneath the bark initially
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Monochamus ruspator (Fabricius)
Status: Larvae bore at first beneath the bark of the stems of dead or dying trees but later tunnel in the sap
wood.
Distribution: Cameroon (Van Hall 1914), Ghana (Majer 1975), Guinea (Zacher 1921)

Monochamus sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Monochamus tuberosa Bates
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Monochamus variegator Aurivillius
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Myoxomorpha breve (Sulzer)
Synonyms: Steirastoma breve (Sulzer), Steirastoma depressum (Fabricius)
Status: A serious pest, especially of unshaded cocoa. The larva feeds beneath the bark of branches or the stem,
tunneling downwards in a spiral path which can cause the death of the branch through ring-barking. Frass is
expelled through small holes in the bark. When ready to pupate the larva excavates a chamber in the
heartwood. Development within a pod has been recorded. The adult beetles feed on the bark.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1922), Ecuador (Rorer 1918), Grenada (Ballou 1915), Guadeloupe (Entwistle
1972), Jamaica (Entwistle 1972), Martinique (Entwistle 1972), Puerto Rico (Entwistle 1972), Surinam (Van
Hall 1914), Trinidad & Tobago (Fennah 1954), Venezuela (Jaffe Tablante & Sanchez 1986)
Primary parasites: Cyanopterus depressi Viereck, Trinidad & Tobago (Myers 1931)
Cyanopterus peronatus (Cameron), Trinidad & Tobago (Myers 1931)
Cyanopterus steirastomae Viereck, Trinidad & Tobago (Myers 1931)
Horismenus steirastomae (Girault), Trinidad & Tobago (Myers 1931)
Predators: Azteca forelii Emery, Venezuela (Jaffe Tablante & Sanchez 1986)

Nanyohammus luteosparsus Matsushita
Synonyms: Pelargoderus luteosparsus (Matsushita)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Federated States of Micronesia (Esaki 1940)

Nepholotus conspersus Thomson
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Nyssodrys lignaria Bates
Status: The larva is a wood borer. The reference to cocoa cites damage to pods presumably caused by the
adult.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Nyssodrys sp.
Status: A brown 7-8 mm long beetle observed gnawing pods infected by Phytophthora
Distribution: Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

Obereopsis apicalis Kolbe
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

COLEOPTERA

30

Ocularia cineracea Jordan
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Olenecamptus bilobus (Fabricius)
Status: Beetle is ochreous with four conspicuous white spots and two small orange red spots on the elytra, 18
mm long. Larva tunnels into branches
Distribution: Indonesia (Dammerman 1913)

Oncideres sp.
Status: No record of status. Probably gnaws bark like O. tessellata
Distribution: Colombia (Campos 1933b)

Oncideres tessellata Thomson
Status: Larval development takes place in shade trees causing branches to fall which could damage the cocoa
trees beneath. Adults gnaw the bark of cocoa.
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Urich 1913)

Oreodera bituberculata Bates
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Oreodera ohausi Melzer
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bovi Coral & Parra 1977)

Oxyhammus cinctus Jordan
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Oxymagis horni (Heller)
Synonyms: Megaceresium horni Heller
Status: The larva tunnels along the centre of the branch cutting holes to the exterior at intervals of about 10cm
through which waste pellets are expelled. When ready to pupate, it moves to the distal end of the tunnel and
cuts a circular flat chamber beneath the bark which extends to the full diameter of the branch causing the outer
branch to fall. The larva blocks off the tunnel in the cut end of the living branch with wood shavings and
pupates in the tunnel. The species is an important pest of forest plantations in the Solomon Islands and Papua
New Guinea.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Moxon 1991b), Solomon Is (Friend & MacFarlane 1974)

Oxymagis vitticollis Fairmaire
Status: Causes similar damage to O. horni
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Pelargoderus arouensis (Thomson)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Pelargoderus bipunctatus (Dalman)
Status: A grey beetle 30 mm long with a black spot on each elytrum. Dammerman (1929) considers it to be an
important borer of cocoa and other trees but Kalshoven (1950-51) mentions it only as found in dead and dying
trees.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Koningsberger 1908)

Pelargoderus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Anon 1912)

Phemone frenata Pascoe
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

COLEOPTERA

31

Phloeus brevis Jordan
Status: Larva boring in a necrotic branch
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Phosphorus virescens var. gabonator Thomson
Status: Female gnaws off the tip of a shoot and ring barks it slightly lower down laying a single egg. The larva
on hatching bores downwards leaving small holes to the exterior. It is principally a pest of Cola but has been
recorded from cocoa.
Distribution: Cameroon (Weidner 1938)

Phryneta hecphora (Thomson)
Synonyms: Phrystola assimilis Kolbe
Status: Larvae tunnel beneath the bark of branches.
Distribution: Zaire (Aulmann & La Baume 1912)

Phryneta obliquata (Harold)
Synonyms: Phrystola hecphora Thomson
Status: Larvae tunnel beneath the bark of branches. Adults chew bark.
Distribution: Cameroon (Aulmann & La Baume 1912)

Phrynetoides regia Aurivillius
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Proctocera 4-guttata Aurivillius
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Proctocera senegalensis Thomson
Status: Adult feeding on leaves
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Prosopocera bioculata Hintz
Status: Adult feeding on leaves
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown

Pterolophia biarcuata Thomson
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown

Pterolophia bigibbera Newman
Synonyms: Praonetha bigibbera Newman
Status: Larva bores into bark
Distribution: Philippines (Uichanco 1931)

Pterolophia binodosa (Bates)
Status: Larva bores under bark of trunk of young trees and branches of older ones causing them to dry out.
Distribution: Vanuatu (Risbec 1937)

Pterolophia crassipes Wiedemann
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

COLEOPTERA

34

Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Gressitt 1984)

Tragocephala castnia cacaoensis Entwistle
Status: The adult female ring barks incompletely hardened chupons or fan branches about 15cm from the tip
and lays her egg just above this point. The larva at first bores upwards into the shoot and later turns downwrds
and bores down the shoot below the ring-bark for about 50cm cutting air holes to the exterior at intervals.
When ready to pupate the larva cuts off the shoot a short distance from the end of its tunnel and plugs the hole
with wood fibres. Alternative hosts include cola and citrus.
Distribution: Nigeria (Entwistle 1963a), Togo (Entwistle 1963a)
Primary parasites: Aprostocetus lamiicidus Kerrich, Nigeria (Kerrich 1963)
Nadia sp. , Nigeria (Entwistle 1972)

Tragocephala castnia islandica Entwistle
Status: The adult female ring barks incompletely hardened chupons or fan branches about 15cm from the tip
and lays her egg just above this point. The larva at first bores upwards into the shoot and later turns downwrds
and bores down the shoot below the ring-bark for about 50cm cutting air holes to the exterior at intervals.
When ready to pupate the larva cuts off the shoot a short distance from the end of its tunnel and plugs the hole
with wood fibres.
Distribution: Equatorial Guinea (Entwistle 1963a)

Tragocephala castnia theobromae Entwistle
Status: The adult female ring barks incompletely hardened chupons or fan branches about 15cm from the tip
and lays her egg just above this point. The larva at first bores upwards into the shoot and later turns downwrds
and bores down the shoot below the ring-bark for about 50cm cutting air holes to the exterior at intervals.
When ready to pupate the larva cuts off the shoot a short distance from the end of its tunnel and plugs the hole
with wood fibres.
Distribution: Ghana (Entwistle 1963a), Ivory Coast (Entwistle 1963a)
Primary parasites: Aprostocetus lamiicidus Kerrich, Ghana (Kerrich 1963)
Billaea vanemdeni Fennah, Ghana (Entwistle 1972)

Tragocephala guerini buqueti Thomson
Synonyms: Tragocephala buqueti Thomson
Status: The adult female ring barks incompletely hardened chupons or fan branches about 15cm from the tip
and lays her egg just above this point. The larva at first bores upwards into the shoot and later turns downwrds
and bores down the shoot below the ring-bark for about 50cm cutting air holes to the exterior at intervals.
When ready to pupate the larva cuts off the shoot a short distance from the end of its tunnel and plugs the hole
with wood fibres.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1925)

Tragocephala guerini White
Synonyms: Tragocephala anselli Bates, Tragocephala senatoria Chevrolat
Status: The adult female ring barks incompletely hardened chupons or fan branches about 15cm from the tip
and lays her egg just above this point. The larva at first bores upwards into the shoot and later turns downwrds
and bores down the shoot below the ring-bark for about 50cm cutting air holes to the exterior at intervals.
When ready to pupate the larva cuts off the shoot a short distance from the end of its tunnel and plugs the hole
with wood fibres. Alternative hosts include coffee.
Distribution: Cameroon (Aulmann & La Baume 1912), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Tragocephala modesta Fairmaire
Status: Beetle is 12 mm long and black, decorated with dark yellow spots. Larvae are branch borers
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Tragocephala nobilis (Fabricius)
Synonyms: Tragocephala chloris Chevrolat, Tragocephala maynei Gahan
Status: The adult female ring barks incompletely hardened chupons or fan branches about 15cm from the tip
and lays her egg just above this point. The larva at first bores upwards into the shoot and later turns downwrds
and bores down the shoot below the ring-bark for about 50cm cutting air holes to the exterior at intervals.
When ready to pupate the larva cuts off the shoot a short distance from the end of its tunnel and plugs the hole
with wood fibres. Alternative hosts include coffee, citrus and cotton.
Distribution: Cameroon (Entwistle 1963a), Equatorial Guinea (Entwistle 1963a), Equatorial Guinea Bioko
(Entwistle 1963a), Ghana (Kerrich 1963), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Entwistle 1963a), Sao Tome &
Principe (Entwistle 1963a), Sierra Leone (Entwistle 1963a), Togo (Entwistle 1963a), Zaire (Gahan 1918)

Primary parasites: Aprostocetus lamiicidus Kerrich, Ghana (Kerrich 1963)
Billaea vanemdeni Fennah, Ghana (Entwistle 1972)

Status: No record of status but probably boring in trunk.

Mallodon downesi Hope
Status: Damage is normally confined to dead or dying trees. The larvae feed at first in the sapwood but later
penetrate to the heartwood.

Coast (Alibert 1951), Sao Tome & Principe (Navel 1921), Togo (Quicke 1985)
Primary parasites: Fraterarchibracon affinis (Szepligeti), Togo (Quicke 1985)

Colaspis sp.
Status: Adults feed on flowers

Paraivongius chalceatus (Lefebvre)
Synonyms: Menius chalceatus Lefebvre
Status: Adults feed on leaves making a characteristic pattern of small holes and also on the epidermis of young
pods which may fall prematurely as a result
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Status: Adults feed on leaves making a characteristic pattern of small holes and also on the epidermis of young
pods which may fall prematurely as a result
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Selman 1973)

Phytorus destructor Jacoby

Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Papua New Guinea (Deputy 1956)

Phytorus dilatatus Jacoby
Synonyms: Phytorus simplex Lefroy
Status: A brown beetle 4.5-5 mm long which feeds on leaves of many plants including cocoa. It is a serious
pest of tea.
Distribution: Indonesia (Menzel 1925), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)
Primary parasites: Phytorophaga ventralis Bezzi, Indonesia (Menzel 1925)

Nisotra gemella (Erichson)
Synonyms: Podagrica gemella (Erichson)
Status: Adult is 2.5-3.5 mm long with a red head and thorax and steel blue elytra. It feeds on the underside of
the leaf but also on shoots and flowers, often in large numbers
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1929), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941)

COLEOPTERA

Nisotra rotundata Jacoby
Status: Adult is brown, 3-4.5 mm long and commonly found feeding on cocoa foliage
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Deputy 1956)

Nisotra theobromae Laboulbene
Status: Adults feed on unripe pods making grooves 2-3 mm wide in the epidermis. This causes distortion of
the young pod and often leads to fungal infection.
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919d)

Oedionychus sp.
Status: Adults feed on foliage
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Guppy 1911c)

and yellow in colour.

Primary parasites: Homalotylus africanus Timberlake, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Homalotylus sp. , Ghana (Donald 1956)
Homalotylus sp. near quaylei Timberlake, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Predator of: Ferrisia virgata (Cockerell), Ghana (Donald 1956)
Phenacoccus madeirensis Green, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Pseudococcus longispinus (Targioni Tozzetti), Ghana (Donald 1956)

Nephus vallens Chazeau
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Chazeau 1987)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Papua New Guinea (Chazeau 1987)

Status: Adults and larvae are predators
Distribution: Ghana (Cotterell 1927c)
Predator of: Toxoptera aurantii (Boyer de Fonscolombe), Ghana (Cotterell 1927c)

Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Ghana (Majer 1975)

COLEOPTERA CURCULIONIDAE
Acicnemis dumalis Faust
Status: Collected from dried pods.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941)

Acicnemis incisidens Marshall
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Vanuatu (Risbec 1937)

Acicnemis sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Acryptorrhynchus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Agametis festiva Pascoe
Status: No record of damage
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Alcidodes aschanticus (Faust)
Synonyms: Alcides aschanticus Faust
Status: Larva burrow in branches
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Alcidodes australis (Boisduval)
Status: Larvae are branch borers. The species is principally a pest of kapok
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Alcidodes discedens Pascoe
Status: Larvae burrow in branches
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Alcidodes erroneus (Thomson)
Synonyms: Alcides erroneus Thomson
Status: Larvae burrow in branches
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Alcidodes leeuweni (Heller)
Synonyms: Alcides leeuweni (Heller)
Status: Adults bite holes close to the tips of shoots causing the shoot to die back and eggs are laid in these pits.
Larvae begin to burrow into the pith towards the tip of the shoot but later turn and burrow down into the stem
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Anon 1912)
Primary parasites: Euderus torymoides (Ferriere), Indonesia Java (Ferriere 1931)

Alcidodes olivaceus (Gerstaeker)
Status: No record of status but larva is probably a branch borer
Distribution: Madagascar (Frappa 1930)

Alcidodes sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ghana (Owusu-Manu 1976), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Alcidodes theobromae (Marshall)
Synonyms: Alcides theobromae Marshall
Status: Larvae burrow within small branches with air holes left at regular intervals

COLEOPTERA

Distribution: Zaire (Marshall 1918)

Alocorhinus albolineatus Heyne & Taschenberg
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bovi Coral & Parra 1977)

Amadus notatus (Pascoe)
Status: Bred from a dead cocoa branch
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Apirocalus cornutus cornutus Pascoe
Status: Adults feed on the foliage and young shoots which may be destroyed. It is mainly confined to the
coastal areas of Papua New Guinea feeding on Robusta coffee but has also been recorded damaging Arabica
coffee in the highlands.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Apirocalus ebrius ebrius Faust

Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Thompson 1977)

Status: Adults feed on foliage

Catascythropus acuticollis Kolbe
Status: Catascythropus acuticollis
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Cercidocerus albicollis Olivier
Status: Adult feeding on leaves
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Chalcodermus camposi Bondar
Status: Damage is similar to that of C.marshalli
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1944a)

Chalcodermus marshalli Bondar
Status: The species is a serious pest. The adult female ring barks a shoot by biting holes 5-10 cm from the tip.
She then bites a hole just above the girdle in which an egg is laid and the emerging larva burrows into the stem
above the girdle. After a few days the stem above the girdle falls to the ground and the larva emerges to pupate
in the soil.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1930a)

Chaunoderus transversalis Faust
Status: Adults feed on foliage
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Chelyophyes angulatus (Hustache)
Synonyms: Chelyophyes hemisphaericus Marshall
Status: Adults feed on the edges of young leaves
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Marshall 1944)

Cnemidothrix protensus Fairmaire
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Vanuatu (Cohic 1953)

Compsus molitor Rosen
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Compsus sp.
Status: Adult feeds on leaves

COLEOPTERA

56

Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli Silviera & De Barros-Mendes 1989)

Conotrachelus costirostris Boheman
Status: Larvae feed in fruits of wild hosts but feeding as adults on cocoa causes the death of shoots and
deformation of pods
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1937)

Coryssopus sp.
Status: Larvae recorded boring into stems of small seedlings close to ground level and causing death of the
plant
Distribution: Nigeria (Donald 1959)

Cosmopolites sordidus (Germar)
Synonyms: Sphenophorus striatus Fabricius
Status: An important pest of banana, the larvae of this species have been recorded boring into the base of the
stem of cocoa trees where the damage may be severe enough to cause the stem to break off.
Distribution: Fiji (Aulmann & La Baume 1912), Sao Tome & Principe (Aulmann & La Baume 1912)

Costovia brunnea (Hustache)

Cycloteres socius Hustache

Orthorhinus cylindrirostris (Fabricius)
Synonyms: Orthorhinus patruelis Pascoe
Status: Larvae feed on bark of branches. Probably coming from overhead shade trees.

Synonyms: Orthorhinus sp. near patruelis Pascoe
Status: Larvae feed on bark of branches. Probably coming from overhead shade trees.

Oxydema procer Boheman
Synonyms: Oxydema subcaudata Fairmaire
Status: No record of status

Pachnaeus litus (Germar)
Status: Known as the fiddler beetle, adults feed on the bark of the trunk and roots beneath ground level and is
an important pest
Distribution: Jamaica (Urquhart 1957)

Pachyrhynchus moniliferus Germar
Status: Larvae bore into pods causing serious damage
Distribution: Philippines (Kayashima 1940)

Palaeocorynus dorsalis Faust
Status: Adults feed on leaves
Distribution: Gabon (Lavabre 1966), Ivory Coast (Lavabre 1966)

Palaeocorynus femoratus Faust
Status: Adults are found on trunks and branches where they suck sap from wounds, the larvae bore into the
wood of branches leaving air holes to the exterior
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Pantomorus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bovi Coral & Parra 1977)

Pantorhytes albopunctulatus Heller
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Gressitt 1966)

Pantorhytes batesi Faust
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Gressitt 1966)

Pantorhytes biplagiatus (Guerin-Meneville)
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Gressitt 1966), Solomon Is (Lever 1968)
Predators: Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius), Solomon Is. (Friend 1973)

COLEOPTERA

63

Pantorhytes healyi Gressitt
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Gressitt 1966)

Pantorhytes horni Stibick
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Stibick 1978)

Pantorhytes plutus (Oberthur)
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Pantorhytes proximus Faust
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Gressitt 1966)

Pantorhytes pseudocarbonarius Stibick
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Stibick 1979)

Pantorhytes quadripustulatus (Gestro)
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Smee 1963)

Pantorhytes rubroverrucatus Tryson
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Gressitt 1966)

Pantorhytes sp.
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Bourke et al 1971)

Pantorhytes stanleyanus (White)
Synonyms: Pantorhytes chrysomeles (Montrouzier)
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.

COLEOPTERA

64

Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Pantorhytes szentivanyi Marshall
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Gressitt 1966)
Primary parasites: Doleschalla sp. , Papua New Guinea (Baker 1978)
Pristocera rufa Kieffer, Papua New Guinea (Baker 1976b)
Propristocera sp. , Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Singalphogastra sp. , Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Hyperparasites: Exoristobia philippinensis Ashmead, Papua New Guinea (Baker 1978)
Zaplatycerus sp. , Papua New Guinea (Baker 1978)
Predators: Anoplolepis gracilipes (F.Smith), Papua New Guinea (Room 1975)
Evaza fortis (Walker), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Limonia sp. , Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Mesochria cinctipes De Meijere, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Neoarcesius sp. , Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)

Pantorhytes torricellianus Heller
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Gressitt 1966)

Pantorhytes verrucatus (Bates)
Status: The genus includes important pests of cocoa in Papua New Guinea. Adults are flightless and feed on
bark of young fan branches and chupons and sometimes pods. Eggs are laid in crevices of the bark of branches
and on hatching the larvae burrow into the branch or stem at a depth of about 1 cm parellel to the surface.
Heavily infested trees may die.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Gressitt 1966)

Paratactus sp.
Status: Adults feeding on foliage
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Dun 1954b)

Peltotrachelus isabellinus Boheman
Status: Beetle is almost white with brown markings on the head and thorax and 8-9 mm long. It is principally
a pest of kapok but does damage by piercing leaf veins of cocoa
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Phytoscaphus leporinus Faust
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Piazurus sp.
Status: Adults seen feeding on Phytophthora infested pods
Distribution: Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

Platyacus lihirensis (Marshall)
Synonyms: Paratactus lihirensis Marshall
Status: Adults feed on young stems and branches and growing points and can cause significant damage
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Marshall 1957)

Platyacus papuana Oberthur
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Platyacus ruralis Faust
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

65

Platymycteropsis subvirens (Boheman)
Synonyms: Myllocerus subvirens Boheman
Status: Adults feed on foliage
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Plectrophoroides incertus Voss
Synonyms: Plectrophorus incertus Silva & Costa
Status: Adults causing severe damage to leaves.
Distribution: Brazil (Voss 1990)

Polyrhabdotus transversalis Faust
Status: Adults feed on foliage
Distribution: Tanzania (Morstatt 1913)

Proictes curvipes Boheman
Status: Adults feed on foliage
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Hoffman 1966)

Proictes schachae Hoffman
Status: Adults feed on foliage
Distribution: Ghana (Gibbs & Leston 1970)

Prosicoderus ciconia (Gyllenhal)
Synonyms: Erodiscus ciconia Gyllenhal
Status: Adults oviposit in grooves in the bark and larvae bore into stems and shoots.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1924b)

Pseudominus sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Pseudophytoscaphus triangularis (Olivier)
Synonyms: Phytoscaphus triangularis Olivier
Status: Beetle is grey to light brown with a dark band across the elytra between two white spots. Adults pierce
the leaf veins.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Pseudopiazurus obesus Boheman
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Pseudoporopterus sp.
Status: Adults feed on foliage
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Rhadinocopes echinatus Marshall
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Hoffman 1966)

Synonyms: Mecistocerus cribratus Pascoe
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Rhadinomerus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Rhineilipus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Rhinoscapha amicta (Wiedemann)
Status: Adults are leaf feeders

Scolochirus armatipes Marshall

Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Sitophilus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Spermologus rufus Boheman
Status: Found in stored cocoa beans. Adults feed on external pulp whilst larvae feed on the cotyledons.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1923a)

Sphaeropterus albolineatus Guerin-Meneville
Status: Adults gnaw out deep pits in green shoots
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Stastiastes glabratus Faust
Status: Adult feeding on leaves. Larva develops under the bark of dead forest trees of several species in large
congested corridors of white sawdust
congested corridors of white sawdust
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Stegotes sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Status: The adults feed in flowers of cocoa and coffee

Euplatypus hintzi (Schaufuss)
Synonyms: Platypus hintzi Schaufuss, Platypus linearis Stephens, Platypus rugulosus Chapuis
Status: An important forest timber borer of newly felled logs and living trees.
Distribution: Costa Rica (Lara & Shenefelt 1965), Zaire (Schedl 1962)

Euplatypus parallelus (Fabricius)
Synonyms: Platypus parallelus Chapuis
Status: No record of status. Probably a branch borer
Distribution: Colombia (Steinhausen 1956)

Megaplatypus latreillei (Chapuis)
Synonyms: Platypus latreillei Chapuis
Status: Found occasionally and not thought to be important. Borers its tunnels perpendicularly to the bark and
only on trees covered in moss.
Distribution: Costa Rica (Lara & Shenefelt 1965)

COLEOPTERA

Platypus (Stenoplatypus) sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Distribution: No locality (Wood & Bright 1992)
