Status: No record of status
Distribution: Colombia (Steinhausen 1956)

Platypus sp. near jansoni Chapius
Status: Recorded as a borer of cankers caused by Phytophthora palmivora thought to be the causal agent of
sudden death of trees.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Prior 1986)

Status: Adults feed on flowers
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

Glycyphana sp.
Status: No record of status, probably a leaf feeder
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

COLEOPTERA

Niphobleta niveosparsa Kraatz
Status: A brown beetle 12 mm long feeding on young leaves and flowers
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Poecilopharis bimaculata Schurhof
Status: Adults feed on foliage
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

Taeniodera monacha (Gory & Percheron)
Synonyms: Macronota monacha Gory & Percheron
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

COLEOPTERA SCARABAEIDAE DYNASTINAE
Heteronychus plebejus (Klug)
Status: No record of status. Larvae recorded as damaging roots of sugarcane.
Distribution: Madagascar (Anderson 1929)

Ligyrus ebenus (DeGeer)
Status: Larva have been recorded feeding on roots of young cocoa. It is principally a pest of bananas.
Distribution: Dominica (Anon 1913), St Lucia (Anon 1913)

Oryctes rhinoceros Linnaeus
Status: Larvae are important pests of coconuts. Adults feed on the leaves of a range of trees including cocoa
but do little damage.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Strategus simsoni (Linnaeus)
Synonyms: Strategus titanus (Wolcott 1921) Fabricius
Status: The larva attacks the roots of seedlings planted in virgin soil. It is particularly a pest of sugarcane.
Distribution: Dominican Republic (Wolcott 1926)

Xylotrupes sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

COLEOPTERA SCARABAEIDAE MELOLONTHINAE
Ancistrosoma farinosum Salle
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Guppy 1911c)

Apogonia blanchardi Ritsema
Status: 9-11 mm long beetle. Adult feeds on leaves at night
Distribution: India (Emmanuel Sujatha & Gautam 2010a)

Apogonia conradtiana D.Torre
Synonyms: Apogonia conradti Kolbe
Status: Adults feed on foliage
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975), Ivory Coast (Lavabre Decelle & Debord 1963)

Apogonia cribricollis Burmeister
Status: An important pest of cocoa. Adults feed on leaves during the night, hiding in the soil during the day.
The roots may be attacked by the soil living larvae. Alternative hosts include coffee.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Lever 1953)
Primary parasites: Tiphia sp. , Malaysia (Entwistle 1972)

Apogonia destructor Ritsema
Status: Adult feeds on leaves. Mainly on sugarcane

77

Distribution: Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1929)
Primary parasites: Masicera sp. , Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)
Prosena siberita Fabricius, Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)

Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Lever 1953)

Brahmina sp.
Status: Adults feed on foliage

Camenta obesa Burmeister
Status: A serious pest of young cocoa plants. Both adults and larvae feed on roots.
Distribution: Equatorial Guinea Bioko (Cotterell 1930a)

Camenta westermanni Harold
Status: Larvae, and probably, adults feed on roots.

Status: Larvae feed on roots of seedlings

Empecamenta hintzi (Aulmann)
Synonyms: Camenta hintzi Aulmann
Status: Larvae, and probably, adults feed on roots.
Distribution: Cameroon (Aulmann & La Baume 1912)

Enaria melanictera (Klug)
Status: Larvae feed on roots and can do considerable damage.
Distribution: Cameroon (Aulmann & La Baume 1912), Madagascar (Frappa 1931)

Status: No record of status

Holotrichia vandinei (Smyth)
Synonyms: Ancylonycha vandinei (Smyth)
Status: Adults feed on leaves. Larvae recorded from roots of sugarcane
Distribution: Puerto Rico (Smyth 1917)

Predators: Ignelator luminosus (Illiger), Puerto Rico (Smyth 1917)

Hoplebaea congoana (Brenske)

Status: Adults feed on foliage and may skeletonize the leaf
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Status: Adults feed on foliage
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Lepidiota sp.
Status: Larvae feed on roots
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Simon-Thomas 1959)

Lepidiota sp. near vogeli Brenske
Status: Larvae feed on roots of young plants and can kill the tree under drought conditions
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Lepidiota stigma (Fabricius)

Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Simon-Thomas 1962)

Macrodactylus sp.

Maladera apogonoides (Brenske)

Adoretus sinicus Burmeister

Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Adoretus sp. near fusculus Fabricius
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Adoretus umbrosus Fabricius
Synonyms: Adoretus hirtellus Laporte
Status: Adults feed on leaves, larvae in the soil. Coffee and kola are alternative hosts
Distribution: Ghana (Patterson 1914), Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Malaysia
(Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991), Nigeria (Mayne 1917), Uganda (Gowdey 1912)

Adoretus versutus Harold
Synonyms: Adoretus umbrosus (Fiji) Fabricius, Adoretus umbrosus tenuimaculatus (Fiji) Waterhouse,
Adoretus vestitus Boheman
Status: A serious pest of seedling cocoa. Adults, 10-12 mm long, are leaf feeders at night. Also recorded from
coffee
Distribution: Fiji (Jepson 1916), India (Emmanuel Sujatha & Gautam 2010a), Indonesia Java (Entwistle
1972), Vanuatu (Beaudoin et al 1995), Western Samoa (O'Connor 1966)
Primary parasites: Micromeriella marginella modesta (F.Smith), Fiji (Entwistle 1972)

Adoretus vitticauda Arrow
Status: Adults feed on leaves, larvae in the soil.
Distribution: Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)

Anomala aeneotincta Fairmaire
Status: Adults feed on foliage
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Anomala anchoralis Lansberge
Status: Adult 10-12 mm long with anchor shaped marking on the elytra feeding on leaves. Larvae are probably
root feeders.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Kalshoven 1950-51)

Anomala cupripes Hope
Status: Adults feed on foliage
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Lever 1953)

Anomala denuda Arrow
Status: Larvae feed on roots of young trees, and the adults on the foliage where they can cause much damage
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Anomala humeralis Burmeister
Status: Beetle is bronzy green and 11 mm long and feeds on leaves
Distribution: Philippines (Dammerman 1929)

Anomala immarginata Ohaus
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Anomala obsoleta Blanchard
Status: Beetle is bronzy brown with black beneath and 10-12 mm long and feeds on leaves
Distribution: Indonesia (Dammerman 1929)

Anomala pallida (Fabricius)
Status: Adults feed on leaves at night

Rutela lineola (Linnaeus)

Cryphalus kolbei (Hagedorn)
Synonyms: Allarthrum kolbei Hagedorn
Status: A bark beetle which makes a vertical tunnel between the bark and the wood with a number of
horizontal tunnels leading off it.

Cryptocarenus heveae (Hagedorn)
Synonyms: Pityophthorus heveae (Hagedorn)
Status: No record of status

Dryocetoides capucinus (Eichhoff)

Eccoptopterus spinosus (Olivier)
Synonyms: Eccoptopterus sexspinosus Motschulsky
Status: Adults bore tunnels beneath the bark where eggs are laid and larvae develop.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Schedl 1962), Sri Lanka (Schedl 1959), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

86

COLEOPTERA

87

Euwallacea destruens (Blandford)
Synonyms: Xyleborus destruens Blandford
Status: Boring into weakened trees
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Kalshoven 1961), Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Euwallacea fornicatus (Eichhoff)
Synonyms: Xyleborus fornicatus Eichhoff, Xyleborus schultzei Eggers
Status: A small blackish beetle 4-5mm long which bores into the stems and branches where the larvae live in
the tunnels on fungus spores. Branches are weakened by the borings and break easily and the whole plant is
debilitated.
Distribution: Fiji (Swaine 1971), Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1929), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Browne 1961),
Solomon Is (Lever 1968), Sri Lanka (Rutherford 1915)

Euwallacea interjectus (Blandford)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: No locality (Wood & Bright 1992)

Euwallacea laevis (Eggers)
Synonyms: Xyleborus laevis Eggers
Status: Boring into trunk of unhealthy tree
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Browne 1961), Papua New Guinea (Bourke et al 1971)

Euwallacea xanthopus (Eichhoff)
Synonyms: Xyleborus interruptus Eggers, Xyleborus semirudis Blandford
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Schedl 1959)

Hadrodemius ursus (Eggers)
Synonyms: Xyleborus ursus Eggers
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Schedl 1964)

Hypothenemus areccae (Hornung)
Synonyms: Hypothenemus hispidus (Eggers), Hypothenemus polyphagus (Eggers), Hypothenemus subvestitus
Eggers, Hypothenemus vafer Blandford, Stephanoderes polyphagus Eggers
Status: Recorded from dry pods in Malaysia. Also on coffee.
Distribution: Ghana (Schedl 1964), Ivory Coast (Entwistle 1972), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941),
Nigeria (Schedl 1964), Zaire (Eggers 1924)

Hypothenemus ater (Eggers)
Synonyms: Stylotentus ater Eggers
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ghana (Entwistle 1960a), Nigeria (Entwistle 1960a), Zaire (Schedl 1961)

Hypothenemus birmanus (Eichhoff)
Synonyms: Stephanoderes alter Eggers, Stephanoderes birmanus Eichhoff
Status: The insect is a twig borer
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Browne 1961)

Hypothenemus camerunus (Eggers)
Synonyms: Stephanoderes camerunus Eggers
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Sierra Leone (Schedl 1962), Zaire (Schedl 1962)

Hypothenemus concolor (Hagedorn)
Synonyms: Stylotentus concolor (Hagedorn)
Status: A twig borer
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Schedl 1962), Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Hypothenemus criticus (Schedl)
Synonyms: Stylotentus criticus (Schedl)
Status: A branch borer
Distribution: Zaire (Schedl 1961)

COLEOPTERA

Hypothenemus erectus Le Conte
Status: Boring into trunk
Distribution: Venezuela (Jimenez 2003)

Hypothenemus eruditus (Westwood)
Synonyms: Hypothenemus bicolor Schedl, Hypothenemus pusillus Eggers
Status: No record of status. Probably a branch borer
Distribution: Congo (Schedl 1961), Ghana (Entwistle 1972), Indonesia Java (Schedl 1962), Ivory Coast
(Entwistle 1972), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Schedl 1962), Mexico (Perez De la Cruz et al 2009), Nigeria
(Entwistle 1972), Sierra Leone (Entwistle 1960a), Venezuela (Goitia & Rosales 2001), Zaire (Eggers 1927)

Hypothenemus grandis Schedl
Status: No record of status. Probably a branch borer
Distribution: Zaire (Schedl 1962)

Hypothenemus hampei (Ferrari)
Synonyms: Stephanoderes hampei Ferrari, Stephanoderes punctatus Eggers
Status: A major pest of coffee but only occasionally found on cocoa. Alternative hosts are Tephrosia,
Crotalaria, Centrosema, Caesalpinia, Leucaena glauca, Hibiscus, Rubus, Vitis lanceolaria, Ligustrum
pubinerve, Oxycanthus, Phaseolus lunatus, Dialium lacourtiana
Distribution: Ghana (Entwistle 1972), Ivory Coast (Entwistle 1972), Nigeria (Schedl 1964), Zaire (Eggers
1924)

Hypothenemus intricatus (Schedl)
Synonyms: Stephanoderes intricatus Schedl
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Uganda (Schedl 1962)

Hypothenemus javanus (Eggers)
Synonyms: Hypothenemus subagnatus (Eggers), Stephanoderes subagnatus Eggers
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Hypothenemus liberiensis Hopkins
Synonyms: Stephanoderes theobromae Eggers
Status: No record of status. Probably a branch borer
Distribution: Zaire (Schedl 1962)

Hypothenemus morio (Eggers)
Synonyms: Stephanoderes morio Eggers
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Zaire (Schedl 1962)

Hypothenemus mozambiquensis Eggers
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Sierra Leone (Entwistle 1960a)

Hypothenemus mulongensis Eggers
Status: Boring into fruit
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Entwistle 1960a), Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Hypothenemus obscurus (Fabricius)
Synonyms: Hypothenemus hispidulus (Leconte), Stephanoderes guatemalensis Hopkins, Stephanoderes
heterolepis Da Costa Lima, Stephanoderes obscurus (Fabricius), Stephanoderes seriatus Eichhoff
Status: Of minor importance.
Distribution: Brazil (Da Costa Lima 1928), Mexico (Dampf 1928)

Hypothenemus opacus (Eichhoff)
Status: Boring into trunk. Of minor importance.
Distribution: Venezuela (Jimenez 2003)

Xyleborus asper Eggers
Status: No record of status

Xyleborus barumbuensis Eggers
Status: No record of status

Status: No record of status

Xyleborus commixtus Blandford
Status: No record of status
Distribution: No locality (Wood & Bright 1992)

Xyleborus dolosus Blandford
Status: Bores into trunks of trees particularly cankered ones.
Distribution: No locality (Dammerman 1929)

Xyleborus ferox Blandford
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Costa Rica (Wood 1982)

Xyleborus ferrugineus (Fabricius)
Synonyms: Xyleborus amplicollis Eichhoff, Xyleborus argentinensis Schedl, Xyleborus bispinatus Eichhoff,
Xyleborus confusus Eichhoff, Xyleborus fuscatus Eichhoff, Xyleborus hopkinsi Beeson, Xyleborus impressus
Eichhoff, Xyleborus insularis Sharp, Xyleborus notatus Eggers, Xyleborus nyssae Hopkins, Xyleborus
planicollis Zimmerman, Xyleborus schedli Eggers, Xyleborus tanganus Hagedorn
Status: Trees are attacked in the collar region both above and below ground. The adult beetle excavates a
branching tunnel horizontally into the wood which may penetrate to a depth of 5cm or more. The larvae are
reared within this tunnel system on fungi which grow on the tunnel walls. In Central and South America this
species is associated with a wilt disease of cocoa caused by Ceratocystis fimbriata.
Distribution: Brazil (Beaver 1976), Costa Rica (Eggers 1934), Ecuador (Saunders & Knoke 1967), Mexico
(Perez De la Cruz et al 2009), Trinidad & Tobago (Iton & Conway 1961), Venezuela (Goitia & Rosales 2001),
Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Xyleborus ficus Eggers
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Schedl 1962)

Xyleborus haberkorni Eggers
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Schedl 1962)

Xyleborus horridatus Wood
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Costa Rica (Wood 1982)

Xyleborus lacunatus Wood
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Costa Rica (Wood & Bright 1992)

Xyleborus macer Blandford
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Venezuela (Wood 1982)

Xyleborus maynei Schedl
Status: Boring into trunks
Distribution: Zaire (Mayné & Donis 1962)

Xyleborus volvulus (Fabricius)

Status: Recorded from decaying pods
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941), Mexico (Perez De la Cruz et al 2009), Zaire (Mayné &
Donis 1962)

COLEOPTERA

94

Xylosandrus compactus (Eichhoff)
Synonyms: Coccotrypes pygmaeus (Nigeria) Eichhoff, Xyleborus compactus Eichhoff, Xyleborus morstatti
(Hagedorn)
Status: The female makes a nest by boring into a shoot or small branch. Once having penetrated to the heart of
the shoot, the tunnel continues longitudinal either up or down the branch. The larvae feed on ambrosia fungi
cultivated on the walls of the tunnel
Distribution: Cameroon (Entwistle 1960a), Ghana (Anon 1951), Ivory Coast (Magnin 1954), Malaysia W.
Malaysia (Browne 1961), Nigeria (Gregory 1954), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964), Sierra
Leone (Hargreaves, E. 1930)

Xylosandrus crassiusculus (Motschulsky)
Synonyms: Xyleborus semigranosus Blandford, Xyleborus semiopacus Eichhoff
Status: A branch borer with a wide range of recorded hosts
Distribution: Ghana (Entwistle 1960a), Ivory Coast (Entwistle 1960a), Papua New Guinea (Bourke et al
1971), Sri Lanka (Schedl 1959), Zaire (Eggers 1927)

Xylosandrus curtulus (Eichhoff)
Synonyms: Xyleborus curtulus Eichhoff
Status: Beetles bore into wood and have a relationship with Ceratocystis fimbriata causing Cocoa Necrosis
Distribution: Venezuela (Goitia & Rosales 2001)

Xylosandrus discolor (Blandford)
Status: The adult makes galleries in green twigs where the larvae later develop leading to shoot dieback.
Alternative host plants include Albizia, cinnamon, coffee, Grevillea and Lonicera
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Schedl 1959)

Xylosandrus discolor posticestriatus (Eggers)
Status: Boring into leaf axils on unhealthy trees.
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Xylosandrus mancus (Blandford)
Synonyms: Xyleborus abruptus Sampson, Xyleborus mancus Blandford
Status: Recorded from decaying pods
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941), Sri Lanka (Hagedorn 1913)

Xylosandrus morigerus (Blandford)
Synonyms: Xyleborus coffeae Wurth
Status: The adult makes a gallery in twigs where the eggs are laid. The larvae extend the burrow where they
feed on fungus spores. The resulting damage causes the twig to die. Damage can be severe. Alternative host
palnts include orchids, tea, coffee, Camphor, Dendrobium, Bombax, Swietenia, Crotalaria, Leucaena, Tectona,
Tephrosia
Distribution: Brazil (Nakayama & Terra 1986), Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924), Venezuela (Jimenez 2003)

Xylosandrus ursinus (Hagedorn)
Synonyms: Xyleborus ursinus Hagedorn
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Praeugena aurichalcea Quedenfeldt
Status: The adults are often found on cocoa trees and appear to feed on bark but are not important
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Tenebroides mauritanicus Linnaeus
Status: Although this species is primarily a predator in storage it will also feed on cocoa beans.
Distribution: Brazil (De Abreu & Williams 1980), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus
& Ho 1980), Nigeria (Mejule & Onyuike 1979)
Predator of: Lasioderma serricorne Fabricius, Nigeria (Riley 1969b)

97

Tribolium castaneum Herbst
Status: Both adults and larvae feed mainly on grain in store but will attack cocoa beans.

et al 1999), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Malaysia Sabah (Asimah & Lopez 2000), Malaysia Sarawak

Breese & Mcfarlane 1962)

Status: Both adults and larvae feed mainly on grain in store but will attack cocoa beans.

DIPTERA CECIDOMYIIDAE
Clinodiplosis sp.
Status: Adults visit flowers and are pollinators
Distribution: Belize (Young 1985), Costa Rica (Young 1985)

Coccodiplosis coffeae (Barnes)
Synonyms: Schizobremia coffeae Barnes
Status: Larvae are parasites of coccids
Distribution: Ghana (Donald 1956), Sao Tome & Principe (Prinsloo 1979), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Primary parasites: Cheiloneurus carinatus Compere, Ghana (Ackonor & Mordjifa 1999)
Coccidoctonus pseudococci (Risbec), Ghana (Ackonor & Mordjifa 1999), Sao Tome & Principe (Prinsloo
1979)
Predator of: Ferrisia virgata (Cockerell), Ghana (Donald 1956)
Formicococcus njalensis (Laing), Ghana (Ackonor & Mordjifa 1999), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Phenacoccus hargreavesi (Laing), Ghana (Donald 1956)
Planococcus citri (Risso), Ghana (Donald 1956)

Megommata donaldi (Pritchard)
Synonyms: Coccomyza donaldi Pritchard
Status: Larvae are predators
Distribution: Ghana (Pritchard 1952)
Predator of: Phenacoccus hargreavesi (Laing), Ghana (Pritchard 1952)

99

Dasyhelea sp. near grisea (Coquillett)

Dasyhelea williamsi Wirth & Waugh
Status: Adults visit flowers and are potential pollinators
Distribution: Brazil (Wirth & Waugh 1976), Dominica (Wirth & Waugh 1976), Panama (Wirth & Waugh
1976), Trinidad & Tobago (Wirth & Waugh 1976)

HETEROPTERA
HETEROPTERA ACANTHOSOMATIDAE
Catadipson sus Breddin
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

HETEROPTERA ALYDIDAE
Riptortus sp.
Status: Adults and nymphs occasionaly cause damage by sucking shoots.
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

HETEROPTERA ANTHOCORIDAE
Dufouriellus ater (Dufour)
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Nigeria (Mejule & Onyuike 1979)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Nigeria (Mejule & Onyuike 1979)

Lasiochilus sp.
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941)

Xylocoris afer (Reuter)
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Nigeria (Riley & Simmons 1968)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Nigeria (Riley & Simmons 1968)

Xylocoris flavipes (Reuter)
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Nigeria (Okobi 1980)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Nigeria (Okobi 1980)

Xylocoris sp.
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Nigeria (Mejule & Onyuike 1979)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Nigeria (Mejule & Onyuike 1979)

HETEROPTERA ARADIDAE
Brachyrhynchus furcatus Germar
Synonyms: Mezira furcata Germar
Status: The insect is a fungus feeder and is only associated with moribund cocoa trees attacked by Fomes.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Mezira affinis (Signoret)
Status: Species of this family are known as flat bugs and generally live beneath loose bark of dead branches
where they feed on fungus.
Distribution: Ghana (Gibbs & Leston 1970)

HETEROPTERA

114

Mezira rugosa (Signoret)
Status: Species of this family are known as flat bugs and generally live beneath loose bark of dead branches
where they feed on fungus.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1967), Ghana (Majer 1975)

Mezira sp.
Status: Browny black and about 8 mm long. In the Ivory Coast it is often found on older leaves of both cocoa
and coffee.
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Usingeria mirabilis Schouteden
Status: Species of this family are known as flat bugs and generally live beneath loose bark of dead branches
where they feed on fungus.
Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1967)

HETEROPTERA BERYTIDAE
Capyella sp.
Synonyms: Gombura sp.
Status: No record of status. Usually on grasses.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Jalysus reversus Duzee
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Callan 1957)

Metacanthus pulchellus Dallas
Synonyms: Gampsochoris pulchellus Dallas
Status: Both adults and nymphs feed on green shoots and sometimes on the leaf midribs. Brown spots appear
on the shoots as a result of feeding and eventually the shoot may wilt.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941)
Predators: Cosmolestes picticeps Stal, Malaysia (Miller 1941)

Parajalysus spinosus Distant
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Peru (Wille 1942)

HETEROPTERA BRACHYPLATIDAE
Caternaultiella guineensis Spinola
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

HETEROPTERA COREIDAE
Acanthocoris dentatus Haglund
Synonyms: Homoeocerus dentatus (Haglund)
Status: Mainly found on Leguminosae but occasionally feeds on young cocoa.
Distribution: Nigeria (Golding 1941a)

Acanthotyla distinguenda Blote
Status: Found in small numbers on pods and branches close to the ground
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Acanthotyla sp.
Status: Adults numerous mainly on pod peduncles
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

HETEROPTERA

115

Amblypelta ardleyi Brown
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on pods
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Amblypelta coccophaga malaitensis Brown
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on pods and shoots. It is a serious pest of coconut causing premature nutfall
Distribution: Solomon Is (Brown 1958)

Amblypelta cocophaga coccophaga China
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on pods and shoots. It is a serious pest of coconut causing premature nutfall
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961), Solomon Is (Lever 1968)

Amblypelta costalis szentivanyi Brown
Status: Has been recorded feeding on pods but does not commonly do so
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Amblypelta gallegonis bougainvillensis Brown
Status: Recorded as a pod feeder
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Amblypelta gallegonis Lever
Status: Recorded as a shoot feeder
Distribution: Solomon Is (Lever 1968)

Amblypelta madangana Brown & Ghauri
Status: An occasional feeder on pods but cocoa is clearly not a preferred host.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

Amblypelta theobromae Brown
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on pods and shoots causing die-back to the latter
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Anoplocnemis phasiana (Fabricius)
Status: An occasional pest which feeds by sucking shoots. Mainly on Leguminosae but also recorded from tea
and citrus.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941)

Brachylybas inflexus Blote
Status: Feeding on pods
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Clavigralla horrida (Germar)
Synonyms: Acanthomia horrida Germar
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Cletomorpha lancigera (Fabricius)
Status: Occasionally common on unshaded cocoa when the weeds on which it feeds are cleared. Usually on
Amaranthus
Distribution: Equatorial Africa Bioko (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934), Nigeria (Golding 1941a), Sao Tome &
Principe (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Cletus ochraceus (Herrich-Shaffer)
Status: Occasionally common on unshaded cocoa when the weeds on which it feeds are cleared. Also found
on guava.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Cletus unifasciatus (Blote)
Synonyms: Cletomorpha unifasciata Blote, Cletomorpha unifasciatus Blote
Status: Russet coloured with patches of yellow and around 7 mm long. It feeds principally on Amaranthaceae
but may feed on young cocoa leaves from time to time.
Distribution: Ghana (Lodos 1967a), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

HETEROPTERA

116

Dalader acuticosta Amyot & Serville
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Homoeocerus ignotus Schouteden
Status: Principally found on leguminous shade trees but may move onto coffee or cocoa from time to time. On
cocoa it feeds on young pods. The adult is about 15 mm long.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Homoeocerus pallens (Fabricius)
Status: Mainly found on Leguminosae but occasionally feeds on pods by sucking them. Also recorded from
coffee.
Distribution: Ghana (Cotterell 1927c), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Homoeocerus punctum Dallas
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Homoeocerus sp.
Status: Feeding on pods
Distribution: Ghana (Lodos 1967a), Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Hydara tenuicornis (Westwood)
Status: Adults and nymphs recorded as feeding on young cocoa leaves. Lodos (1967a) states that it is confined
to leguminous plants and does not feed on cocoa
Distribution: Ghana (Lodos 1967a), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Leptocorisa lepida Breddon
Status: Known as a pest of rice, it is not important on cocoa
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Leptoglossus australis (Fabricius)
Status: Adults and nymphs occasionaly cause damage by sucking shoots.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Leptoglossus dilaticollis Guerin Meneville
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Da Costa Lima 1936)

Leptoglossus gonagra (Fabricius)
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Dominican Republic (Anon 1933)

Megalotomus rufipes (Westwood)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Costa Rica (Entwistle 1972)

Mictis longicornis Westwood
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Petalocnemis sp.
Status: Nymphs recorded as puncturing pods and producing lesions similar to Helopeltis.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Priocnemicoris flaviceps (Guerin-Meneville)
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Pseudotheraptus devastans (Distant)
Synonyms: Pendulinus devastans Distant
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on pods producing spotting. Also recorded from rubber.
Distribution: Ghana (Lodos 1965), Nigeria (Entwistle 1972), Zaire (Distant 1918)

HETEROPTERA

117

Predators: Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Ghana (Lodos 1967a)
Pheidole megacephala (Fabricius), Ghana (Lodos 1967a)

Pseudotheraptus wayi Brown
Synonyms: Theraptus sp. (EastAfrica)
Status: An important pest of coconuts, adults and nymphs sometimes attack the pods of cocoa producing
spotting.
Distribution: Tanzania Pemba (Way 1953), Tanzania Zanzibar (Tait 1954)
Predators: Pheidole megacephala (Fabricius), Tanzania Zanzibar (Tait 1954)

Sciophyrus fasciata Walker
Status: In small numbers on pods
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Sciophyrus sp.
Status: Feeding on stalks of pods
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Stenocoris apicalis (Westwood)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (Simmonds 1969)

Theraptus carmelita (Burmeister)
Synonyms: Pendulinus carmelita Burmeister
Status: A polyphagous forest species which feeds on young cocoa leaves causing translucent spots which
become dry and fall out resulting in a characteristic pattern of perforations.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Theraptus sp.
Status: Feeds on leguminous plants, particularly Glyricidia sepium used as temporary shade over young cocoa
but is rarely seen on cocoa.
Distribution: Ghana (Lodos 1967a)

HETEROPTERA CYDNIDAE
Macroscytus sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

HETEROPTERA MIRIDAE
Boxia khayae China
Status: Originally described from Khaya grandifoliola in Ghana, the insect feeds on pods and shoots.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (China 1943)
Primary parasites: Peristenus sahlbergellae (Wilkinson), West Africa (Entwistle 1972)

Boxiopsis madagascariensis Lavabre
Status: Feeding takes place on pods, suckers and branches causing lesions and cankers. Also found on shade
trees.
Distribution: Madagascar (Lavabre 1961)

Bryocoropsis cotterelli China
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on pods in colonies of Sahlbergella
Distribution: Equatorial Guinea Bioko (China 1929), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Bryocoropsis laticollis Schumacher
Status: A brown bug about 8 mm long. Adults and nymphs feed on pods.
Distribution: Equatorial Guinea (Box 1944), Ghana (Box 1943), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Primary parasites: Peristenus sahlbergellae (Wilkinson), West Africa (Box 1943)
Telenomus sp. , Ghana (Lodos 1968b)
Hyperparasites: Mesochorus melanothorax Wilkinson, Ghana (Box 1943)
Predators: Rhynocoris loratus Stal, Ghana (Waters 1941)

Coctoteris winthemii (Guerin-Meneville)
Synonyms: Coctoteris viridescens Walker
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Deraeocoris crigi Gibbs & Leston
Status: Adults are predators.
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)
Predator of: Mesohomotoma tessmanni (Aulmann), Ghana (Lodos 1968c)

Distantiella theobroma (Distant)
Synonyms: Sahlbergella theobroma Distant
Status: A major pest, particularly of unshaded cocoa. Adults and nymphs feed by sucking young shoots and
pods causing necrotic lesions at the point of puncture. Feeding on pods results in black circular spots but as the
mouthparts do not penetrated through the parenchyma the beans are not damaged. Feeding on shoots leads to
more serious damage because the lesions become infected by the fungus Calonectria rigidiuscula which causes
the shoot to die-back. Persistant attack leads to progressive loss of canopy and the induced production of

HETEROPTERA

120

chupon growth which is in turn subject to attack. "Capsid pockets" of these damaged trees form a permanent
permanent breeding reservoir for the pest.
Distribution: Cameroon (Lavabre 1957), Central African Republic (Boulard 1967), Ghana (Dudgeon 1910),
Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Lamborn 1914), Togo (Alibert 1951)
Primary parasites: Encyrtus cotterelli Waterston, Ghana (Waterston 1922)
Euphorus sp. , Ghana (Box 1944)
Telenomus sp. , Ghana (Lodos 1968b)
Predators: Carcinomma astrologus Bergroth, Ghana (Entwistle 1972), Zaire (Entwistle 1972)
Cataspilota misana (Giglio-Tos), Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Cheiracanthium sp. , Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Crematogaster africana Mayr, Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Crematogaster depressa (Latreille), Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Endochus africanus Bergroth, Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Hyllus holochalceus Simon, Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Cameroon (Mpe 2002), Ghana (Williams 1954)
Panurgica compressicollis (Saussure), Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Pheidole megacephala (Fabricius), Ghana (Williams 1954)
Phonoctonus sp. , Ghana (Entwistle 1972)
Platythyrea conradti Emery, Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Prohierodula ornatipennis (Bolivar), Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Rhynocoris albopilosus (Signoret), Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Rhynocoris bicolor (Fabricius), Ghana (Entwistle 1972)
Rhynocoris carmelita (Stal), Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Rhynocoris loratus Stal, Ghana (Waters 1941)
Rhynocoris obtusus (Palisot de Beauvois), Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Rhynocoris tristis Stal, Ghana (Entwistle 1972)
Sphodromantis lineola (Burmeister), Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Tarachodes gerstaeckeri Werner, Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Telamonia sp. , Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Tetramorium aculeatum (Mayr), Cameroon (Mpe 2002), Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Vestula lineaticeps (Signoret), Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Viciria equestris Simon, Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Viciria ocellata (Thorell), Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Wasmannia auropunctata (Roger), Cameroon (Bruneau De Mire 1969)

Helopeltis allaudi Poppius
Status: Both adults and nymphs feed by sucking pods and to a lesser extent green shoots. Feeding results in
the production of brown to black sunken spots which may cover much of the pod.
Distribution: Zaire (Ghesquiere 1922b)

Helopeltis antonii Signoret
Status: Both adults and nymphs feed by sucking pods and to a lesser extent green shoots. Feeding results in
the production of brown to black sunken spots which may cover much of the pod. Many alternative hosts
include tea, cashew, cinchona and mango
Distribution: India (Abraham & Padmanaban 1967), Indonesia Java (Koningsberger 1908), Indonesia Sumatra
(Rutgers 1918), Indonesia West Irian (Ruinard 1959), Sri Lanka (Wright 1907)
Primary parasites: Euphorus helopeltidis Ferriere, Indonesia Java (Betrem 1950)
Predators: Dolichoderus thoracicus (F.Smith), Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Helopeltis bakeri Poppius
Status: Both adults and nymphs feed by sucking pods and to a lesser extent green shoots. Feeding results in
the production of brown to black sunken spots which may cover much of the pod.
Distribution: Philippines (Stonedahl 1991)

Helopeltis bergrothi Reuter
Status: Both adults and nymphs feed by sucking pods and to a lesser extent green shoots. Feeding results in
the production of brown to black sunken spots which may cover much of the pod. Many alternative host plants
include tea, cotton, mango and cinchona
Distribution: Cameroon (Schmitz 1968), Nigeria (Golding 1941a), Tanzania (Harris 1937), Zaire (Mayne &
Ghesquiere 1934)

HETEROPTERA

121

Predators: Leptus sp. , Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Onocephalus subspinosus Amyot & Serville, Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Philodicus temerarius (Walker), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Polytoxus wahlbergi Stal, Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Sastrapoda vicina Schouteden, Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Sphedanolestes picturellus Schouteden, Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Helopeltis bradyi Waterhouse
Synonyms: Helopeltis ceylonensis Silva
Status: Both adults and nymphs feed by sucking pods and to a lesser extent green shoots. Feeding results in
the production of brown to black sunken spots which may cover much of the pod. Alternative host plants
include tea, cashew and cinchona.
Distribution: India (Sundararaju & Babu 1999), Sri Lanka (De Silva 1957)
Predators: Sycanus collaris (Fabricius), Sri Lanka (De Silva 1962)

Helopeltis cinchonae Mann
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on flush leaves and young shoots producing sunken brown spots which are
angular on the leaf blade. As the leaves grow they become distorted. Alternative hosts include cinchona.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1929)

Helopeltis clavifer Walker
Status: Both adults and nymphs feed by sucking pods and to a lesser extent green shoots. Feeding results in
the production of brown to black sunken spots which may cover much of the pod. Alternative host plants
include tea
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Graham 1991), Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961),
Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1964), Malaysia Sarawak (Ron 1985), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)
Predators: Amyotea reciproca Walker, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Dolichoderus thoracicus (F.Smith), Indonesia (Graham 1991)
Euagorus sp. , Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)

Helopeltis collaris Stal
Status: Both adults and nymphs feed by sucking pods and to a lesser extent green shoots. Feeding results in
the production of brown to black sunken spots which may cover much of the pod.
Distribution: Philippines (Viado et al 1965)

Status: Both adults and nymphs feed by sucking pods and to a lesser extent green shoots. Feeding results in
the production of brown to black sunken spots which may cover much of the pod.
Distribution: Cameroon (Schmitz 1968), Congo (Schmitz 1968)

the production of brown to black sunken spots which may
Distribution: China (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997), Malaysia Sabah (Stonedahl 1991)

Helopeltis sumatranus Roepke
Status: Both adults and nymphs feed by sucking pods and to a lesser extent green shoots. Feeding results in
the production of brown to black sunken spots which may

Helopeltis theivora theobromae Miller
Synonyms: Helopeltis theobromae Miller
Status: Both adults and nymphs feed by sucking pods and to a lesser extent green shoots. Feeding results in
the production of brown to black sunken spots which may cover much of the pod. Immature pods when
damaged may fall prematurely but larger pods tend to survive. Alternative host plants include tea, cinchona
and cashew.
Distribution: Indonesia (Graham 1991), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1939)
Primary parasites: Erythmelus helopeltidis Gahan, Malaysia (Ibrahim 1989)
Telenomus sp. , Malaysia (Ibrahim 1989)
Predators: Dolichoderus thoracicus (F.Smith), Indonesia (Graham 1991), Malaysia W.Malaysia (Way &
Khoo 1991)
Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius), Malaysia W.Malaysia (Way & Khoo 1991)

Helopeltis theivora Waterhouse
Status: Both adults and nymphs feed by sucking pods and to a lesser extent green shoots. Feeding results in
the production of brown to black sunken spots which may cover much of the pod. Alternative host plants
include tea, cinchona and cashew.
Distribution: Bangladesh (Mir 1990), India (Sundararaju & Babu 1999), Indonesia Java (Koningsberger
1908), Indonesia Sumatra (Dammerman 1929), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Entwistle 1972)
Primary parasites: Euphorus helopeltidis Ferriere, Indonesia Java (Betrem 1950)
Predators: Dolichoderus thoracicus (F.Smith), Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Status: Both adults and nymphs feed by sucking pods and to a lesser extent green shoots. Feeding results in

Distribution: Nigeria (Golding 1941a)

Horcias punctatus Carvalho

Monalonion annulipes Signoret
Synonyms: Monalonion braconoides Atkinson, Monalonion illustris Distant
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on young shoots and green pods producing necrotic pustules and warty black
spots.
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987), Colombia (Distant 1917), Costa Rica (Morales & Matarita 1961)

Monalonion atratum Distant
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on young shoots and green pods producing necrotic pustules and warty black

Status: Adults and nymphs feed on young shoots and green pods producing necrotic pustules and warty black

(Wille 1952), Venezuela (Hernandez Palma & Pedrique 1958)

Monalonion schaefferi Stal
Synonyms: Monalonion flavisignatum Knight, Monalonion xanthophilum Walker, Mosquilla vastatrix
Zehntener
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on young shoots and green pods producing necrotic pustules and warty black

Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939b)

Monalonion versicolor Distant
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on young shoots and green pods producing necrotic pustules and warty black
spots.
Distribution: Costa Rica (Morales & Vargas 1961)

Odoniella reuteri Haglund
Status: Feeds on stems. Uncommon on cocoa
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Odoniella rubra Reuter
Status: Feeding on pods only.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Lavabre Decelle & Debord 1963)

Platyngomiriodes apiformis Ghauri
Status: Feeds on pods and shoots often leading to fungal attack.
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1964)

Proboscidocoris fuliginosus Reuter
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Proboscidocoris sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Prodromus sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

HETEROPTERA

124

Pseudodoniella duni (China & Carvalho)
Synonyms: Parabryocoropsis duni China & Carvalho
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on pods and shoots and are important pests
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (China & Carvalho 1951)

Pseudodoniella laensis Miller
Synonyms: Pseudodoniella szentivanyi Miller
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on pods and shoots and are important pests
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Papua New Guinea (Miller 1957)
Predators: Amyotea reciproca Walker, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Euagorus sp. , Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)

Pseudodoniella pacifica China & Carvalho
Synonyms: Pseudodoniella cheesmanae China & Carvalho
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on pods and shoots and are important pests
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (China & Carvalho 1951)

Pseudodoniella typica (China & Carvalho)
Synonyms: Parabryocoropsis typicus China & Carvalho
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on pods and shoots and are important pests
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Papua New Guinea (China & Carvalho
1951), Philippines (Entwistle & Youdeowei 1964)
Predators: Aulacagonia cheesmanae Miller, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius), Papua New Guinea (Dun 1954a)
Pristhesancus sp. , Papua New Guinea (Dun 1954a)

Pycnoderes incurvus (Distant)
Status: No record of status. It is well known as a pest of squash and melon.
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

Sahlbergella singularis Haglund
Status: A major pest, particularly of unshaded cocoa. Adults and nymphs feed by sucking young shoots and
pods causing necrotic lesions at the point of puncture. Feeding on pods results in black circular spots but as the
mouthparts do not penetrated through the parenchyma the beans are not damaged. Feeding on shoots leads to
more serious damage because the lesions become infected by the fungus Calonectria rigidiuscula which causes
the shoot to die-back. Persistant attack leads to progressive loss of canopy and the induced production of
chupon growth which is in turn subject to attack. "Capsid pockets" of these damaged trees form a permanent
permanent breeding reservoir for the pest.
Distribution: Cameroon (Warburg 1902), Central African Republic (Boulard 1967), Dahomey (Box 1944),
Equatorial Guinea Bioko (Cotterell 1930a), Ghana (Patterson 1914), Ivory Coast (Fourneau 1928), Nigeria
(Lamborn 1914), Sierra Leone (Gerard 1964a), Togo (Alibert 1951), Zaire (Bredo 1931)
Primary parasites: Encyrtus cotterelli Waterston, Zaire (Alibert 1951)
Peristenus sahlbergellae (Wilkinson), Cameroon (Box 1944), Equatorial Guinea Bioko (Squire 1947), Ghana
(Wilkinson 1927), Ivory Coast (Squire 1947), Nigeria (Box 1944), Zaire (Squire 1947)
Telenomus sp. , Ghana (Lodos 1968b)
Hyperparasites: Mesochorus melanothorax Wilkinson, Cameroon (Box 1944), Ghana (Wilkinson 1927),
Nigeria (Box 1944)
Predators: Carcinomma astrologus Bergroth, Ghana (Entwistle 1972), Zaire (Ghesquiere 1922a)
Cataspilota misana (Giglio-Tos), Ghana (Collingwood 1971)
Homoeogryllus tessellatus Serville, Zaire (Alibert 1951)
Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Cameroon (Mpe 2002), Ghana (Cotterell 1943), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951),
Togo (Alibert 1951)
Onocephalus subspinosus Amyot & Serville, Zaire (Entwistle 1972)
Panurgica compressicollis (Saussure), Ghana (Collingwood 1971)
Phonoctonus sp. , Ghana (Entwistle 1972)
Polytoxus wahlbergi Stal, Zaire (Entwistle 1972)
Prohierodula ornatipennis (Bolivar), Ghana (Collingwood 1971)
Rhynocoris bicolor (Fabricius), Ghana (Entwistle 1972)
Rhynocoris loratus Stal, Ghana (Waters 1941)
Rhynocoris obtusus (Palisot de Beauvois), Ghana (Entwistle 1972)
Rhynocoris sp. , Ghana (Collingwood 1971)

HETEROPTERA

Rhynocoris tristis Stal, Ghana (Entwistle 1972)

Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Xenetomorpha carpenteri Poppius
Status: In colour and appearance it resembles the ant, Oecophylla longinoda, and lives among colonies of the
ant receiving protection from it.
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Status: No record of status

Status: Status on cocoa not recorded. More usually a pest of soyabean
Distribution: Brazil (Grazia 1979)

Aethemenes chloris (Dallas)
Synonyms: Acrosternum chloris Dallas
Status: Adults and nymphs feed by sucking sap from pods. Also recorded from cotton.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Agonoscelis versicolor (Fabricius)

Status: Feeding on pods
Distribution: Colombia (De Franco 1958)

Antiteuchus amplus (Walker)
Synonyms: Mecistorhinus amplus (Walker)
Status: Adults and nymphs live in colonies on branches and also attack pods causing small lesions.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1924d)

Antiteuchus mixtus (Fabricius)
Synonyms: Antiteuchus variolosus Dallas
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Antiteuchus piceus (Palisot de Beauvais)
Synonyms: Mecistorhinus piceus (Palisot de Beauvais)
Status: Normally feed on pods but can be troublesome in nurseries feeding on shoots
Distribution: Colombia (De Franco 1958), Trinidad & Tobago (Callan 1944)
Primary parasites: Phanuropsis semiflaviventris Girault, Trinidad & Tobago (Callan 1944)

Antiteuchus punctissimus Ruckes

Antiteuchus tripterus (Fabricius)
Synonyms: Mecistorhinus tripterus (Fabricius)
Status: Feeds on branches and flower cushions but more often on pedicels of pods and always in shade. Is
associated with Monilia pod rot.
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli Silviera & De Barros-Mendes 1989), Colombia (De Franco 1958), Costa Rica
(Entwistle 1972), Trinidad & Tobago (Callan 1944), Venezuela (Salas 1984)

(Callan 1944), Venezuela (Salas 1984)

Podisus sp. , Colombia (Eberhard 1974)

Antiteuchus tripterus limbativentris Ruckes
Status: Feeds on branches and flower cushions but more often on pedicels of pods and always in shade. Is

Apateticus sp.
Status: No record of status. Some species of this genus are predators

Aspavia hastator (Fabricius)
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Aspongopus dubitabilis Fairmaire
Synonyms: Coridius dubitabilis (Fairmaire)
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on branches, leaves and pods.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1967), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Atelocera armata Laporte
Status: Both adults and nymphs feed on young pods and green shoots.
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Atelocera attenuata Distant
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on shoots and green pods causing spotted lesions. More commonly found on
shaded cocoa.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Atelocera natalensis Stal
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on shoots causing spotted lesions. More commonly found on unshaded cocoa.
Also recorded from cotton.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Atelocera raptoria Germar
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on shoots and green pods causing spotted lesions.
Distribution: Nigeria (Golding 1935)

Atelocera serrata (Fabricius)
Status: A brown bug with grey spots around 20 mm long. Both adults and nymphs feed on young pods and
green shoots. It can at times be a significant pest.
Distribution: Cameroon (Lavabre 1957), Central African Republic (Boulard 1967), Ghana (Majer 1975),
Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Atelocera sp.
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on shoots and green pods causing spotted lesions.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Lavabre Decelle & Debord 1963), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Atelocera spinulosa (Palisot de Beauvais)
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on shoots and green pods causing spotted lesions. More commonly found on
shaded cocoa. Also found on cinchona
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Atelocera stictica (Westwood)
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on shoots causing spotted lesions. More commonly found on unshaded cocoa.
Also recorded from cotton.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

HETEROPTERA

128

Austromalaya sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Bathycoelia ovalis Stal
Status: Adults and nymphs feed by sucking young pods.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1967), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Gerard 1964b)

Bathycoelia thalassina (Herrich-Schaffer)
Status: Adults and nymphs feed by sucking young pods which turn yellow and finally black. The long stylets
penetrate the husk into the developing beans. Some feeding may take place on leaf veins if no pods are
available. Alternative host plants include a range of wild fruits and there are records of attack to citrus and
coffee.
Distribution: Cameroon (Aulmann & La Baume 1912), Ghana (Gerard 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951),
Nigeria (Entwistle 1972), Zaire (Mayne 1917)
Primary parasites: Acroclisoides africanus Ferriere, Ghana (Lodos 1968b)
Anastatus sp. , Ghana (Lodos 1968b)
Cylindromyia eronis Curran, Ghana (Gerard 1966b), Nigeria (Eguagie 1975a)
Ooencyrtus sp. , Ghana (Lodos 1968b)
Telenomus sp. , Ghana (Lodos 1968b)
Telenomus sp. near seychellensis (Kieffer), Ghana (Lodos 1968b)
Trissolcus sp. , Ghana (Owusu-Manu 1975)
Hyperparasites: Acroclisoides africanus Ferriere, Ghana (Lodos 1968c)
Pediobius sp. , Ghana (Lodos 1968c)
Predators: Acanthaspis bilineolata (Palisot de Beauvois), Nigeria (Eguagie 1975a)
Cenaeus sp. , Ghana (Lodos 1968b)
Crematogaster clariventris (Mayr), Ghana (Firempong 1976)
Crematogaster depressa (Latreille), Ghana (Lodos 1968b)
Miomantis paykullii Stal, Nigeria (Eguagie 1975a)
Odontogonus dimenis Schouteden, Ghana (Owusu-Manu 1975)
Odontomachus haematodus (Linnaeus), Nigeria (Eguagie 1975a)
Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Ghana (Owusu-Manu 1975), Nigeria (Eguagie 1975a)
Pachycondyla tarsata (Fabricius), Nigeria (Eguagie 1975a)
Pheidole megacephala (Fabricius), Ghana (Lodos 1968b)
Polyspilota aeruginosa (Goeze), Nigeria (Eguagie 1975a)
Sphesianolestes sp. , Nigeria (Eguagie 1975a)
Sphodromantis lineola (Burmeister), Nigeria (Eguagie 1975a)
Tetraponera sp. , Ghana (Lodos 1968b)
Theopompella westwoodi (Kirby), Ghana (Lodos 1968b)

Bathycoelia variolaria Distant
Status: Adults and nymphs feed by sucking young pods
Distribution: Ghana (Lodos 1967b)

Beroaldus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Carbula sp.
Status: Chestnut coloured and about 7 mm long. It is principally found on Amaranthaceae but occasionally
feeds on the leaves of cocoa.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Cardiophthalmus sexspinosus Assmann

Caura bipartita (Signoret)

Cryptacrus novemmaculatus (Signoret)

Status: Feeding on pods and of minor importance

Edessa cornuta Burmeister

Halyomorpha annulicornis (Signoret)
Status: Normally a pest of cotton it has been recorded feeding on green pods.

Tectocoris diophthalmus (Thunberg)
Synonyms: Tectocoris lineola Fabricius
Status: Adult 15-20 mm long and ochreous yellow with blue spotting which many vary from none to more or
less entire steel blue. It is primarily a pest of cotton and Hibiscus but occasionally seen on cocoa
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Dammerman 1929)

HETEROPTERA PYRRHOCORIDAE
Antilochus boerhaviae (Fabricius)
Status: The general colour is black but the pronotum is bordered with orange yellow. Length about 15 to 18
mm.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Callibaphus longirostris (Drury)
Status: Brown colour spotted with red and about 25 to 35 mm long. Feeds on pods sucking the contents of the
beans and causing the pods to turn yellow prematurely. It is not common
Distribution: Ghana (Lodos 1968a), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Booker 1968)

Cenaeus sp.
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Ghana (Lodos 1968b)
Predator of: Bathycoelia thalassina (Herrich-Schaffer), Ghana (Lodos 1968b)

Dindymus pyrochrous (Boisduval)
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Predator of: Mambara inconspicua Bethune-Baker, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)

Dysdercus andreae (Linnaeus)
Status: A pest of cotton. Not of importance on cocoa
Distribution: Dominican Republic (Anon 1933)

Dysdercus cingulatus (Fabricius)
Status: An important cotton pest. Not of importance on cocoa
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Dysdercus longirostris Stal
Status: Reported to heavily infest pods in Brazil.
Distribution: Brazil (De Abreu & Silva 1972)

Dysdercus superstitiosus (Fabricius)
Status: A serious pest of cotton and other Malvaceae. Mayne & Ghesquiere are of the opinion that the
presence of this species on cocoa is probably accidental since it does not appear to feed on pods and suggest
that the insect may be feeding primarily on shade plants.
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919c), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

HETEROPTERA

Endochus africanus Bergroth
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Predator of: Distantiella theobroma (Distant), Ghana (Marchart 1968)

Euagorus sp.
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Predator of: Helopeltis clavifer Walker, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Pseudodoniella laensis Miller, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)

Helonotus exsugiens Stal
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Predator of: Tiracola plagiata (Walker), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)

Margasus afzelii (Stal)
Status: Adults and nymphs are predators
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Ghana (Majer 1975)

Status: Adults and nymphs are predators
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Ghana (Majer 1975)

Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Predator of: Pantorhytes szentivanyi Marshall, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)

Odontogonus dimenis Schouteden
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Ghana (Owusu-Manu 1975)
Predator of: Bathycoelia thalassina (Herrich-Schaffer), Ghana (Owusu-Manu 1975)

Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Predator of: Helopeltis bergrothi Reuter, Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Ghana (Entwistle 1972)
Predator of: Distantiella theobroma (Distant), Ghana (Entwistle 1972)
Sahlbergella singularis Haglund, Ghana (Entwistle 1972)

Physoderes sp.
Status: Adults found in old Pantorhytes larval tunnels, probably feeding on detritus
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Bourke et al 1971)

Polytoxus wahlbergi Stal
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Predator of: Helopeltis bergrothi Reuter, Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

HETEROPTERA TINGIDAE
Ammianus alberti (Schouteden)
Synonyms: Phyllontocheila alberti Schouteden
Status: Feeds on underside of the leaf
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Eocader vegrandis Drake & Hambleton
Status: Feeds on chupons an stalks of young pods
Distribution: Brazil (De Abreu & Silva 1972)

Habrochila placida Horvath
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on the underside of the leaves. Attacks are sporadic but can occasionally lead
to complete defoliation.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Phatnoma sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Stephanitis typica (Distant)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Tigava convexicollis Champion
Status: No record of status but presumably a leaf feeder
Distribution: Peru (Wille 1952)

Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

HOMOPTERA AETALIONIDAE
Aetalion reticulatum (Linnaeus)
Status: Feeding on shoots and branches
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a), Peru (Escalante 1974)

HOMOPTERA ALEYRODIDAE
Aleurodicus cocois (Curtis)
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Aleurodicus dispersus Russell
Status: Spiralling whitefly is a pest of a wide range of crops causing premature leaf drop
Distribution: Cameroon (Evans 2007)

Aleurodicus fucatus Bondar
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Aleurodicus neglectus (Quaintance & Baker)
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Aleurodicus pulvinatus (Maskell)
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Aleurodicus sp.
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Evans 2007)

Aleurothrixus floccosus (Maskell)
Status: Feeding on leaves. Fourth and fifth instar nymphs are covered in woolly filaments
Distribution: Colombia (Moncayo 1958), Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

HOMOPTERA

139

Aleurotrachelus granosus Bondar
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Aleurotrachelus sp. near mesuae Corbett
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Aleurotrachelus theobromae Bondar
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Aleurotrachelus trachoides (Back)
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Cuba (Vazquez 1999)

Bemisia tabaci Gennadius
Synonyms: Bemisia gossypiperda mosaicivectura Ghesquiere
Status: Polyphagous on a wide range of field crops, it is an important vector of a number of virus diseases. On
cocoa, feeding produces a clear yellow spot on the leaf about 5mm in diameter which later turns into a raised
spot.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Dialeuropora papillata Cohic
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: No locality (Mound & Halsey 1978)

Lecanoideus floccissimus Martin et al
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Mexico (Cortéz-Madrigal et al 2008)
Predators: Ceraeochrysa sp. , Mexico (Cortéz-Madrigal et al 2008)

Paraleyrodes crateraformans Bondar
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Tetraleurodes cacaorum (Bondar)
Synonyms: Aleurotrachelus cacaorum Bondar
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

HOMOPTERA APHIDIDAE
Aphis craccivora Koch
Status: The aphid is more commonly associated with Leguminosae. It has been recorded as a casual feeder on
cocoa grown under the shade of Gliricidia sepium.
Distribution: Mexico (Sanchez-Soto & Cortez-Madrigal 1998), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1955)

Aphis gossypii Glover
Status: Feeding on flower pedicels, often in large colonies and almost always attended by ants.
Distribution: China (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997), Costa Rica (Shenefelt Stelzer & Lara 1960), India
(Abraham & Padmanaban 1967), Indonesia Java (Van der Goot 1917a), Jamaica (Entwistle 1972), Nigeria
(Entwistle 1972), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964), Sudan (Schmutterer 1969), Taiwan (Li Wang
& Waterhouse 1997)
Tended by: Crematogaster limata F.Smith, Costa Rica (Lara & Shenefelt 1961)
Ectatomma tuberculatum punctigerum Weber, Costa Rica (Lara & Shenefelt 1961)

Aphis spiraecola Patch
Synonyms: Aphis citricola Van der Goot
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Cameroon (Dejean et al 1991)

HOMOPTERA

140

Tended by: Crematogaster depressa (Latreille), Cameroon (Dejean et al 1991)

Asteropteryx rappardi (Hille Ris Lambers)
Synonyms: Cervaphis rappardi (Hille Ris Lambers)
Status: Found in large numbers on flower stems and base of flowers
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Lambers 1956), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Aulacorthum circumflexum (Buckton)
Synonyms: Neomyzus circumflexus (Buckton)
Status: Causes leaf corrugation leading to premature fall.
Distribution: Costa Rica (Salas & Hansen 1962)

Cerataphis variabilis Hille Ris Lambers
Status: Found on flowers
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Cervaphis schouteniae Van der Goot
Status: Found on flowers
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Van der Goot 1917a), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Myzus persicae (Sulzer)
Status: Feeding on foliage
Distribution: Dominican Republic (Schmutterer 1990)

Sitobion martorelli (Smith)
Synonyms: Macrosiphum martorelli Smith
Status: Feeding on flowers, young pods and flush foliage
Distribution: Dominican Republic (Smith 1960)
Tended by: Solenopsis geminata (Fabricius), Dominican Republic (Smith 1960)

Toxoptera aurantii (Boyer de Fonscolombe)
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on the underside of young leaves, on green shoots and on stalks of pods.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1922), Cameroon (Schouteden 1906), Central African Republic (Boulard 1967),
China (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997), Colombia (Moncayo 1958), Costa Rica (Lara & Shenefelt 1961),
Dominican Republic (Wolcott 1922), Fiji (Lever 1946), Ghana (Cotterell 1927c), Haiti (Wolcott 1933),
Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Malaysia W. Malaysia
(Dammerman 1929), Mexico (Sanchez-Soto & Lagunas 1995), Montserrat (Theobald 1917), Nigeria
(Theobald 1917), Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969), Peru (Wille 1944), Puerto Rico (Wolcott 1924), Sao Tome
& Principe (De Seabra 1919c), Solomon Is (Lever 1968), Sri Lanka (Theobald 1917), Sudan (Schmutterer
1969), Surinam (Van Dinther 1960), Taiwan (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997), Togo (Dufour 1991), Trinidad &
Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1955), Uganda (Gowdey 1913), Vanuatu (Risbec 1937), Western Samoa (Hopkins 1927),
Zaire (Theobald 1917)
Primary parasites: Lysiphlebus testaceipes (Cresson), Brazil (Silva 1944a)
Pseudendaphis ?maculans (Barnes), Ghana (Firempong & Kumar 1975)
Predators: Chrysopa sp. , Ghana (Firempong & Kumar 1975)
Crematogaster clariventris (Mayr), Ghana (Firempong 1976)
Cycloneda sanguinea (Linnaeus), Brazil (Bondar 1922)
Isora anceps Mulsant, Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Novius sp. , Ghana (Cotterell 1927c)
Paragus borboricus Macquart, Ghana (Cotterell 1927c)
Paragus marshalli Bezzi, Ghana (Cotterell 1927c)
Paragus sp. , Ghana (Firempong & Kumar 1975)
Paragus tibialis (Fallen), Ghana (Firempong & Kumar 1975)
Platynaspis ferruginea Weise, Ghana (Firempong & Kumar 1975)
Platynaspis solieri Mulsant, Togo (Dufour 1991)
Pseudocreobotra wahlbergi Stal, Uganda (Gowdey 1913)
Scymnus kibonotensis Weise, Togo (Dufour 1991)
Scymnus scapuliferus Mulsant, Ghana (Firempong & Kumar 1975)
Scymnus sp. , Togo (Dufour 1991)
Sphodromantis lineola (Burmeister), Uganda (Gowdey 1913)
Tended by: Azteca chartifex spiriti Forel, Brazil (Silva 1944a)
Camponotus acvapimensis Mayr, Ghana (Firempong 1975)

HOMOPTERA APHROPHORIDAE
Clovia bigoti (Signoret)
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on young branches and main veins of leaves beneath a covering of white
froth.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b), Ghana (Majer 1975)

Clovia conifer Walker
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Clovia fasciata Lallemand
Synonyms: Clovinia fasciata Lallemand
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Clovia sp.
Synonyms: Clovinia sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Poophilus camerunensis Schmidt
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on young branches and main veins of leaves beneath a covering of green
froth.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b)

Poophilus costalis (Walker)
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on young branches and main veins of leaves beneath a covering of white
froth.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b), Upper Volta (Bonzi 1981)

Poophilus obscuris Walker
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Ptyelus grossus (Fabricius)
Status: A green spittle bug feeding on shoots beneath a frothy white covering.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b), Ghana (Majer 1975)

Ptyelus sp.
Status: Lives within a foamy mass on young shoots
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

HOMOPTERA

142

HOMOPTERA ASTEROLECANIIDAE
Asterolecanium epidendri (Bouche)
Synonyms: Asterolecanium aureum Boisduval
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Dominican Republic (Gómez-Menor 1934), Jamaica (Gowdey 1922)

Asterolecanium neoguineense Williams & Watson
Synonyms: Asterolecanium sp. near javae Russell
Status: Causes slight deformations at the point of feeding
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany &
Dun 1964)

Asterolecanium pustulans (Cockerell)
Status: Occasional on cocoa causing local swellings of stem tips and shedding of leaves.
Distribution: Fiji (Williams & Watson 1990), Grenada (Ballou 1915), Jamaica (Ritchie 1917), Trinidad &
Tobago (Pickles 1941)

Asterolecanium pustulans princeps Castel Branco
Status: Nymphal stages are yellowish in colour, whilst the adult scale is about 1.5 mm long, reddish brown
and pear shaped in outline and covered with hair like filaments concentrated in a fringe around the margins of
the scale. Scales are usually found hiding in crevices of the bark of the stem.
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (Castel-Branco 1964)
Primary parasites: Encarsia citrina (Craw), Sao Tome & Principe (Castel-Branco 1971)
Metaphycus portoricensis (Dozier), Sao Tome & Principe (Castel-Branco 1971)
Predators: Chilocorus cacti (Linnaeus), Sao Tome & Principe (Castel-Branco 1971)

Asterolecanium sp. near pustulans Cockerell
Status: Found occasionally and causing some stem swellings.
Distribution: Nigeria (Entwistle 1962)

HOMOPTERA CERCOPIDAE
Lehina apicalis (Haglund)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b)

Literna intermedia Haglund
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on main veins of upper surface of leaves beneath a covering of white froth.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b)

Literna tartemoriou Lallemand
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Tomaspis sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ecuador (Campos 1933b)

HOMOPTERA CICADELLIDAE
Afroccidens lodosi Ghauri
Status: Feeding on underside of young leaves causing distortion when severe
Distribution: Ghana (Ghauri 1969)

Afroccidens sp.
Status: Feeding on underside of young leaves causing distortion when severe
Distribution: Cameroon (Bruneau De Mire & Lotode 1974)

HOMOPTERA

143

Afroccidens sympatrica Ghauri
Status: Feeding on underside of young leaves causing distortion when severe
Distribution: Ghana (Ghauri 1969)

Agalliota sp.
Synonyms: Agalia sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

Amrasca biguttula Ishida
Synonyms: Empoasca devastans Distant
Status: Periods of drought following heavy rain can lead to large outbreaks on cocoa. Feeding takes place on
the underside of flush leaves leading to premature leaf fall.
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Fernando 1959)

Chinaia rubescens (Fowler)
Status: Feeding takes place on the underside of leaves leading to spotting and yellowing of the leaf and later
leaf fall.
Distribution: Costa Rica (Salas & Hansen 1963)

Citorus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1964a)

Coelidia sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Drabescus sp.

Empoasca ?kraemeri Ross & Moore
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Colombia (Moncayo 1958)

Empoasca sp.
Status: Feeding on leaves

Erythrogonia sp. near areolata (Signoret)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

Gypona sp.
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Costa Rica (Salas & Hansen 1963)

Idioscopus clypealis (Lethierry)
Status: Pale colour and 3.5-4.1 mm long. Feeding on foliage and flowers
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Gnaneswaran et al 2007)

Idioscopus nagpurensis (Pruthi)
Status: Light yellow to brown and 3.6-3.8 mm long. Feeding on foliage and flowers
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Gnaneswaran et al 2007)

Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1964a)

Selenocephalus sp.
Status: No record of status
