Stragania sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

Typhlocyba erythrinae Koningsberger
Status: Well known from Erythrina. On cocoa has been recorded feeding on leaves.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (De Haan 1933)

Typhlocyba sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Wolfella benjamini Boulard
Status: The adult is furnished with a large backward curved horn on the head which has backward pointing
projections. Feeding takes place on leaves and shoots and may lead to a mild necrosis
Distribution: Cameroon (Boulard 1975)

Wolfella cama Kramer
Status: The adult is furnished with a large backward curved horn on the head which has backward pointing
projections. Feeding takes place on leaves and shoots and may lead to a mild necrosis
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b)

144

HOMOPTERA

145

Wolfella caternaultii Spinola
Status: The adult is furnished with a large backward curved horn on the head which has backward pointing
projections. Feeding takes place on leaves and shoots and may lead to a mild necrosis
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b), Ghana (Anon 1964a)

Wolfella krameri Boulard
Status: The adult is furnished with a large backward curved horn on the head which has backward pointing
projections. Feeding takes place on leaves and shoots and may lead to a mild necrosis
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969a)

Xestocephalus ancorifer Linnavuori
Status: Feeding on flowers
Distribution: Brazil (Winder 1978)

HOMOPTERA CICADIDAE
Dundubia rufivena Walker
Status: Adults are relatively short lived and feed exclusively on aerial parts of the tree. The nymphs are white
and feed on the roots, taking several years to develop. Recorded damage appears to have been the result of
dieback due to oviopsition within shoots.
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Foster & Kee 1970)

Huechys sanguinea DeGeer
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Musoda flavida Karsch
Status: Adults feed above ground and have a relatively short life. By contrast the nymphs live for several years
underground feeding on roots.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b)

Panka africana Distant
Status: Adults found on shoots, larvae on roots. Cola is an alternative host
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1970)

Panka lunguncus Boulard
Status: Adults found on shoots, larvae on roots. Cola is an alternative host
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1970)

Panka minimuncus Boulard
Status: Adults found on shoots, larvae on roots
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1970)

Proarna sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ecuador (Campos 1933b)

Ugada grandicollis Germar
Status: Adults feed on the trunks of cocoa trees leading to gum exudation at the site of the puncture.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Ugada stalina Butler
Status: Adults feed above ground and have a relatively short life. By contrast the nymphs live for several years
underground feeding on roots.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b)

Zammara sp.
Status: Adults are relatively short lived and feed exclusively on aerial parts of the tree. The nymphs are white
and feed on the roots, taking several years to develop. Feeding leads to a general debility of the tree and a
severe attack may result in leaf and fruit loss and even death.
Distribution: Ecuador (Campos 1933b)

HOMOPTERA

146

HOMOPTERA CIXIIDAE
Bothriocera sp.
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

Bothriocera sp. near tinealis Burmeister
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

Bothriocera sp. near westwoodi (Stal)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

Myndus sp.
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

HOMOPTERA CLASTOPTERIDAE
Clastoptera globosa Fowler
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on flower cushions beneath a covering of white froth. Is thought to be
correlated with incidence of cushion gall
Distribution: Costa Rica (Shenefelt Stelzer & Lara 1960), Mexico (Valenzuela-Gonzalez Lopez-Mendez &
Garcia-Ballinas 1994)
Predators: Pachycondyla villosa (Fabricius), Mexico (Valenzuela-Gonzalez Lopez-Mendez & Garcia-Ballinas
1994)

Clastoptera laenata Fowler
Status: Adults and nymphs feed beneath a covering of white froth.
Distribution: Mexico (Sanchez-Soto 1995)

Clastoptera ochrospila Jacobi
Status: Adults and nymphs feed beneath a covering of white froth.
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli Silviera & De Barros-Mendes 1989)

Clastoptera sp.
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on shoots close to the insertion of the leaf petioles beneath a covering of white
froth.
Distribution: Brazil (Mendes 1979), Ecuador (Williams 1923)

Clastoptera theobromae Williams
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on flower stalks beneath a covering of white froth leading eventually to loss
of flowers
Distribution: Costa Rica (Williams 1923), Panama (Williams 1923)

Clastoptera xanthocephala var. unicolor Fowler
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on leaves, flowers and cherelles beneath a covering of white froth.
Distribution: Colombia (De Franco 1958)

HOMOPTERA COCCIDAE
Alecanium hirsutum Morrison
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Anthococcus keravatae Williams & Watson
Synonyms: Eriochiton sp.(Szent-Ivany 1961)
Status: No record of status

HOMOPTERA

147

Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Ceroplastes destructor Newstead
Synonyms: Gascardia destructor (Newstead)
Status: Adult females live beneath a white waxy scale. They are broadly oval in outline 6mm x 5mm and
domed but irregular in shape and are found on green shoots. Nymphal stages live on leaves and pass through a
series of shape changes.
Distribution: Uganda (Newstead 1910)

Ceroplastes floridensis Comstock
Status: Found on leaves and shoots
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Ceroplastes lamborni Newstead
Status: Adult females found on shoots living beneath a waxy scale. Not of importance
Distribution: Nigeria (Newstead 1917)

Ceroplastes quadrilineatus Newstead
Status: Adult females found on shoots living beneath a waxy scale. Not of importance
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Couturier Matile-Ferrero & Richard 1985)

Ceroplastes sp.
Status: The scales feed on young branches.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1967), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Ceroplastes theobromae Newstead
Status: Adult females found on shoots living beneath a waxy scale. Not of importance
Distribution: Cameroon (Newstead 1908)

Ceroplastes toddaliae Hall
Status: Adult females found on shoots living beneath a waxy scale. Not of importance
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Couturier Matile-Ferrero & Richard 1985)

Ceroplastodes bahiensis Bondar
Status: Adult females found on shoots living beneath a waxy scale and under carton tents tended by Azteca
chartifex. Not of importance
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1925)
Tended by: Azteca chartifex spiriti Forel, Brazil (Silva 1950)

Ceroplastodes melzeri Bondar
Status: Adult females found on shoots living beneath a waxy scale and under carton tents tended by Azteca
chartifex. Not of importance
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1925)
Tended by: Azteca chartifex spiriti Forel, Brazil (Silva 1950)

Ceroplastodes theobromae Bondar
Status: Adult females found on shoots living beneath a waxy scale and under carton tents tended by Azteca
chartifex. Not of importance
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1925)
Tended by: Azteca chartifex spiriti Forel, Brazil (Silva 1950)

Coccus hesperidum Linnaeus
Status: A flat scale insect found on leaves and shoots.
Distribution: Fiji (Williams & Watson 1990)

Coccus longulus (Douglas)
Status: A flat scale insect found on leaves and shoots.
Distribution: Uganda (Strickland 1947a), Western Samoa (Williams & Watson 1990)

Coccus viridis (Green)
Status: A major pest of coffee, this species is not particularly important on cocoa. Also found on tea, citrus
and mango among other crops.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a), Guyana (Bodkin 1919a), Indonesia Java (Kalshoven 1950-51), Malaysia
Sabah (Conway 1971), Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919c)

HOMOPTERA

148

Tended by: Dolichoderus thoracicus (F.Smith), Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1929)
Myrmicaria arachnoides (F.Smith), Indonesia Java (Kalshoven 1950-51)
Wasmannia auropunctata (Roger), Brazil (Entwistle 1972)

Drepanococcus chiton (Green)
Synonyms: Ceroplastodes chiton Green
Status: Of no importance
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)
Predators: Stathmopoda sp. near trichopeda Lower, Papua New Guinea (Williams & Watson 1990)

Drepanococcus virescens (Green)
Synonyms: Ceroplastodes virescens Green
Status: Of no importance
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Green 1922)

Etiennea cacao Hodgson
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Nigeria (Hodgson 1991)

Etiennea gouligouli Hodgson
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Central african Republic (Hodgson 1991)

Eucalymnatus tessellatus (Signoret)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: New Caledonia (Williams & Watson 1990), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Hemilecanium theobromae Newstead
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Cameroon (Von Faber 1909)

Inglisia sp.
Status: Feeding on shoots and main vein of underside of leaf.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1967), Ghana (Anon 1948)

Inglisia theobromae Newstead
Status: Feeding on pods and flowers
Distribution: Uganda (Newstead 1917)

Lagosinia aristolochiae (Newstead)
Synonyms: Pulvinaria aristolochiae Newstead
Status: Yellow in colour and very uncommon on cocoa
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a)

Lecanium sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1948)

Millericoccus costalimae (Bondar)
Synonyms: Ceroplastodes costalimae Bondar
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1925)
Tended by: Azteca chartifex spiriti Forel, Brazil (Silva 1950)

Parasaissetia nigra (Nietner)
Synonyms: Lecanium nigrum Nietner, Saissetia nigra Nietner
Status: The rounded black scales are found, often thickly clustered, on leaves shoots and branches. They are
commonly attended by ants for their honeydew. At times it can be a serious pest.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1917b)

Philephedra broadwayi (Cockerell)
Synonyms: Philephedra theobromae Green
Status: In Grenada found in large numbers on flower cushions and thought to cause an increase in flower
numbers and low pod set

HOMOPTERA

149

Distribution: Grenada (Ballou 1922), Panama (Fisher 1920), Trinidad & Tobago (Green 1915)

Pseudocribrolecanium andersoni (Newstead)
Synonyms: Cribrolecanium andersoni (Newstead)
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Cameroon (Matile-Ferrero & Nonveiller 1984), Ghana (Bigger 1993)

Pulvinaria cacao Williams & Watson
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Williams & Watson 1990)

Pulvinarisca jacksoni (Newstead)
Synonyms: Macropulvinaria jacksoni (Newstead), Pulvinaria jacksoni Newstead
Status: Commonly found on Acalypha but uncommon on cocoa
Distribution: Cameroon (Von Faber 1909), Ghana (Strickland 1947a), Ghana (Waterston 1917)
Primary parasites: Cheiloneurus afer Waterston, Ghana (Waterston 1917)

Saissetia coffeae (Walker)
Status: The scale is dome shaped, smooth and dark coloured. It is common on coffee and widely distributed.
Distribution: China (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997), Taiwan (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997)

Saissetia hurae Newstead
Status: Feeding on leaves, shoots, flower buds and pods
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Saissetia sp.
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Cameroon (Bruneau De Mire 1969), Central African Republic (Boulard 1967)
Tended by: Wasmannia auropunctata (Roger), Cameroon (Bruneau De Mire 1969)

Udinia catori (Green)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: No locality (Handford 1974)

Udinia farquharsoni (Newstead)
Synonyms: Saissetia subhirsuta (Strickland 1947a) Newstead
Status: Only once recorded on cocoa
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a)

Vitrococcus conchiformis (Newstead)
Synonyms: Inglisia conchiformis Newstead
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Uganda (Gowdey 1917)
Predators: Coccidiphaga scitula (Rambur), Uganda (Gowdey 1917)

Waxiella sp. near zonata (Newstead)
Synonyms: Gascardia sp. near zonatus (Newstead)
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1951)
Tended by: Crematogaster clariventris (Mayr), Ghana (Campbell 1994)

HOMOPTERA DACTYLOPIIDAE
Dactylopius sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1950)

HOMOPTERA DIASPIDIDAE
Abgrallaspis cyanophylli (Signoret)
Synonyms: Aspidiotus cyanophylli Signoret, Furcaspis cyanophylli (Signoret), Hemiberlesia cyanophylli
Signoret
Status: A yellow red scale found on leaves
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a), Ghana (Anon 1948), Western Samoa (Williams & Watson 1990)

Aonidiella gracilis (Balachowsky)
Synonyms: Aspidiotus gracilis Balachowsky
Status: Feeding takes place on the underside of the leaf leading to chlorosis
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

150

HOMOPTERA

151

Aonidiella replicata (Lindinger)
Status: Feeding takes place on the underside of the leaf leading to chlorosis
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1951)

Aspidiotus destructor Signoret
Status: The scale is flat, yellow and circular 1.5-2.0 mm and found on the underside of leaves. It is a serious
pest of coconut and found on a wide range of tropical crops but rarely on coffee
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a), Fiji (Williams & Watson 1988a), Ghana (Anon 1948), Indonesia Java
(Kalshoven 1950-51), Sao Tome & Principe (Castel-Branco 1956), Trinidad & Tobago (Pickles 1945)
Primary parasites: Encarsia citrina (Craw), Sao Tome & Principe (Castel-Branco 1958)
Pterotrix parvipennis (Gahan), Sao Tome & Principe (Castel-Branco 1958)

Aspidiotus elaeidis Marchal
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Ghana (Campbell 1983)

Aspidiotus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1950), Ghana (Anon 1948), Sao Tome & Principe (Passos de Carvalho 1968)

Hemiberlesia palmae (Morgan & Cockerell)
Synonyms: Aspidiotus palmae Morgan & Cockerell, Borchseniaspis palmae (Morgan & Cockerell)
Status: Leaf feeders
Distribution: Fiji (Williams & Watson 1988a), Ghana (Anon 1948), Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971), Papua
New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961), Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra & Vayssiere 1918)

Howardia biclavis (Comstock)
Status: Known as the mining scale because the scale is often partly covered by the bark of the host plant. It has
been recorded from a wide range of crops including cocoa
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Pickles 1941)

Howardia stricklandi Williams
Status: Feeding on foliage
Distribution: Ghana (Williams 1960b)

Ischnaspis longirostris (Signoret)
Status: The long thin scales are found on leaves and is more particularly a pest of coconut and other palms.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Lepidosaphes beckii (Newman)
Synonyms: Mytilococcus beckii (Newman)
Status: An elongated brown scale close to veins on underside of the leaf
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919c)

Lopholeucaspis cockerelli (Grandpre & Charmoy)
Status: Feeding on foliage
Distribution: Vanuatu (Williams & Watson 1988a)

Morganella longispina (Morgan)
Synonyms: Morganella (Aspidiotus) maskelli Cockerell
Status: No record of status.
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919c)

Neoselenaspidus silvaticus (Lindinger)
Synonyms: Selenaspidus silvaticus Lindinger
Status: Colonies are found on the underside of the leaf often in association with colonies of Aonidiella
gracilis.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Paraselenaspidus madagascariensis (Mamet)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: No locality (Borchsenius 1966)

HOMOPTERA

152

Parlatoria camelliae Comstock
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Parlatoria proteus (Curtis)
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Fiji (Williams & Watson 1988a)

Pseudaonidia sp.
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1948)

Pseudaonidia trilobitiformis (Green)
Synonyms: Aspidiotus trilobitiformis Green
Status: The scales are found on both surfaces of the leaf tightly clustered around the principal veins. Males
are predominantly found on the upper surface and females on the lower. There are many alternative hosts
including coffee, citrus, cashew, mango and guava.
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1950), Dominican Republic (Schmutterer 1990), Madagascar (Newstead 1910),
Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1917a), Sudan (Schmutterer 1969), Vanuatu (Williams & Watson 1988a),
Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Pseudaulacaspis pentagona (Targioni Tozzetti)
Synonyms: Aulacaspis pentagona Targioni Tozzetti
Status: Commonly found on rubber and on parasitic mistletoes growing on cocoa trunks.
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919c)

Pseudoparlatoria parlatorioides (Comstock)
Synonyms: Pseudoparlatoria pusilla Green
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Green 1922)

Pseudoparlatoria suelda Wolff
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Colombia (Wolff 2001)

Selenaspidus articulatus (Morgan)
Synonyms: Aspidiotus articulatus Morgan
Status: A red scale insect found on the upper surface of the leaves. Also on coffee citrus and tea among other
hosts.
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra & Vayssiere 1918), Trinidad & Tobago (Pickles 1945)

Selenaspidus kamerunicus Lindinger
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: No locality (Borchsenius 1966)

Semelaspidus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Semelaspidus theobromae Williams
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Williams 1957)

Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Carthaeomorpha sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

Chaetormenis sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1964a)

Colgar chlorospilum (Walker)
Status: Light green in colour and about 10 mm long. Feeding on a wide range of plants including coffee
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

Colgar elatum Medler
Synonyms: Colgar sp. (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964) , Colgar tricolor (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964) Distant
Status: Dark green and 12-13 mm long. Feeding on a wide range of plants including coffee
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Medler 1989), Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989), Papua New Guinea
(Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Colgar ligorum Medler
Status: Green and 11-12 mm long. Also recorded from coffee and tea
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

Colgar missior Medler
Status: Green and 10-11 mm long. Also recorded from coffee.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

Colgar surrectum (Melichar)
Status: Bright green, dull green or yellow green and 13-14 mm long. Also recorded from coffee.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

Colobesthes falcata (Guerin Meneville)
Status: Feeding on foliage
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Wood & Chung 1992)

Cryptoflata unipunctata (Olivier)
Status: A shoot and fruit feeder
Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1964a)

Epormenis roscida (Germar)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

Epormenis unimaculata (Fennah)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Euphanta pokiana Distant
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Euphanta sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Lawana candida (Fabricius)
Status: The insect feeds by sucking the sap from leaf petioles and green shoots. It has many alternative hosts
including coffee and tea.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1929)
Primary parasites: Neodryinus javanus (Roepke), Indonesia Java (Roepke 1916a)

Lawana conspersa Walker
Status: The insect feeds by sucking the sap from leaf petioles and green shoots.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Lawana optata Melichar
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Necromna bistriguttata (Stal)
Status: Variable in colour including light pink, light green, tawny and dark green and 13-15.5 mm long. Also
recorded from coffee.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

Neocromna sp.
Status: Hoppers feed on shoots and leaf veins and cause little damage. Eggs are laid in the midrib of older
leves and may cause some damage
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Neodaksha furtiva (Melichar)
Synonyms: Paradaksha sp. (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)
Status: Pale green, pale ochraceous or white and 18-20 mm long. Also recorded from coffee
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

Ormenis albigyna Campos
Status: Very common especially during the rainy season
Distribution: Ecuador (Campos 1933b)

Papuanella affinis Medler
Synonyms: Papuanella sp. (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)
Status: Orange vertex, front green fading to orange at the sides. 9.5-10 mm long
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Papuanella bistigma Medler
Status: Red orange vertex, pronotum faded orange, mesonotum tawny . 9.5-10 mm long.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

Papuanella cyanea (Melichar)
Status: Colour blue green and 10-11 mm long.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

HOMOPTERA

155

Papuanella destituta Medler
Status: Orange vertex, blue green front, pronotum blue green. 9.5-10 mm long. Also recorded from coffee.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

Papuanella jacata Medler
Status: Head and thorax green, 9.5-10 mm long
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

Papuanella rufilis Medler
Status: Colour brownish orange and 9.5-10.5 mm long.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

Phromnia sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Phyllophanta sp.
Status: No record of status

Sephena conforma Medler
Status: Tawny in colour, 7.5-8 mm long.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

Sephena conspersa Melichar
Synonyms: Sephena punctulosa Distant
Status: Colour green, ochraceous or ivory white and 8-9 mm long. Feeding on shoots and leaf veins.
Distribution: Solomon Is (Lever 1968)

Sephena infumata Medler
Status: Dark brown and 7-8 mm long. Also on coffee and citrus
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

Sephena nivosa (Walker)
Synonyms: Paratella nivosa (Walker)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Sephena sp.
Status: Hoppers feed on shoots and leaf veins and cause little damage. Eggs are laid in the midrib of older
leves and may cause some damage
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany &
Dun 1964)

Sephena spargula (Walker)
Status: Hoppers feed on shoots and leaf veins and cause little damage. Eggs are laid in the midrib of older
leves and may cause some damage
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Siphanta sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Talopsus albastum Medler
Status: Colour fuscous and 5.5-6 mm long. Also on coffee
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Medler 1989)

Taparella amata (Walker)
Synonyms: Paratella discoidalis Melichar, Paratella miniata Melchior
Status: Hoppers are 15-17 mm long and feed on shoots and leaf veins and cause little damage. Eggs are laid in
the midrib of older leaves and may cause some damage
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Medler 1989), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Anecphora olivacea Schm.
Status: Uncommon on cocoa
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Elasmoscelis trimaculata Walker
Status: Recorded from newly planted cocoa
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Holodictya sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1964a)

Laternaria candelaria (Linnaeus)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: China (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997)

Neolieftinckana fuscata Spin.
Status: Adults collected on foliage but not apparently causing damage
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1971)

Novodictya punctata Lallemand
Status: General colour is blackish with chestnut spots but there are five yellow spots on the thorax. Length is
22 to 25 mm. Found principally on forest trees but sometimes feeds on young cocoa shoots.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Phrictus diadema (Linneus)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (O’Brien 1988)

Phrictus quinquepartitus Distant
Status: Feeds on trunks piercing the bark
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Phrictus sp.
Status: Feeds on trunks piercing the bark
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1945b)

Painella simmondsi Muir
Status: Associated with lethal yellowing of coconut but unimportant on cocoa

Crypticerya caudatus (Newstead)
Synonyms: Steatococcus caudatus Newstead
Status: Feeding on branches and shoots

157

HOMOPTERA

158

Drosicha mangiferae (Green)
Status: A large insect up to 16 mm long it is commonly found on mango but is not important on cocoa
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Icerya nigroareolata Newstead
Status: Colonies are found principally on the underside of the leaf but where infestation is severe shoots or
branches may be colonised. Infestation is more severe during the dry season. Also recorded from coffee.
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a)

Icerya pulchra (Leonardi)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Icerya purchasi Maskell
Status: The adult female is brown covered by a white layer of wax and bears a large white fluted egg sac
posteriorly. Common on cotton and citrus
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (Castel-Branco 1962)

Icerya sp.
Status: Found on leaves and shoots
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Icerya tremae Vayssiere
Status: The body of the adult is crimson with a covering of yellow wax dorsally and white ventrally. Has a
moderately wide range of hosts but is not important
Distribution: Zaire (Liegeois 1944)

Misracoccus convexus (Morrison)
Synonyms: Lophococcus convexus Morrison
Status: A large grey cushion shaped species 11 mm long which feeds on shoots of a range of trees. Has been
recorded as a serious pest of cocoa at one time.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (De Jong 1931)

Steatococcus samaraius Morrison
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Solomon Is (Williams & Watson 1990)

Steatococcus sp.
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a)

Steatococcus theobromae (Newstead)
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Cameroon (Von Faber 1909), Ghana (Strickland 1947a), Nigeria (Newstead 1908)

HOMOPTERA MEENOPLIDAE
Agathodes caliginosalis Snellen
Status: Caterpillars are leaf feeders
Distribution: Indonesia Sulawesi (Hoehn et al 2009)
Predators: Rhynchium haemorrhoidale (Fabricius), Indonesia Sulawesi (Hoehn et al 2009)

Meenoplus sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

HOMOPTERA

159

HOMOPTERA MEMBRACIDAE
Acanophora sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ecuador (Campos 1933b)

Amastris elevata Funkhouser
Status: No record of status but probably feeding on pods
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

Amastris obtegens (Fabricius)
Status: Feeding on young pods and causing cherelle wilt
Distribution: Costa Rica (Anon 1959)

Anchon decoratum Distant
Status: Adult 7 mm, black with white bands on the thorax and very well developed spreading processes, two
vertical and two protruding backward over the abdomen
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b)

Anchon dilaticornis Pelaez
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1964a)

Anchon erici Boulard
Status: Adult 6-7 mm long with prominent horns on the thorax pointing both upwards and backwards over the
abdomen. Red brown with yellow eyes.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969a)

Anchon flavipes Signoret
Status: Adult 6 mm long and brown, with processes similar to A. decoratum.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b)

Anchon vicinum Signoret
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Bocchar sp. near montanum Jacobi
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1964a)

Bolbonota insignis Fowler
Status: No record of status.
Distribution: Costa Rica (Salas & Hansen 1963)

Bolbonota nisus Germar
Status: No record of status.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1922)

Bolbonota pictipennis Fairmaire
Status: Cause wounds by inserting eggs into bark
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1924b), Colombia (Moncayo 1958)
Tended by: Azteca chartifex Forel, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Crematogaster evallans Forel, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Dolichoderus attelaboides (Fabricius), Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Dolichoderus bidens (Linnaeus), Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Dolichoderus bispinosus (Olivier), Brazil (Bondar 1924b)

Cymbomorpha sp.
Status: A nymph found on flowers was seen to effect pollination
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Billes 1941)

HOMOPTERA

160

Cyphonia clavata (Fabricius)
Status: Of no importance
Distribution: Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

Dingkana sp.
Status: Often seen on shoots but does not appear to cause much damage
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Ebhul varium (Walker)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Azhar 1992)
Tended by: Dolichoderus thoracicus (F.Smith), Malaysia (Azhar 1992)

Enchenopa auridorsa Sakakibara& Marques
Status: No record of status, collected at light
Distribution: Brazil (Sakakibara & Marques 2007)

Enchenopa fusca Sakakibara& Marques
Status: No record of status, collected at light
Distribution: Brazil (Sakakibara & Marques 2007)

Eumonocentrus erectus Schmidt
Status: Reasonably common during rainy periods living in colonies near the tips of branches.
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b)

Eumonocentrus sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Gargara chinchonettae Boulard
Status: Feeding on young stems, shoots and main veins of leaves
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1968)

Gargara lullae Boulard
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1968)

Gargara perpolita Distant
Status: Feeding on young stems, shoots and main veins of leaves
Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1964a)

Gargara sp.
Status: Feeding on young stems, shoots and main veins of leaves
Distribution: Ghana (Cotterell 1927c)

Gargara variegata Signoret
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Harmonides dispar (Fabricius)
Status: Feeding on pods and branches
Distribution: Colombia (Urueta Sandino 1975b)

Horiola picta Fabricius
Synonyms: Horiola arcuata Fabricius, Horiola lineolata Fairmaire, Tragopa picta Fabricius
Status: Cause wounds by inserting eggs into stalks of flowers and young pods. The female is triangular in
shape and blackish, with a conspicuous X shaped pale brown mark narrowly edged in white.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1924b), Colombia (Moncayo 1958), Costa Rica (Salas & Hansen 1963), Guyana
(Bodkin 1914), Trinidad & Tobago (Guppy 1911b)
Primary parasites: Trichogrammatella tristis Girault, Trinidad & Tobago (Guppy 1911b)
Tumidifemur pulchrum Girault, Trinidad & Tobago (Guppy 1911b)
Uscanella bicolor Girault, Trinidad & Tobago (Guppy 1911b)
Tended by: Azteca chartifex Forel, Brazil (Bondar 1924b), Trinidad & Tobago (Urich 1911)

HOMOPTERA

161

Crematogaster evallans Forel, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Dolichoderus attelaboides (Fabricius), Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Dolichoderus bidens (Linnaeus), Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Dolichoderus bispinosus (Olivier), Brazil (Bondar 1924b)

Horiola sp.
Status: No record of status.
Distribution: Colombia (De Franco 1958), Trinidad & Tobago (Guppy 1911b)

Imporcitor sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Leptocentrus albolineatus Funkhouser
Status: No record of status
Distribution: China (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997)

Leptocentrus altifrons (Walker)
Status: Pronotum has a pair of sharp laterally pointing horns and a long thin posterior horn pointing back over
the abdomen
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b), Ghana (Anon 1964a)

Leptocentrus bos Signoret
Status: Pronotum has a pair of sharp laterally pointing horns and a long thin posterior horn pointing back over
the abdomen
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b)

Leptocentrus lobayensis Boulard
Status: Pronotum has a pair of sharp laterally pointing horns and a long thin posterior horn pointing back over
the abdomen
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969a)

Leptocentrus macarangae Boulard
Status: Pronotum has a pair of sharp laterally pointing horns and a long thin posterior horn pointing back over
the abdomen
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b)

Leptocentrus paganus Capener
Status: Pronotum has a pair of sharp laterally pointing horns and a long thin posterior horn pointing back over
the abdomen
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b)

Leptocentrus reponens Walker
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Leptocentrus rufotibialis Capener
Status: Pronotum has a pair of sharp laterally pointing horns and a long thin posterior horn pointing back over
the abdomen
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1969b)

Leptocentrus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Membracis foliata (Linnaeus)
Status: Eggs are laid beneath the bark particulary in nurseries and young plantations
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Membracis tectigera (Stal)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bicelli et al 1987)

HOMOPTERA

Metcalfiella pertusa (Germar)
Synonyms: Hoplophorion pertusum Germar
Status: Feeds on young branches but is not of importance
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a), Peru (Escalante 1974)
Primary parasites: Prionomastix ?fasciatipennis (Girault), Brazil (Anon 1983)
Predators: Ocyptamus ?flatus (Hull), Brazil (Anon 1983)

Micrutalis nitida Sakakibara& Marques
Status: No record of status, collected at light
Distribution: Brazil (Sakakibara & Marques 2007)

Mitranotus costei Boulard
Status: About 5-6mm long with a raised hump on each side of the pronotum. Not common on cocoa
Distribution: Cameroon (Boulard 1983)

Monocentrus insularis Schm.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1964a)

Nassunia armata Sakakibara& Marques
Status: No record of status, collected at light
Distribution: Brazil (Sakakibara & Marques 2007)

Nassunia inermis Sakakibara& Marques
Status: No record of status, collected at light
Distribution: Brazil (Sakakibara & Marques 2007)

Oxyrhachis pandata Distant
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1964a)

Platybelus flagellifer Signoret
Synonyms: Centrotus flagellifer Signoret
Status: Found on branches
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Publilia sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Peru (Escalante 1974)

Terentius sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Tolania acuticornis Sakakibara& Marques
Status: No record of status, collected at light
Distribution: Brazil (Sakakibara & Marques 2007)

Tragopa aenea (Perty)
Status: Cause wounds by inserting eggs into stalks of flowers and young pods
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Tragopa fulvovaria Fairmaire
Status: Cause wounds by inserting eggs into stalks of flowers and young pods

Status: Cause wounds by inserting eggs into stalks of flowers and young pods

Tricentrus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Tropidolomia auriculata (Olivier)
Synonyms: Tragopa auriculata Olivier
Status: Cause wounds by inserting eggs into stalks of flowers and young pods

Umbonia sp.
Status: Feeding on the midrib of leaves in heavily shaded farms
Distribution: Ecuador (Evans & Samson 1977)

Uroxiphus maculiscutum Amyot & Serville
Synonyms: Centrotus maculiscutum Amyot & Serville
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Gaetulia sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

HOMOPTERA ORTHEZIIDAE
Insignorthezia insignis (Browne)
Synonyms: Orthezia insignis Browne
Status: Polyphagous and probably not breeding on cocoa.
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919c)

163

HOMOPTERA

164

Mixorthezia fodiens (Giard)
Status: Originally ecorded from the roots of coffee
Distribution: Guadeloupe (Morrison 1952)

Mixorthezia reynei (Laing)
Synonyms: Ortheziopa reynei Laing, Ortheziopa sp. (Trinidad & Tobago)
Status: Living in colonies on the roots.
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Strickland 1947a)
Tended by: Acropyga sp. , Trinidad & Tobago (Strickland 1945)

Newsteadia wacri Strickland
Status: The female is oval and 2.2 mm long and with relatively long legs. It has been recorded low down on
the bole of a tree and from a root just below the ground. Not important
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a)

Praelongorthezia praelonga (Douglas)
Synonyms: Orthezia praelonga Douglas
Status: Common under Gliricidia shade
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)

HOMOPTERA PSEUDOCOCCIDAE
Benedictycoccina ornata (Hambleton)
Synonyms: Rhizoecus ornatus (Hambleton), Ripersiella ornata Hambleton
Status: Colonies develop on the roots of cocoa where the mealybugs feed within a sheath formed by the
mycelium of fungi of the genus.
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Strickland 1945)

Coccidella globocula (Hambleton)
Synonyms: Morrisonella globocula Hambleton, Rhizoecus globoculus (Hambleton)
Status: Colonies develop on the roots of cocoa where the mealybugs feed within a sheath formed by the
mycelium of fungi of the genus.
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Hambleton 1946)

Coccidella theobromae (Hambleton)
Synonyms: Morrisonella theobromae Hambleton, Rhizoecus theobromae (Hambleton)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ecuador (Hambleton 1946)

Criniticoccus ficus Williams
Status: Feeding in colonies on pods
Distribution: Solomon Is (Lever 1968)

Criniticoccus tectus Williams
Status: Feeding in colonies on pods
Distribution: Solomon Is (Lever 1968)
Tended by: Philidris myrmecodiae (Emery), Solomon Islands (Williams 1960a)

Criniticoccus theobromae Williams
Status: Feeding in colonies on pods
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961), Solomon Is (Lever 1968)
Tended by: Technomyrmex albipes (F.Smith), Solomon Islands (Williams 1960a)

Crisicoccus longipillosus De Lotto
Synonyms: Trionymus longipillosus De Lotto
Status: No record of status
Distribution: ?Tanzania (De Lotto 1967)

Crisicoccus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

HOMOPTERA

165

Crisicoccus theobromae Williams & Watson
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Williams 2004), Papua New Guinea (Williams & Watson 1988b)

Delococcus tafoensis (Strickland)
Synonyms: Formicococcus tafoensis Strickland
Status: Female is practically circular in shape with 12 pairs of wax plates laterally and one pair of fused plates
anteriorly. It feeds in cracks of the bark and is uncommon on cocoa.
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a), Togo (Nguyen-Ban 1984)

Delottococcus sp. near proteae (Hall)
Synonyms: Pseudococcus sp. near proteae Hall
Status: Can transmit several isolates of Cocoa Swollen Shoot virus
Distribution: Ghana (Donald 1956), Nigeria (Donald 1955b)
Primary parasites: Anagyrus beneficiens Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Leptomastix dactylopii Howard, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Hyperparasites: Cheiloneurus carinatus Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)

Dysmicoccus brevipes (Cockerell)
Synonyms: Pseudococcus bromeliae (Bouche)
Status: The adult female is broadly oval with a thin covering of white wax and 17 pairs of short lateral wax
filaments. It is an important pest of pineapple but not of great importance on cocoa usually being found on pod
stalks or young shoots except that it is a virus vector.
Distribution: American Samoa (Williams & Watson 1988b), Colombia (Williams & Granara de Willink
1992), Costa Rica (Weber 1957), Cuba (Blanco Perez & Rodriguez 2003), Ghana (Donald 1956), Grenada
(Ballou 1922), Guyana (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Honduras (Williams & Granara de Willink
1992), Nigeria (Donald 1955b), Panama (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Tanzania Zanzibar (De Lotto
1964), Togo (Dufour 1991), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b), Vanuatu (Williams & Watson 1988b),
Western Samoa (Williams & Watson 1988b)
Primary parasites: Aenasius longiscapus Compere, Trinidad & Tobago (Kerrich 1967)
Aenasius tachigaliae (Brues), Trinidad & Tobago (Kerrich 1953)
Tropidophryne africana Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Predators: Hyperaspis jucunda (Mulsant), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)
Ocyptamus stenogaster (Williston), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)
Pseudiastata vorax Sabrosky, Trinidad & Tobago (Sabrosky 1951)
Tended by: Crematogaster sp. , Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008)
Pheidole sp. , Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008)
Solenopsis geminata (Fabricius), Costa Rica (Weber 1957)
Solenopsis picea Emery, Costa Rica (Weber 1957)
Solenopsis sp. , Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008)
Wasmannia auropunctata (Roger), Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008)

Dysmicoccus debregeasiae (Green)
Status: Feeding on roots
Distribution: Malaysia (Williams 2004)

Dysmicoccus grassii (Leonardi)
Synonyms: Dysmicoccus alazon Williams
Status: Colonies are found below ground in the collar region and on the roots associated with a fungus
(Septobasiduim sp.) which forms a rubbery sheath around the root and under which the insects live, tended by
ants.
Distribution: Belize (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008),
Malaysia Sabah (Williams 2004), Mexico (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Trinidad & Tobago
(Williams & Granara de Willink 1992)

Dysmicoccus lepelleyi (Betrem)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia (Williams 2004)

HOMOPTERA

166

Dysmicoccus neobrevipes Beardsley
Status: Colonies develop below ground and the mealy bugs feed on roots
Distribution: American Samoa (Williams & Watson 1988b), Hawaii (Chang 1985), Malaysia (Williams
2004), Philippines (Williams 2004), Surinam (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992)
Tended by: Pheidole megacephala (Fabricius), Hawaii (Chang 1985)

Dysmicoccus nesophilus Williams & Watson
Status: Colonies develop below ground and the mealy bugs feed on roots
Distribution: Fiji (Williams & Watson 1988b)

Dysmicoccus sp.
Status: Colonies develop below ground and the mealy bugs feed on roots
Distribution: Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008), Cuba (Martinez Blanco & Perez 2001), Fiji
(Hinckley 1965), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)
Tended by: Solenopsis geminata (Fabricius), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)

Dysmicoccus sp. near brevipes (Cockerell)
Status: The species in Trinidad forms large colonies on unripe pods and is a vector of virus.
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)
Primary parasites: Blepyrus schwarzi (Howard), Trinidad & Tobago (Kerrich 1967)
Tended by: Solenopsis geminata (Fabricius), Costa Rica (Weber 1957)
Solenopsis picea Emery, Costa Rica (Weber 1957)
Wasmannia auropunctata (Roger), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)

Dysmicoccus texensis (Tinsley)
Synonyms: Dysmicoccus bispinosus Beardsley
Status: Colonies develop on the roots where the mealybugs feed within a sheath formed by the mycelium of
fungi of the genus Septobasidium and attended by various species of Acropyga ants for their honeydew. A
heavy infestation can seriously weaken the tree.
Distribution: Colombia (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Cuba (Blanco Perez & Rodriguez 2003),
Trinidad & Tobago (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Virgin Is (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992)
Tended by: Crematogaster sp. , Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008)

Exallomochlus camur Williams
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Williams 2004)

Exallomochlus hispidus (Morrison)
Synonyms: Cataenococcus hispidus (Morrison), Pseudococcus hispidus Morrison
Status: Common on cocoa mostly on pod stalks, but not important
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Williams 2004), Indonesia Sumatra (Williams 2004), Malaysia Sabah (Conway
1971), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Azhar 1992)
Tended by: Anoplolepis gracilipes (F.Smith), Malaysia W.Malaysia (Azhar 1983)
Crematogaster sp. , Malaysia W.Malaysia (Azhar 1983)
Dolichoderus thoracicus (F.Smith), Malaysia (Azhar 1992)

Exallomochlus sulawesicus Williams
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Indonesia Sulawesi (Williams 2004)

Ferrisia virgata (Cockerell)
Status: The adult female is elongated oval in shape but wider towards the front and tapering somewhat at the
rear., 3-4 mm long and 2-2.5 mm wide. The body is covered with white wax but there are two wax free spots
on the thorax exposing the yellowish integument and three pairs of spots on the abdomen. Glassy white hairs
sprout from the back and there are two long terminal wax filaments but no lateral filaments. Eggs are laid in an
ovisac partly concealed beneath the body of the female. Individuals are usually isolated ane rerely attended by
ants. It is the vector of a few strains of Cocoa Swollen Shoot Virus but not of much importance as such.
Distribution: Bolivia (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Central African Republic (Boulard 1967), China
(Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997), Colombia (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Costa Rica (Weber 1957),
Ecuador (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Ghana (Strickland 1947a), India (Williams 2004), Indonesia
Java (Van der Knaap 1952), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Jamaica (Gowdey 1921b), Malaysia Sabah (Conway
1971), Malaysia Sarawak (Williams 2004), Mexico (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Nigeria (Donald

HOMOPTERA

167

1955b), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964), Sao Tome & Principe (Passos de Carvalho 1968),
Sierra Leone (Attafuah Blencowe & Brunt 1963), Sri Lanka (Carter 1956), Sudan (Schmutterer 1969), Taiwan
(Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997), Togo (Dufour 1988), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b), Zaire (Liegeois
1944)
Primary parasites: Acerophagus sp. , Trinidad & Tobago (Entwistle 1972)
Aenasius advena Compere, Trinidad & Tobago (Kerrich 1967)
Aenasius caeruleus Brues, Trinidad & Tobago (Kerrich 1967)
Aenasius frontalis Compere, Trinidad & Tobago (Kerrich 1967)
Aenasius martinii (Compere), Ghana (Donald 1956), Nigeria (Gregory 1954)
Aenasius regularis Kerrich, Trinidad & Tobago (Kerrich 1967)
Aenasius sp. , Trinidad & Tobago (Entwistle 1972)
Allothrombium sp. , Ghana (Donald 1956)
Anagyrus sp. near aurantifrons Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Anagyrus subproximus (Silvestri), Ivory Coast (Risbec 1949)
Anagyrus trinidadensis (Kerrich), Trinidad & Tobago (Kerrich 1953)
Blepyrus insularis (Cameron), Nigeria (Kerrich 1967), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Bothriocraera bicolor Compere & Zinna, Trinidad & Tobago (Compere & Zinna 1955)
Coccidoencyrtus sp. , Trinidad & Tobago (Entwistle 1972)
Gyranusoidea dispar (Kerrich), Trinidad & Tobago (Kerrich 1953)
Holcencyrtus myrmicoides (Compere & Zinna), Trinidad & Tobago (Compere & Zinna 1955)
Holcencyrtus sp. , Trinidad & Tobago (Entwistle 1972)
Leptomastidea ?jeanneli Mercet, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Leptomastix dactylopii Howard, Ghana (Donald 1956), Ivory Coast (Risbec 1949), Nigeria (Gregory 1954)
Pseudaphycus ferrisianae Bennett, Trinidad & Tobago (Bennett 1955)
Pseudaphycus sp. , Trinidad & Tobago (Entwistle 1972)
Thysanus sp. , Ghana (Donald 1956)
Hyperparasites: Chartocerus ?elongatus (Girault), Ivory Coast (Risbec 1949)
Cheiloneurus carinatus Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Prochiloneurus aegyptiacus (Mercet), Ghana (Donald 1956), Ivory Coast (Risbec 1949)
Predators: Chrysopa sp. , Ghana (Donald 1956), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Coccodiplosis coffeae (Barnes), Ghana (Donald 1956)
Exochomus flavipes Thunberg, Ghana (Anon 1953c)
Exochomus melanocephalus (Zoubkoff), Sri Lanka (Carter 1956)
Exochomus sp. near flavipes Thunberg, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Nephus ornatulus Korschefsky, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Spalgis epeus (Westwood), Sri Lanka (Carter 1956)
Spalgis lemolea Druce, Ghana (Donald 1956), Nigeria (Donald 1955b)
Triommata coccotroctes Barnes, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Tended by: Ectatomma ruidum (Roger), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)
Lophomyrmex bedoti Emery, Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Formicococcus celtis (Strickland)
Synonyms: Planococcoides celtis (Strickland), Planococcus celtis (Strickland), Pseudococcus celtis
(Strickland)
Status: Female is yellowish with a covering of white powdery wax and 17-18 lateral filaments. It has not been
shown to transmit Cooa Swollen Shoot virus.
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947b), Sierra Leone (Attafuah Blencowe & Brunt 1963)
Primary parasites: Aenasius martinii (Compere), Ghana (Donald 1956)

Formicococcus njalensis (Laing)
Synonyms: Formicococcus lamabokensis (Balachowsky & Ferrero), Planococcoides lamabokensis
(Balachowsky & Ferrero), Planococcoides njalensis (Laing), Planococcus lamabokensis Balachowsky &
Ferrero, Pseudococcus exibitialis Laing
Status: The adult female is oval, about 2.4 mm long by 1.8 mm across. The body colour is pinkish. It is
covered with a dense covering of powdery white wax but the underlying integument shows through as
transverse patches dorsally. Fifteen wax filaments radiate from the sides of the body and a pair of slightly
longer filaments protrude backward. The insects live together in tightly packed colonies particularly on pods
and are almost invariably tended by ants which build covers over the colonies. Females give birth to offspring
viviparously. The insect was described originally from coffee in Sierra Leone but is of little importance on
coffee. However it is an important vector in West Africa of several strains of the Swollen Shoot virus of cocoa.

HOMOPTERA

168

Distribution: Cameroon (Entwistle 1972), Central African Republic (Boulard 1967), Dahomey (Box 1944),
Ghana (Strickland 1947a), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Liberia (Entwistle 1972), Nigeria (Sutherland 1953),
Sao Tome & Principe (Passos de Carvalho 1968), Sierra Leone (Hargreaves, E. 1937), Togo (Hall 1945), Togo
(Nguyen-Ban 1984), Zaire (De Lotto 1964)
Primary parasites: ?Trichomasthus sp. , Ghana (Donald 1956)

169

Geococcus coffeae Green
Status: The adult female is oval, about 2-2.5 mm long with a thin covering of white wax and is found feeding
on roots within small cells. It is quite important on coffee but less so on cocoa.
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a), Nigeria (Donald 1955a)

Heliococcus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Nigeria (Donald 1955b)

Hopefoldia catherineae Foldi
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992)

Hordeolicoccus nephelii (Takahashi)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia (Williams 2004)

Laingiococcus painei (Laing)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Solomon Is (Williams & Watson 1988b)

Laminicoccus vitiensis (Green & Laing)
Synonyms: Laminicoccus cocois Williams
Status: Normally found on palms, the record is doubtful.
Distribution: Solomon Is (Lever 1968)

Leptococcus neotropicus Williams & Granara de Willink
Synonyms: Plotococcus neotropicus (Williams & Granara de Willink)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Colombia (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Cuba (Blanco Perez & Rodriguez 2003)

Maconellicoccus hirsutus (Green)
Synonyms: Spilococcus perforatus De Lotto
Status: This species is an important pest of many woody plants forming dense colonies on the bark which
debilitates and may kill the tree. It is not particularly important on cocoa.
Distribution: Grenada (Cock 2002), Indonesia Java (Kalshoven 1950-51), Malaysia (Williams 2004), Papua
New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964), Sri Lanka (Williams 2004), Tanzania (De Lotto 1964), Tanzania
Zanzibar (De Lotto 1964)
Primary parasites: Anagyrus kamali Moursi, Grenada (Cock 2002)

Maconellicoccus multipori (Takahashi)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia (Williams 2004)

Maconellicoccus ugandae (Laing)
Synonyms: Pseudococcus ugandae Laing
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Ghana (Campbell 1983), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Primary parasites: Anagyrus ?subproximus (Silvestri), Ghana (Donald 1956)
Anagyrus abyssinicus Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Anagyrus kivuensis Compere, Togo (Dufour 1991)
Anagyrus sp. , Togo (Dufour 1991)
Anagyrus sp. near abyssinicus Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Predators: Hyperaspis quadrilla Mulsant, Togo (Dufour 1991)

Maculicoccus malaitensis (Cockerell)
Status: Feeding on shoots and pods
Distribution: Solomon Is (Lever 1968)
Tended by: Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius), Solomon Is. (Williams 1960a)

Mutabilicoccus sp.
Status: Feeding on pods
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

HOMOPTERA

170

Tended by: Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Mutabilicoccus vanheurni (Reyne)
Status: Found feeding on pods but not a serious pest
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Williams & Watson 1988b)

Neochavesia trinidadensis (Beardsley)
Status: Forming colonies on roots
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Beardsley 1970)

Nipaecoccus guazumae (Balachowsky)
Status: Common in Colombia feeding on leaves and shoots
Distribution: Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008), Venezuela (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992)

Nipaecoccus jonmartini Williams & Granara de Willink
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Colombia (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992)

Nipaecoccus kuduyaricus Williams & Granara de Willink
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Colombia (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992)

Nipaecoccus neogaeus Williams & Granara de Willink
Status: Feeding on flower shoots and pods
Distribution: Brazil (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Colombia (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992)
Tended by: Wasmannia auropunctata (Roger), Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008)

Nipaecoccus nipae (Maskell)
Status: Shoot feeders
Distribution: Colombia (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Costa Rica (Williams & Granara de Willink
1992), Dominican Republic (Schmutterer 1990), Ecuador (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Grenada
(Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Nicaragua (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), St Lucia (Williams
& Granara de Willink 1992), Trinidad & Tobago (Bennett 1955)
Primary parasites: Pseudaphycus utilis Timberlake, Trinidad & Tobago (Bennett 1955)
Tended by: Paratrechina sp. , Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008)

Nipaecoccus pitkini Williams & Granara de Willink
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992)

Nipaecoccus viridis (Newstead)
Synonyms: Nipaecoccus vastator Maskell, Pseudococcus perniciosus Newstead
Status: Forms colonies on leaf petioles and twigs covered by waxy secretions. Very variable in the amount of
damage it can cause, in some areas it can be a serious pest, in others it is minor
Distribution: China (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997), Kenya (Anderson 1924), Taiwan (Li Wang &
Waterhouse 1997)

Paraputo anomalus (Newstead)
Synonyms: Paraputo multispinosa James, Paraputo ritchei Laing
Status: Feeds in cracks of bark and is not common on cocoa
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a)
Primary parasites: Pseudaphycus ?prosopodis Timberlake, Ghana (Donald 1956)

Paraputo loranthi (Strickland)
Synonyms: Farinococcus loranthi (Strickland), Paraputo loranthi (Strickland)
Status: It is associated with epiphytic Loranthus mistletoe growing on cocoa and has once been recorded in a
colony on cocoa pods.
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a)

Paraputo taylori Williams & Granara de Willink
Synonyms: Cataenococcus taylori Williams & Granara de Willink
Status: Collected off wild cocoa Theobroma subincanum
Distribution: Colombia (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992)

HOMOPTERA

171

Paraputo theobromicola Williams & Granara de Willink
Synonyms: Cataenococcus theobromicola Williams & Granara de Willink
Status: Collected off wild cocoa Theobroma subincanum
Distribution: Colombia (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992)

Phenacoccus hargreavesi (Laing)
Synonyms: Pseudococcus bukobensis Laing, Pseudococcus hargreavesi Laing
Status: Female is pink in colour covered with powdery white wax and with 17-18 pairs of lateral wax
filaments. Feeding mainly on leaves and shoots, it is common but occuring either singly or in small groups so
is easily overlooked. It is the vector of several strains of swollen shoot virus
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Donald 1955a), Sierra Leone
(Attafuah Blencowe & Brunt 1963), Togo (Nguyen-Ban 1984)
Primary parasites: Aenasius martinii (Compere), Nigeria (Gregory 1954)
Coccophagus sp. near eleaphilus Silvestri, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Leptomastix dactylopii Howard, Ghana (Donald 1956), Nigeria (Gregory 1954)
Metaphycus sp. , Ghana (Donald 1956)
Hyperparasites: Cheiloneurus carinatus Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Predators: Coccodiplosis coffeae (Barnes), Ghana (Donald 1956)
Megommata donaldi (Pritchard), Ghana (Pritchard 1952)
Tended by: Camponotus sp. , Ghana (Strickland 1947a)
Crematogaster sp. , Ghana (Strickland 1947a)
Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Ivory Coast (Couturier Matile-Ferrero & Richard 1985)
Pheidole sp. , Ghana (Strickland 1947a)

Phenacoccus madeirensis Green
Status: The species is not a vector of swollen shoot virus and is uncommon on cocoa.
Distribution: Ghana (Donald 1956)
Primary parasites: Leptomastix dactylopii Howard, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Hyperparasites: Cheiloneurus carinatus Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Predators: Nephus ornatulus Korschefsky, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Spalgis lemolea Druce, Ghana (Donald 1956), Nigeria (Donald 1955b)

Planococcus boafoensis (Strickland)
Synonyms: Tylococcus boafoensis Strickland
Status: Described from Musanga smithii, it has been recorded on cocoa but is not important
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947b)

Planococcus citri (Risso)
Status: The adult female is oval, 3-5 mm long by 1-2 mm wide. The body is covered with powdery white wax
and bordered along each side with 17 waxy filaments of which the anal pair is longest. Eggs are laid in an
ovisac partly hidden beneath the rear end of the female’s body. Adult females and nymphs cluster together in
small colonies usually tended by ants. They are important vectors of several strains of Swollen Shoot virus.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a), Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008), Cook Is (Williams &
Watson 1988b), Costa Rica (Weber 1957), Cuba (Blanco Perez & Rodriguez 2003), Dominican Republic
(Wolcott 1922), Ghana (Strickland 1947a), Grenada (Ballou 1915), Guyana (Bodkin 1914), India
(Ramakrishna Ayyar 1919), Indonesia Java (Van der Knaap 1952), Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & SimonThomas 1961), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971), Nigeria (Donald 1955a), Papua
New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961), Peru (Wille 1952), Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra & Vayssiere 1918),
Sierra Leone (Attafuah Blencowe & Brunt 1963), Solomon Is (Lever 1968), Sri Lanka (Carter 1956), Sudan
(Schmutterer 1969), Tanzania (De Lotto 1964), Tanzania Zanzibar (De Lotto 1964), Togo (Dufour 1988),
Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b), Western Samoa (Demandt 1914), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Primary parasites: Aenasius abengouroui (Risbec), Ghana (Ackonor 2002), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Aenasius martinii (Compere), Ghana (Donald 1956), Nigeria (Donald 1955b)
Allothrombium sp. , Ghana (Donald 1956)
Anagyrus ?aurantifrons Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Anagyrus ?greeni Howard, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Anagyrus abyssinicus Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Anagyrus amoenus Compere, Ghana (Ackonor 2002)
Anagyrus beneficiens Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Anagyrus kivuensis Compere, Togo (Dufour 1991)
Anagyrus pullus Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)

Planococcus ficus (Signoret)
Status: A pest of vines No record of status on cocoa

Planococcus flagellatus De Lotto

HOMOPTERA

173

Planococcus kenyae (Le Pelley)
Synonyms: Pseudococcus lilacinus (Zaire) Cockerell
Status: The adult female is oval, 2.5 mm long by 1.5 mm wide. The body is yellowish in colour but covered by
powdery white wax which is absent or thinner along the central line with 17 pairs of waxy filaments getting
larger towards the hind end. It is very similar in appearance to P. citri and it is possible that it may have been
misidentified with that species in the past. It is the vector of a number of Swollen Shoot virus isolates.
Distribution: Ghana (Entwistle 1972), Ivory Coast (Couturier Matile-Ferrero & Richard 1985), Nigeria
(Browne 1968), Sierra Leone (Attafuah Blencowe & Brunt 1963), Togo (Dufour 1991), Zaire (Mayne &
Ghesquiere 1934)
Primary parasites: Aenasius abengouroui (Risbec), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Aenasius martinii (Compere), Nigeria (Donald 1955b)
Anagyrus kivuensis Compere, Togo (Dufour 1991)
Anagyrus sp. , Togo (Dufour 1991)
Leptomastix dactylopii Howard, Nigeria (Entwistle 1972), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Hyperparasites: Cheiloneurus carinatus Compere, Togo (Dufour 1991)
Cheiloneurus sp. , Togo (Dufour 1991)
Cheiloneurus sp. near cyanonotus Waterston, Togo (Dufour 1991)
Prochiloneurus aegyptiacus (Mercet), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Prochiloneurus pulchellus Silvestri, Togo (Dufour 1991)
Predators: Platynaspis higginsi Crotch, Nigeria (Donald 1955b)
Tended by: Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Ivory Coast (Couturier Matile-Ferrero & Richard 1985)

Planococcus lilacinus (Cockerell)
Synonyms: Planococcus crotonis (Green), Planococcus tayabanus (Cockerell), Pseudococcus crotonis Green,
Pseudococcus tayabunis Cockerell
Status: The species is confined to the Far East and is the vector of a mild cocoa virus in Sri Lanka.
Distribution: Brunei (Williams 2004), India (Ram 1979), Indonesia Java (Roepke 1916b), Indonesia West
Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Madagascar (Mamet 1959), Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991),
Malaysia Sabah (Williams 2004), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961), Philippines (Cockerell 1905), Sri
Lanka (Carter 1956)
Primary parasites: Anagyrus sp. , Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)
Predators: Exochomus melanocephalus (Zoubkoff), Sri Lanka (Carter 1956)
Scymnus sp. , Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)
Spalgis epeus (Westwood), Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924), Philippines (Entwistle 1972), Sri Lanka (Carter
1956)
Tended by: Dolichoderus thoracicus (F.Smith), Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924), Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho
1991)
Odontomachus haematodus (Linnaeus), Sri Lanka (Fernando 1956)
Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius), Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991), Sri Lanka (Fernando 1956)
Technomyrmex albipes (F.Smith), Sri Lanka (Le Pelley 1943)

Planococcus minor (Maskell)
Synonyms: Planococcus pacificus Cox
Status: Very similar in structure to P. citri and has probably been misidentified as this species in the past.
Distribution: Brazil (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Brunei (Williams 2004), Colombia (Williams &
Granara de Willink 1992), Dominica (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Fiji (Williams 1982), Grenada
(Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Guadeloupe (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Guyana (Williams
& Granara de Willink 1992), Jamaica (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992), Malaysia Sabah (Williams
2004), Malaysia Sarawak (Williams 2004), Myanmar (Morris & Waterhouse 2001), Papua New Guinea
(Williams 1982), Singapore (Williams 2004), Solomon Is (Williams 1982), Surinam (Williams & Granara de
Willink 1992), Thailand (Williams 2004), Tonga (Williams 1982), Trinidad & Tobago (Williams & Granara de
Willink 1992), Vanuatu (Williams 1982), Western Samoa (Williams 1982)
Primary parasites: Coccidoxenoides perminutus Girault, Trinidad & Tobago (Francis et al 2012)
Leptomastix dactylopii Howard, Trinidad & Tobago (Francis et al 2012)
Tended by: Anoplolepis gracilipes (F.Smith), Solomon Is. (Williams 1960a)
Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius), Solomon Is. (Williams 1960a)
Solenopsis geminata (Fabricius), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Technomyrmex albipes (F.Smith), Papua New Guinea (Williams 1960a), Solomon Islands (Williams 1960a)

174

Planococcus principe Cox
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (Cox 1989)

Promyrmococcus wayi Williams
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Williams 2004)
Tended by: Dolichoderus sp. , Malaysia Sabah (Williams 2004)

Pseudococcus calceolariae (Maskell)
Synonyms: Pseudococcus gahani Green
Status: Is the vector for some strains of Cocoa Swollen shoot virus
Distribution: Ghana (Campbell 1977)

Pseudococcus comstocki (Kuwana)
Status: In Trinidad it is the vector of a cocoa virus.
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)

Pseudococcus concavocerarii James
Status: Female with lateral wax filaments about half the width of the body and long posterior and anal pairs of
filaments 3-6 times as long as laterals. Feeds in small colonies on pods and small branches. Is the vector of
several strains of Swollen Shoot virus
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Donald 1955b), Sierra Leone
(Attafuah Blencowe & Brunt 1963)
Primary parasites: Allothrombium sp. , Ghana (Donald 1956)
Clausenia corrugata Kerrich, Ghana (Kerrich 1967)
Clausenia sp. near purpurea Ishii, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Leptomastix dactylopii Howard, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Hyperparasites: Cheiloneurus carinatus Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)

Pseudococcus jackbeardsleyi Gimpel & Miller
Status: Feeding on pods
Distribution: Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008), Malaysia (Williams 2004)
Tended by: Brachymyrmex sp. , Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008)
Wasmannia auropunctata (Roger), Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008)

Pseudococcus landoi (Balachowsky)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992)

Pseudococcus longispinus (Targioni Tozzetti)
Synonyms: Dactylopius adonidum Linnaeus, Pseudococcus adonidum (Linnaeus)
Status: The female is oviparous and found on stems and the underside of leaves but is uncommon on cocoa in
West Africa. Is a vector of Cooca Mottle Leaf virus but not Swollen Shoot virus.
Distribution: China (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997), Ghana (Anon 1948), Grenada (Williams & Granara de
Willink 1992), Indonesia Java (Koningsberger 1908), Nigeria (Lamborn 1914), Papua New Guinea (Williams
& Watson 1988b), Sierra Leone (Attafuah Blencowe & Brunt 1963), Taiwan (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997),
Tanzania Zanzibar (De Lotto 1964), Togo (Nguyen-Ban 1984), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b),
Vanuatu (Williams & Watson 1988b), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Primary parasites: Leptomastix dactylopii Howard, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Hyperparasites: Cheiloneurus carinatus Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Predators: Laemophloeus nebulosus Grouvelle, Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Leptophloeus janeti (Grouvelle), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Nephus ornatulus Korschefsky, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Spalgis lemolea Druce, Ghana (Donald 1956)

Pseudococcus occiduus De Lotto
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Uganda (De Lotto 1964)

HOMOPTERA

175

Pseudococcus solomonensis Williams
Status: Feeding on foliage
Distribution: Solomon Is (Lever 1968)
Tended by: Technomyrmex albipes (F.Smith), Solomon Islands (Williams 1960a)

Pseudococcus sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Dominican Republic (Russo 1927), Grenada (Williams 1922), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany
& Dun 1964), Uganda (Small 1915), Vanuatu (Risbec 1937)

Pseudococcus sp. near calceolariae (Maskell)
Synonyms: Pseudococcus sp. near gahani Green
Status: Can transmit several isolates of Cocoa Swollen Shoot virus
Distribution: Ghana (Donald 1956), Nigeria (Donald 1955b)
Primary parasites: Leptomastix dactylopii Howard, Ghana (Donald 1956)
Hyperparasites: Cheiloneurus carinatus Compere, Ghana (Donald 1956)

Pseudococcus sp. near comstocki (Kuwana)
Status: In Trinidad it is the vector of a cocoa virus.
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)

Pseudococcus viburni (Signoret)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: No locality (Gimpel & Miller 1996)

Pseudorhizoecus proximus Green
Status: Colonies develop on the roots of cocoa where the mealybugs feed within a sheath formed by the
mycelium of fungi of the genus.
Distribution: Costa Rica (Williams & Granara de Willink 1992)

Puto barberi (Cockerell)
Status: A relatively large mealybug up to 7mm long mainly seen during periods of drought. On coffee,
colonies are formed on roots as well as above ground parts of the plant
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)
Primary parasites: Zarhopalus putophilus Bennett, Trinidad & Tobago (Trjapitzin Bennett & Ruiz-Cancino
2004)
Hyperparasites: Prochiloneurus dactylopii (Howard), Trinidad & Tobago (Trjapitzin Bennett & Ruiz-Cancino
2004)
Tended by: Wasmannia auropunctata (Roger), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)

Rastrococcus iceryoides (Green)
Synonyms: Phenacoccus iceryoides Green
Status: Found mainly on young branches and leaf stems but also on pods it can at times be a troublesome pest
and is encouraged in its spread by the presence of ants. It has a wide range of alternative host plants including
mango, cotton and coffee.
Distribution: India (Abraham & Padmanaban 1967), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941), Tanzania
(Williams 1989)
Tended by: Anoplolepis gracilipes (F.Smith), Malaysia (Miller 1941)
Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius), India (Abraham & Padmanaban 1967)

Rastrococcus spinosus (Robinson)
Status: The mealybug has very long forwardly pointing lateral white wax filaments. It is primarily a pest of
mango but also feeds on leaves of cocoa
Distribution: Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)
Predators: Scymnus sp. , Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)
Tended by: Oecophylla smaragdina (Fabricius), Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)

Rhizoecus falcifer Kunckel d'Herculais
Synonyms: Rhizoecus moruliferus Green
Status: Colonies develop on the roots of coffee where the mealybugs feed within a sheath formed by the
mycelium of fungi of the genus Septobasidium and attended by various species of Acropyga ants for their
honeydew.

HOMOPTERA

176

Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Strickland 1945)
Tended by: Acropyga sp. , Trinidad & Tobago (Strickland 1945)

Rhizoecus spelaeus (Strickland)
Synonyms: Coccidella spelaea Strickland
Status: Described from roots of cocoa in Ghana. The female is oval, 2 mm long by 1.3 mm wide, pale brown
with a thin layer of white wax.
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a)

Saccharicoccus sacchari (Cockerell)
Status: An important pest of sugarcane. Status on cocoa not recorded
Distribution: Cuba (Blanco Perez & Rodriguez 2003)

Tylococcus westwoodi Strickland
Status: Feeding on pods. Transmits some strains of Cocoa Swollen Shoot virus
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a), Ivory Coast (Risbec 1955), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Tended by: Crematogaster stadelmanni Mayr, Ghana (Campbell 1983)
Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Ivory Coast (Risbec 1955)

HOMOPTERA PSYLLIDAE
Diclidophlebia sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Nigeria (Booker 1968)

Mesohomotoma tessmanni (Aulmann)
Synonyms: Tyora tessmanni Aulmann, Udamostigma tessmanni Aulmann
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on vegetative buds, the underside of young leaves, on green shoots and on
flower cushions. The nymphs are covered by a mass of woolly wax mixed with sticky honeydew on which
black moulds grow.
Distribution: Cameroon (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934), Central African Republic (Boulard 1967), Equatorial
Guinea Bioko (Cotterell 1930b), Gabon (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934), Ghana (Lodos 1968a), Ivory Coast
(Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Entwistle 1962), Sao Tome & Principe (Cotterell 1930b), Sierra Leone (Hargreaves,
E. 1927), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Primary parasites: Aloxysta sp. , Ghana (Lodos 1968c)
Dilyta camerounensis Tamesse & Tiyo, Cameroon (Tamesse & Tiyo 2007)
Psyllaephagus ?cellulatus Waterston, Ghana (Lodos 1968c)
Psyllaephagus tessmannii (Tamesse & Tiyo), Cameroon (Tamesse & Tiyo 2007)
Predators: Allobaccha picta (Wiedemann), Ghana (Cotterell 1927c)
Allobaccha praeusta (Bezzi), Ghana (Cotterell 1927c)
Allobaccha sinuata (Brunetti), Ghana (Cotterell 1927c)
Cheilomenes sulphurea (Olivier), Sao Tome & Principe (Entwistle 1972)
Chrysopa sp. , Ghana (Lodos 1968c)
Crematogaster clariventris (Mayr), Ghana (Firempong 1976)
Deraeocoris crigi Gibbs & Leston, Ghana (Lodos 1968c)
Tended by: Wasmannia auropunctata (Roger), Cameroon (Bruneau De Mire 1969)

Phacoptera sp.
Status: Adults and nymphs feed on vegetative buds, the underside of young leaves, on green shoots and on
flower cushions.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

HOMOPTERA RICANIIDAE
Armacia basigera (Walker)
Status: Dense populations recorded on seedlings
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

HOMOPTERA

Armacia sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Euricania discigutta var. bisignata Melichar
Status: Hoppers feed on shoots and leaf veins and cause little damage. Eggs are laid in the midrib of older
leves and may cause some damage
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Pochazia antica (Gray)
Synonyms: Pochazia fuscata Fabricius
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Pochazia fasciata (Fabricius)

Distribution: Ghana (Anon 1964a), Nigeria (Golding 1941a), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Ricania cervina Melichar

Ricania insularis Lallemand
Status: No record of status

HOMOPTERA STICTOCOCCIDAE
Parastictococcus anonae (Green & Laing)
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Richard 1971)
Tended by: Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Ivory Coast (Couturier Matile-Ferrero & Richard 1985)

178

HOMOPTERA

179

Parastictococcus gowdeyi (Newstead)
Synonyms: Stictococcus gowdeyi Newstead
Status: The adult female scale is more or less hemispherical 1.5 to 2 mm long, with a deep lateral depression
to the rear, shining and pale brown tinged with green. It feeds on young branches and is generally attended by
ants.
Distribution: Cameroon (Alibert 1951), Ghana (Cotterell 1927a), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria
(Newstead 1917), Uganda (Gowdey 1918b), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Primary parasites: Aethognathus bicolor Subba Rao, Nigeria (Subba Rao 1973)
Aethognathus unicolor Subba Rao, Nigeria (Subba Rao 1973)
Aprostocetus ugandaensis (Girault), Uganda (Gowdey 1918b)
Coccophagus cowperi Girault, Uganda (Gowdey 1918b)
Tended by: Crematogaster sp. , Ivory Coast (Couturier Matile-Ferrero & Richard 1985), Zaire (Mayne &
Ghesquiere 1934)
Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Ivory Coast (Couturier Matile-Ferrero & Richard 1985), Nigeria (Newstead
1917), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Tetraponera sp. , Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Parastictococcus hargreavesi (Vayssiere)
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Ghana (Campbell 1983), Ivory Coast (Couturier Matile-Ferrero & Richard 1985)
Tended by: Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Ivory Coast (Couturier Matile-Ferrero & Richard 1985)

Parastictococcus multispinosus (Newstead)
Synonyms: Stictococcus aliberti Vayssiere, Stictococcus dimorphus Newstead, Stictococcus diversiseta
Silvestri, Stictococcus multispinosus Newstead
Status: The adult female scale is more or less hemispherical and about 2 mm in diameter, pale brown in colour
and and covered with short upright hairs. In Togo it is found only on pod stalks but elsewhere it also infests
small branches. It has a wide range of alternative hosts.
Distribution: Cameroon (Entwistle 1972), Dahomey (Silvestri 1915), Ghana (Waterston 1917), Ivory Coast
(Alibert 1951), Ivory Coast (Couturier Matile-Ferrero & Richard 1985), Nigeria (Lamborn 1914), Tanzania
(Alibert 1951), Togo (Alibert 1951), Uganda (Gowdey 1912)
Primary parasites: Aethognathus afer Silvestri, Ghana (Waterston 1917)
Aethognathus cavilabris Waterston, Uganda (Waterston 1917)
Aprostocetus stictococci (Silvestri), Dahomey (Silvestri 1915)
Predators: Coccidiphaga scitula (Rambur), Nigeria (Lamborn 1914)
Eublemma costimacula (Saalmuller), Uganda (Gowdey 1913)
Tended by: Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Ivory Coast (Couturier Matile-Ferrero & Richard 1985), Nigeria
(Lamborn 1914)

Parastictococcus mutatus Richard
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Nigeria (Richard 1976)

Stictococcus formicarius Newstead
Status: The insect is found on young branches, generally attended by ants. It also occurs on coffee.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Tended by: Crematogaster sp. , Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Tetraponera sp. , Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Stictococcus intermedius Newstead
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Ghana (Newstead 1917), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Stictococcus sjostedti Cockerell
Status: The adult female scale is oval, about 4 mm long and 3 mm wide and with a depression dorsally. It is
shining, reddish or olive brown. It is found on young branches and pods. On the latter it can occur in
sufficiently large numbers to hamper the development of the pod.
Distribution: Cameroon (Strickland 1947a), Dahomey (Alibert 1951), Gabon (Alibert 1951), Ghana
(Strickland 1947a), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Lamborn 1914), Togo (Strickland 1947a), Zaire
(Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Predators: Eublemma ochrochroa Hampson, Nigeria (Lamborn 1914)

HOMOPTERA

Russograptis callopista (Durrant), Nigeria (Lamborn 1914)
Tended by: Crematogaster clariventris (Mayr), Ghana (Campbell 1994)
Crematogaster sp. , Ghana (Strickland 1947a), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)
Odontomachus haematodus (Linnaeus), Ghana (Evans & Leston 1971)
Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Ghana (Campbell 1984), Nigeria (Lamborn 1914), Zaire (Mayne &
Ghesquiere 1934)
Pheidole sp. , Ghana (Strickland 1947a)
Tetraponera sp. , Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Stictococcus sp.
Status: Feeding on shoots
Distribution: Central African Republic (Boulard 1967), Equatorial Guinea Bioko (Cotterell 1930a), Ghana
(Cotterell 1927a)

Euglossa sp.
Status: A nest of the bee was found in an old rotten cocoa pod.

Cotesia taprobanae (Cameron)
Synonyms: Apanteles stauropi Vierick, Apanteles stauropi formosae, Apanteles taprobanae Cameron
Status: The insect is a parasite

Primary parasite of: Neostauropus alternus (Walker), Indonesia Java (Menzel 1923), Indonesia Sumatra
(Menzel 1923)

HYMENOPTERA EUMENIDAE
Eumenes latreillei petiolaris Schulz

Status: The insect is a predator

Status: The adult mason wasp predates lepidopterous larvae for its nest
Distribution: Indonesia Sulawesi (Hoehn et al 2009)
