HYMENOPTERA FORMICIDAE DOLICHODERINAE
Azteca alfari Emery
Synonyms: Azteca bicolor Forel
Status: The ant nests in rotten parts of the cocoa tree and Erythrina shade and builds covered runways
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Urich 1911)

Azteca chartifex Forel
Status: Ants build carton nests in cocoa trees often of considerable size. They tend Homoptera and are also
predators. Infested trees tend not to grow well.
Distribution: Brazil (Azavedo 1925), Trinidad & Tobago (Urich 1911)
Predator of: Selenothrips rubrocinctus (Giard), Brazil (Torrend 1927)
Homoptera tended: Bolbonota pictipennis Fairmaire, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Horiola picta Fabricius, Brazil (Bondar 1924b), Trinidad & Tobago (Urich 1911)
Tragopa fulvovaria Fairmaire, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tragopa humeralis Fairmaire, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tragopa nitida Germar, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tropidolomia auriculata (Olivier), Brazil (Bondar 1924b)

Azteca chartifex spiriti Forel
Status: Ants build carton nests in cocoa trees often of considerable size. They tend Homoptera and are also
predators
Distribution: Brazil (De Medeiros Delabie & Fowler 1999), Brazil (Silva 1944a)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Brazil (De Medeiros Delabie & Fowler 1999)
Selenothrips rubrocinctus (Giard), Brazil (Delabie et al 2007)
Homoptera tended: Ceroplastodes bahiensis Bondar, Brazil (Silva 1950)
Ceroplastodes melzeri Bondar, Brazil (Silva 1950)
Ceroplastodes theobromae Bondar, Brazil (Silva 1950)
Millericoccus costalimae (Bondar), Brazil (Silva 1950)
Toxoptera aurantii (Boyer de Fonscolombe), Brazil (Silva 1944a)

Azteca forelii Emery
Status: The ant lives in carton galleries on the trunks of large forest trees. Its role on cocoa is not clear
Distribution: Venezuela (Jaffe Tablante & Sanchez 1986)
Predator of: Myoxomorpha breve (Sulzer), Venezuela (Jaffe Tablante & Sanchez 1986)

Azteca instabilis (F.Smith)
Status: Tending Homoptera and is also predatory
Distribution: Brazil (Majer Delabie & Smith 1994), Guyana (Bodkin 1917)

201

HYMENOPTERA

202

Azteca longiceps Emery
Status: The ant nests in branches of Triplaris melaenodendron. Its role on cocoa is not clear
Distribution: Brazil (Delabie et al 2007)

Azteca paraensis bondari Borgmeier
Status: Ants build carton nests in cocoa trees. The ants damage the tree directly by biting the terminal shoots
to obtain mucilage for nest building. Damage may result in death of the tree.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Azteca paraensis Forel
Status: Ants build carton nests in cocoa trees. The ants damage the tree directly by biting the terminal shoots
to obtain mucilage for nest building. Damage may result in death of the tree.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1930b)

Azteca paraensis nociva Borgmeier
Status: Ants build carton nests in cocoa trees. The ants damage the tree directly by biting the terminal shoots
to obtain mucilage for nest building. Damage may result in death of the tree.
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1944a)

Azteca sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Wiltshire 1965), Colombia (De Franco 1958), Costa Rica (Weber 1957), Trinidad &
Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)

Azteca velox Forel
Status: The ant nests in hollows of the trunk and often in abandoned cocoa beetle tunnels.
Distribution: Guyana (Bodkin 1917), Trinidad & Tobago (Urich 1911)

Dolichoderus attelaboides (Fabricius)
Status: Ants tend a number of Homoptera
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Homoptera tended: Bolbonota pictipennis Fairmaire, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Horiola picta Fabricius, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tragopa fulvovaria Fairmaire, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tragopa humeralis Fairmaire, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tragopa nitida Germar, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tropidolomia auriculata (Olivier), Brazil (Bondar 1924b)

Dolichoderus bidens (Linnaeus)
Status: Ants build fibre nests on the underside of a leaf. They tend Homoptera and are predators
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1944a), Guyana (Bodkin 1917), Surinam (Dammerman 1929)
Homoptera tended: Bolbonota pictipennis Fairmaire, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Horiola picta Fabricius, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Toxoptera aurantii (Boyer de Fonscolombe), Brazil (Silva 1944a)
Tragopa fulvovaria Fairmaire, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tragopa humeralis Fairmaire, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tragopa nitida Germar, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tropidolomia auriculata (Olivier), Brazil (Bondar 1924b)

Dolichoderus bispinosus (Olivier)
Status: Ants tend a number of Homoptera
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Homoptera tended: Bolbonota pictipennis Fairmaire, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Horiola picta Fabricius, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tragopa fulvovaria Fairmaire, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tragopa humeralis Fairmaire, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tragopa nitida Germar, Brazil (Bondar 1924b)
Tropidolomia auriculata (Olivier), Brazil (Bondar 1924b)

Dolichoderus thoracicus (F.Smith)
Synonyms: Dolichoderus bituberculatus Mayr, Dolichoderus tuberculatus F.Smith
Status: Ants build fibre nests either between leaves or in holes on the tree. They tend Homoptera and are
predators
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924), Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller
1941)
Predators: Bengalia varicolor (Fabricius), Indonesia Java (Van der Goot 1917b)
Ptilocerus venosus Walker, Indonesia Java (Van der Goot 1917b)
Predator of: Conopomorpha cramerella (Snellen), Malaysia W.Malaysia (See & Khoo 1996)
Helopeltis antonii Signoret, Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)
Helopeltis clavifer Walker, Indonesia (Graham 1991)
Helopeltis theivora theobromae Miller, Indonesia (Graham 1991), Malaysia W.Malaysia (Way & Khoo 1991)
Helopeltis theivora Waterhouse, Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)
Homoptera tended: Coccus viridis (Green), Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1929)
Ebhul varium (Walker), Malaysia (Azhar 1992)
Exallomochlus hispidus (Morrison), Malaysia (Azhar 1992)
Planococcus citri (Risso), Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)
Planococcus lilacinus (Cockerell), Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924), Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)

Iridomyrmex sp.
Status: Damaging flowers
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Linepithema humile (Mayr)
Status: A small 3 mm long litter nesting ant
Distribution: Brazil (Majer Delabie & Smith 1994)

Linepithema pulex Wild
Status: No record of status Nesting in abandoned Nasutitermes nests
Distribution: Brazil (Santos et al 2010)

Linepithema sp. near humile (Mayr)
Status: A small 3 mm long litter nesting ant
Distribution: Brazil (Delabie et al 2007)

Papyrius nitidus (Mayr)
Synonyms: Iridomyrmex nitida Mayr
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Philidris cordata (F.Smith)
Synonyms: Iridomyrmex cordatus F.Smith
Status: The ants nest in crevices, borer holes and in epiphytes and build covered runways
Distribution: Solomon Is (Macfarlane 1987)

HYMENOPTERA

Philidris myrmecodiae (Emery)
Synonyms: Iridomyrmex myrmecodiae Emery
Status: Tending Homoptera. On coffee damage is sometimes caused to bark which the ants use to build
covered runways
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971), Solomon Is (Williams 1960a)
Homoptera tended: Criniticoccus tectus Williams, Solomon Islands (Williams 1960a)
Planococcus citri (Risso), Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Tapinoma melanocephalum (Fabricius)
Status: The ants tend Homoptera and are predators
Distribution: Brazil (Delabie et al 2007), Ghana (Majer 1975)

Tapinoma sp.
Status: The ants tend Homoptera and are predators
Distribution: Brazil (Delabie et al 2007), Ghana (Bigger 1977), Togo (Dufour 1991)

Technomyrmex albipes (F.Smith)
Synonyms: Technomyrmex detorquens (Walker)
Status: The ants tend Homoptera
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1951), Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany
1961), Solomon Is (Williams 1960a), Sri Lanka (Le Pelley 1943)
Homoptera tended: Criniticoccus theobromae Williams, Solomon Islands (Williams 1960a)
Planococcus lilacinus (Cockerell), Sri Lanka (Le Pelley 1943)
Planococcus minor (Maskell), Papua New Guinea (Williams 1960a), Solomon Islands (Williams 1960a)
Pseudococcus solomonensis Williams, Solomon Islands (Williams 1960a)

Technomyrmex elatior Forel
Synonyms: Technomyrmex modiglianii elatior Forel
Status: The ants tend Homoptera
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Technomyrmex sp.
Synonyms: Engramma sp.
Status: The ants tend Homoptera
Distribution: Ghana (Collingwood 1973)

HYMENOPTERA FORMICIDAE DORYLINAE
Dorylus nigricans Illiger
Synonyms: Anomma nigricans (Illiger)
Status: Ground living ant which is a predator
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1951)

Ectatomma ruidum (Roger)

Lepisiota capensis (Mayr)

Status: The ants form a nest by webbing leaves together. They tend coccids for their honeydew and are
important predators., The ants form a nest by webbing leaves together. They tend coccids for their honeydew
and are important predators.

(Newstead 1917), Togo (Alibert 1951), Zaire (Mayne & Ghesquiere 1934)

Acanthognathus ocellatus Mayr
Status: The ant is a predator and nests in forest litter
Distribution: Brazil (Delabie et al 2007)

Acromyrmex octospinosus (Reich)
Status: The ants have underground nests in which they cultivate fungus on a bed of chopped up leaves.
Damage to the tree is caused by the workers cutting off pieces of leaf to replenish these beds.
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Urich 1911)

Crematogaster africana Mayr
Status: The ants are arboreal, building carton nests mostly in shade trees. They are both predators and tend
Homoptera. Has been recorded feeding on flowers and exocarp of pods
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Predator of: Distantiella theobroma (Distant), Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Homoptera tended: Formicococcus njalensis (Laing), Ghana (Strickland 1947a)
Toxoptera aurantii (Boyer de Fonscolombe), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Distribution: Brazil (Santos et al 2010)

Status: The ant tends aphids.
Distribution: Brazil (Delabie et al 2007), Costa Rica (Lara & Shenefelt 1961)
Homoptera tended: Aphis gossypii Glover, Costa Rica (Lara & Shenefelt 1961)
Toxoptera aurantii (Boyer de Fonscolombe), Costa Rica (Lara & Shenefelt 1961)

Crematogaster limata palans Forel
Status: Found nesting in an old rotten cocoa pod
Distribution: Costa Rica (Young 1986b)

Crematogaster luctans Forel
Status: The ants nest under flakes of bark and in rotten holes on the tree. They are both predators and tend
Homoptera
Distribution: Ghana (Strickland 1947a), Nigeria (Entwistle 1972), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Homoptera tended: Formicococcus njalensis (Laing), Ghana (Strickland 1947a), Nigeria (Entwistle 1972)
Planococcus citri (Risso), Ghana (Strickland 1947a)

Crematogaster magnifica Santschi
Status: The ants build large carton nests at branch unions and tends a range of Homoptera. It chews pods to
obtain mucilage for nest building.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Crematogaster montezumia F.Smith
Status: Not considered important
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Crematogaster petiolidens Forel
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Tetramorium aculeatum (Mayr)
Synonyms: Macromischoides aculeatus (Mayr)
Status: The ants make papery nests within the foliage. They are important as predators and because of their
painful bite make harvesting of the crop unpleasant.
Distribution: Cameroon (Mpe 2002), Ghana (Strickland 1951), Ivory Coast (Nguyen-Ban 1975b), Nigeria
(Booker 1967), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Predator of: Cleoporus theobromae Gressitt, Ivory Coast (Nguyen-Ban 1975b)

Wasmannia auropunctata (Roger)
Synonyms: Ochetomyrmex auropunctatus (Roger)
Status: This small ant has a painful bite but is an important deterent to many sucking insects and also tends
coccids for their honeydew.
Distribution: Brazil (Plank 1921), Cameroon (Bruneau De Mire 1969), Colombia (De Franco 1958), Costa
Rica (Weber 1957), Solomon Is (Ikin 1984), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b), Venezuela (Goitia
Bosque & Jaffe 1992)

Selenothrips rubrocinctus (Giard), Trinidad & Tobago (Williams 1918)

Dysmicoccus brevipes (Cockerell), Colombia (Kondo Portilla & Navarro 2008)
Dysmicoccus sp. near brevipes (Cockerell), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1953b)

HYMENOPTERA ICHNEUMONIDAE
Agrypon sp.
Synonyms: Trichionotus sp.
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Ghana (Akotoye 1975), Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)
Primary parasite of: Characoma stictigrapta Hampson, Ghana (Akotoye 1975)
Earias biplaga Walker, Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)

Atrometus sp.
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)
Primary parasite of: Eccopsis sp. near praecedens (Walsingham), Ghana (Smith 1965)

Brachycoryphus sp.
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)
Primary parasite of: Earias biplaga Walker, Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)

Buysmana cryptus (Tosq.)
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)
Primary parasite of: Setora nitens Walker, Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)

Charops sp.
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Entwistle 1969), Trinidad & Tobago
(Entwistle 1972)
Primary parasite of: Anomis leona Schaus, Ghana (Smith 1965)
Characoma stictigrapta Hampson, Ghana (Smith 1965)
Earias biplaga Walker, Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)
Euprosterna elaeasa Dyar, Trinidad & Tobago (Entwistle 1972)
Lophocrama phoenicochlora Hampson, Ghana (Smith 1965)
Olene mendosa (Hubner), Ghana (Smith 1965)

Chlorocryptus sp.
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)
Primary parasite of: Setora nitens Walker, Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)

Diaglyptidea roepkei Viereck
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1929)
Primary parasite of: Conopomorpha cramerella (Snellen), Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1929)

Echthromorpha agrestoria insidiator (Smith)
Synonyms: Echthromorpha insidiator Smith
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Primary parasite of: Tiracola plagiata (Walker), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)

Enicospilus sp.
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)
Primary parasite of: Anomis leona Schaus, Ghana (Smith 1965)
Lophocrama phoenicochlora Hampson, Ghana (Smith 1965)
Melese laodamia (Druce), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Primary parasite of: Conopomorpha cramerella (Snellen), Indonesia Java (Betrem 1941)

Synonyms: Goryphus javanicus Roman

Distribution: Indonesia Java (Betrem 1941)

Setora nitens Walker, Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)

Philippines (Alba et al 1985)

Goryphus sp. near angulicollis (Cameron)

Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)
Primary parasite of: Not recorded -, Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Goryphus sp. near braunsii (Kriechbaumer)
Synonyms: Brachycoryphus sp. near braunsii Kriechbaumer
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Ghana (Akotoye 1975)
Primary parasite of: Characoma stictigrapta Hampson, Ghana (Akotoye 1975)

Leurus caeruliventris (Cresson)
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Brazil (Anon 1983)
Primary parasite of: Syllepte prorogata (Hampson), Brazil (Anon 1983)

Mesochorus melanothorax Wilkinson
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Cameroon (Box 1944), Ghana (Wilkinson 1927), Nigeria (Box 1944)
Primary parasite of: Peristenus sahlbergellae (Wilkinson), Cameroon (Box 1944), Ghana (Wilkinson 1927),
Nigeria (Box 1944)
Hyperparasite of: Bryocoropsis laticollis Schumacher, Ghana (Box 1943)
Sahlbergella singularis Haglund, Cameroon (Box 1944), Ghana (Wilkinson 1927), Nigeria (Box 1944)

Mesostenus sp.
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Roepke 1919)
Primary parasite of: Conopomorpha cramerella (Snellen), Indonesia Java (Roepke 1919)

Nadia sp.
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Nigeria (Entwistle 1972)
Primary parasite of: Tragocephala castnia cacaoensis Entwistle, Nigeria (Entwistle 1972)

Netelia sp.
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Ghana (Akotoye 1975), Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)
Primary parasite of: Characoma stictigrapta Hampson, Ghana (Akotoye 1975)
Earias biplaga Walker, Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)

Ophion sp.
Synonyms: Paniscus sp.
Status: The insect is a parasite

HYMENOPTERA MEGACHILIDAE
Megachile frontalis (Fabricius)
Status: Adult cuts circular pieces from the edges of leaves.
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Papua New Guinea (Michener &
Szent-Ivany 1960)

Megachile sp.
Status: Adult cuts circular pieces from the edges of leaves.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Van Leeuwen 1908)

HYMENOPTERA MYMARIDAE
Erythmelus helopeltidis Gahan
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Ibrahim 1989)
Primary parasite of: Helopeltis theivora theobromae Miller, Malaysia (Ibrahim 1989)

Distribution: Colombia (Cabal-Concha 1956)

Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Boucek 1988)
Primary parasite of: Not recorded -, Papua New Guinea (Boucek 1988)

Pachyneuron sp.
Status: The insect is a parasite
Distribution: Fiji (Lever 1945)

HYMENOPTERA SCELIONIDAE
Baryconus sp.
Status: The insect is an egg parasite
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1945a)
Primary parasite of: Oecanthus sp. , Brazil (Silva 1945a)

Venezuela (Salas 1984)
Primary parasite of: Antiteuchus piceus (Palisot de Beauvais), Trinidad & Tobago (Callan 1944)

Status: The adult wasps are predators

ISOPTERA

232

ISOPTERA
ISOPTERA KALOTERMITIDAE
Bifiditermes madagascariensis (Wassmann)
Status: Feeds on already damaged wood particularly of weak trees
Distribution: Madagascar (Cachan 1949)

Cryptotermes havilandi (Sjostedt)
Synonyms: Cryptotermes lamanianus Sjostedt
Status: The termites usually gain entry to the tree through dead wood but in the Ivory Coast it only attacks
sound wood.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Cryptotermes sp.
Status: The termites usually gain entry to the tree through dead wood but in the Ivory Coast it only attacks
sound wood.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Glyptotermes dilatatus (Bugnion & Popoff)
Status: Can damage living wood entering through dead branches. Mainly a pest of tea but also found attacking
cocoa and coffee
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Jepson 1929)

Glyptotermes parvulus (Sjostedt)
Status: Found in both dry and living branches
Distribution: Ghana (Patterson 1927)

Kalotermes sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Colombia (De Franco 1958), Grenada (Anon 1914b)

Kalotermes wagneri (Desneaux)
Synonyms: Neotermes wagneri (Desneaux)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Neotermes aburiensis Sjostedt
Status: Tunneling in dead and living wood of trees attacked by Nectria rigidiuscula and ring barking
seedlings, young trees and basal chupons.
Distribution: Ghana (Patterson 1927), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Kay 1960)

Neotermes gestri Silvestri
Synonyms: Calotermes gestroi (Cotterell 1930a) Silvestri
Status: Enters wood through untreated wounds and spreads down branches and trunk. May kill the tree
Distribution: Equatorial Guinea Bioko (Harris 1971), Sao Tome & Principe (Cotterell 1930a)

Neotermes pallidicollis (Sjostedt)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919d)

Neotermes papua (Desneaux)
Status: Attacks through dead wood both above and below ground and feeds in healthy wood
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Neotermes samoanus (Holmgren)
Status: Attacks through the collar and tunnels upward through the trunk and branches
Distribution: Western Samoa (Harris 1969)

ISOPTERA

Neotermes sarasini (Holmgren)
Status: Attacks through the collar and tunnels upward through the trunk and branches
Distribution: Western Samoa (Demandt 1914)

Neotermes sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Harris 1971), Ghana (Patterson 1927), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

ISOPTERA RHINOTERMITIDAE
Coptotermes ceylonicus Holmgren
Status: Found in dead trees and in dead wood on living trees
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Jepson 1934)

Coptotermes sjostedti Holmgren
Status: Found in dead trees and in dead wood on living trees
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Coptotermes sp.
Status: Only found in dead branches.
Distribution: Nigeria (Kay 1960)

Schedorhinotermes lamanianus (Sjostedt)
Synonyms: Rhinotermes lamanianus Sjostedt
Status: Nests are built at ground level against the trunk of the tree and runways lead up to dead wood.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Schedorhinotermes putorius (Sjostedt)
Synonyms: Rhinotermes putorius (Sjostedt)
Status: Runways connect subterranean nests with dead wood on the tree
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919d)

ISOPTERA TERMITIDAE
Amitermes evuncifer Silvestri
Status: A soil living termite which attacks wood
Distribution: Ghana (Malaka 1983)

Ancistrotermes sp.
Status: A soil living termite which attacks wood
Distribution: Ghana (Malaka 1983)

Cephalotermes rectangularis (Sjostedt)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919b)

Eutermes latifrons (Sjostedt)
Status: Feeding on diseased parts of the plant
Distribution: Ghana (Patterson 1927), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Eutermes maculiventris Sjostedt
Status: Feeding on diseased parts of the plant
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Eutermes morio Latreille
Synonyms: Nasutitermes morio Latreille
Status: Builds large oval terminaria on trees
Distribution: Dominican Republic (Russo 1930)

233

ISOPTERA

234

Eutermes parvus Haviland
Status: Feeding on diseased parts of the plant
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Macrotermes bellicosus (Smeathman)
Status: Ground nesting and building large earth mounds. Mostly feeding on dead wood but has been recorded
ring-barking seedlings
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Kay 1960)

Macrotermes natalensis (Haviland)
Status: A soil living termite which destroys seedlings
Distribution: Nigeria (Sands 1962)

Macrotermes subhyalinus (Rambur)
Status: A soil living termite which attacks wood
Distribution: Ghana (Malaka 1983), Nigeria (Harris 1971)

Microcerotermes biroi (Desneaux)
Status: Builds conspicuous carton nests on trunks and gains entry to branches through old wounds
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Microcerotermes dolichognathus Silvestri
Status: Nests are in soil and entry is gained to branches through wounds
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919b)

Microcerotermes edentatus Wasmann
Status: Mostly feeding on dead wood
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Microcerotermes fuscotibialis (Sjostedt)
Status: Nests are in soil and entry is gained to branches through wounds
Distribution: Ghana (Malaka 1983)

Microcerotermes parvus (Haviland)
Status: Nests are in soil and entry is gained to branches through wounds
Distribution: Zaire (Harris 1971)

Microcerotermes parvus theobromae (Desneaux)
Status: Nests are in soil and entry is gained to branches through wounds
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1917c)

Microcerotermes solidus Silvestri
Status: Nests are in soil and entry is gained to branches through wounds
Distribution: Ghana (Patterson 1927)

Microcerotermes sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Western Samoa (Demandt 1914)

Microtermes pallidus (Haviland)
Status: Termites are attracted to dead pods remaining on the tree and has been known to attack weak trees
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941)

Microtermes sp.
Status: Only found in dead branches.
Distribution: Nigeria (Kay 1960)

Nasutitermes corniger (Motschulsky)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Santos et al 2010), Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

Nasutitermes elegantulus (Sjostedt)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

ISOPTERA

235

Nasutitermes ephratae (Holmgren)
Status: Carton nests have been found on trunks of cocoa trees but no damage has been done
Distribution: Brazil (Santos et al 2010), Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

Nasutitermes princeps (Desneaux)
Status: Carton nests on the trunk and attacks living wood
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

Nasutitermes rippertii (Rambur)
Status: Mostly feeding on dead wood
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Nasutitermes sp.
Status: Mostly feeding on dead wood but in Ivory Coast feeds on bark and old pods
Distribution: Brazil (Santos et al 2010), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Odontotermes horni (Wasmann)
Status: Feeding on roots
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Kemner 1926)

Pseudacanthotermes militaris (Hagen)
Status: The termites nest in the ground and invade the plant from below under mud runways. The main stem
or branches may be ring barked killing the part effected. Attack is particularly prevalent during periods of
drought.
Distribution: Nigeria (Harris 1969)

Termes amarilii (De Seabra)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (Navel 1921)

Termes ostentans Silvestri
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919d)

LEPIDOPTERA

236

LEPIDOPTERA
LEPIDOPTERA ARCTIIDAE
Acantharctia mundata (Walker)
Synonyms: Diacrisia mundata Walker
Status: Uncommon on cocoa, mainly on field crops
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Alpenus maculosus Stal
Synonyms: Diacrisia maculosa Cramer, Spilosoma maculosa Stal
Status: Larvae are leaf feeders
Distribution: Nigeria (Lamborn 1914), Uganda (Gowdey 1918a), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Alpenus schraderi rattrayi (Rothschild)
Synonyms: Diacrisia rattrayi Rothschild
Status: Caterpillar is around 30 mm long and yellow and with a black patch on each segment and with tufts of
dark hair.
Distribution: Cameroon (Lavabre 1957), Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria
(Youdeowei 1971)
Primary parasites: Chatolydella sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)
Thelaira aurofasciata Emden, Ghana (Smith 1965)
Thelaira nigripes (Fabricius), Ghana (Smith 1965)

Amerila leucoptera (Hampson)
Synonyms: Rhodogastria leucoptera Hampson
Status: Not common
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Amerila luteibarba (Hampson)
Synonyms: Rhodogastria luteibarba Hampson
Status: Caterpillar is green with sparse white setae and red spiracles. Head is yellowish green. Feeds on young
leaves and is common but in small numbers.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Amsacta lactinea Cramer
Status: The caterpillar is black with tufts of red brown hair along the sides with a single red spot on some
sections and two on others. Commonly found on cotton and is also recorded from coffee and tea.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Argina leonina Walker
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919d)

Asura atricraspeda Hampson
Status: The caterpillar is about 24-26 mm long and clothed in pectinate grey hairs.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Asura humilis Walker
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Asura reticulata (Felder)
Synonyms: Nepita reticulata Felder
Status: Caterpillar feeds on leaves. Uncommon
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

LEPIDOPTERA

237

Asura sp.
Status: Caterpillars are small, about 1 cm long. Two recorded from Ghana, one common with dense grey setae
and one uncommon with dark brown setae.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Automolis erubescens (Walker)
Synonyms: Metarctia invarea (Entwistle 1972) Walker
Status: Caterpillar is 28-29 mm long with a chestnut head. Prothorax brown with clear hairs, mesothorax
reddish yellow and the abdomen brown with lateral violet lines. Each segment has tubercles bearing tufts of
hairs. It is not of much importance on cocoa but is more prevalant on kola.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Balacra caeruleifascia Walker
Synonyms: Balacra ehrmanni Holland
Status: Larvae are leaf feeders
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Balacra pulchra Aurivillius
Status: Larvae are leaf feeders
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Balacra testacea Aurivillius
Status: Larvae are leaf feeders
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Belemnia ochriplaga Hampson
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1944a)

Brunia antica Walker
Synonyms: Eilema vicaria Walker
Status: Larvae feed on pods
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941)

Carales astur (Cramer)
Synonyms: Opharus astur Cramer
Status: Caterpillar feeds on flush leaves and is an important pest
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Creatonotus transiens Walker
Status: Polyphagous mainly on herbaceous plants
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Diacrisia auriantiaca Holland
Status: Caterpillar covered with long black setae and a brown head. Feeds on young leaves
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)
Primary parasites: Palexorista ?imberbis (Wiedemann), Ghana (Smith 1965)

Diacrisia chionea Hampson
Status: Caterpillar brown to black in colour with a broken white mid dorsal line and well covered in setae.
Feeds on young leaves and is not common.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Diacrisia curvilinea Walker
Status: Not common
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Nigeria (Golding 1946)

Diacrisia quadrilunata Hampson
Status: Not common
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA

238

Diacrisia turbida Butler
Status: Caterpillars feed on flush leaves
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Eilema ekeikei Bethune-Baker
Status: Caterpillars feed on flush growth
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Euchromia lethe Fabricius
Status: The caterpillar is about 20-22 mm long with a yellowish head. The thorax is yellow with tufts of black
hairs on the sides, the metathorax has in addition two forwardly pointing tufts of black hair.
Distribution: Cameroon (Zacher 1915), Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Halysidota sp.
Synonyms: Halisidota sp.
Status: Defoliation of cocoa occurred after the crop was invaded from the shade tree Trema micrantha
Distribution: Brazil (Ferraz & De Abreu 1984)
Primary parasites: Leschenaultia leucophrys (Wiedemann), Brazil (Ferraz & De Abreu 1984)
Lespesia affinis (Townsend), Brazil (Ferraz & De Abreu 1984)

Hypercompe muzima (Oberthur)
Synonyms: Ecpantheria muzina Oberthur
Status: Was recorded in Trinidad defoliating small cocoa plants under artificial shade
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)
Primary parasites: Carcelia flavirostris (Wulp), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Idalus herois Schaus
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1944a)

Lithosia sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Lobobasis niveimaculata Hampson
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1971)

Lophocampa maroniensis (Schaus)
Synonyms: Halisidota maroniensis Schaus
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1944a)

Lophocampa polyodonta (Rothschild)
Synonyms: Halisidota polyodonta Rothschild
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Lophocampa sobrina (Motschulsky)
Synonyms: Halisidota sobrina Motschulsky
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1944a)

Melese flaviopuncta Rothschild
Status: Caterpillars feed specially on chupons
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Melese laodamia (Druce)
Status: Caterpillars feed specially on chupons
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)
Primary parasites: Carcelia flavirostris (Wulp), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)
Enicospilus sp. , Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)
Microgaster sp. , Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

LEPIDOPTERA

239

Muxta xanthopa Holland
Synonyms: Eilema xanthopa Holland
Status: Very uncommon on cocoa
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Oeonistis entella Cramer
Synonyms: Oeonistis entella delia Fabricius
Status: Caterpillars are leaf feeders
Distribution: Vanuatu (Risbec 1937)
Primary parasites: Carcelia sp. , Vanuatu (Risbec 1937)
Pediobius sp. , Vanuatu (Risbec 1937)

Pelochyta arontes (Cramer)
Status: Caterpillar feeds on flush leaves and is an important pest
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Pericallia ricini (Fabricius)
Status: The caterpillar is dark brown speckled with white and with dorsal and lateral tufts of long dark hair.
Distribution: India (Kumar 1974)

Pseudoblabes oophora Zeller
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Syntomis dilateralis Hampson
Status: Uncommon, feeding on young leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA COSMOPTERIGIDAE
Pyroderces ptilodelta Meyrick
Status: Larvae feed on pods. Probably a scavenger
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941)

LEPIDOPTERA COSSIDAE
Eulophonotus myrmeleon (Felder)
Synonyms: Engyophlebus obesus Karsch
Status: The caterpillar is 28-31 mm long with a shining brown head and pale body with brown spots. The larva
bores tunnels, principally in the stem, but may also be found in branches or even roots. A tunnel is bored
vertically upward from an entrance hole which is as wide as the main gallery and may extend for as much as
30cm. As the mature larva is as much as 10mm in diameter the tunnel can be substantial. Alternative hosts
include coffee and cola.
Distribution: Cameroon (Entwistle 1972), Ethiopia (Abebe 1999), Ghana (Cotterell 1927c), Ivory Coast
(Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Lamborn 1914), Sao Tome & Principe (Gravier 1907), Sierra Leone (Smith 1965),
South Africa (Schoeman 1992), Togo (Entwistle 1972), Zaire (Mayne 1917)
Primary parasites: Amicrocentrum sp. , Ghana (Entwistle 1972)
Bathyaulax sp. , Ethiopia (Abebe 1999)

Xyleutes armstrongi (Hampson)
Synonyms: Duomites armstrongi Hampson, Engyophlebus obesus (Hargreaves 1926) Karsch
Status: The larva bores tunnels in stems. Alternative hosts include coffee.
Distribution: Sierra Leone (Hargreaves, E. 1926)

Zeuzera coffeae Nietner
Synonyms: Zeuzera roricyanea Walker
Status: On hatching the larvae spend the first few days beneath a communal shelter of silk. Later they launch
themselves on threads of silk and are widely dispersed on the wind. When they land on a suitable host they
bore into it, often at a leaf node. In small branches the tunnels of young larvae run down the centre and are
cylindrical, but older larvae hollow out irregular cavities and their tunnels may be ring shaped and girdle the

LEPIDOPTERA

240

branch. The whole tunnel can extend for 30-50 cm and even pass down into the root. Alternative hosts include
coffee, tea, citrus and cotton.
Distribution: India (Sathiamma & Bhat 1974), Indonesia Java (Koningsberger 1908), Indonesia West Irian
(Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941),
Papua New Guinea (Moxon 1991a), Sao Tome & Principe (Navel 1921), Sri Lanka (Hutson 1924)
Primary parasites: Amyosoma leuzerae Rohwer, Indonesia Java (Kalshoven 1950-51)
Bracon sp. , Malaysia Sabah (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)
Glyptomorpha sp. , Malaysia (Miller 1941)
Iphiaulax sp. , Malaysia Sabah (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)

Zeuzera conferta Walker
Status: Larva is a branch borer. Also recorded from coffee.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Kalshoven 1965), Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971), Malaysia W. Malaysia
(Anon 1953a)

Zeuzera sp.
Status: Larva is a branch borer. Probably refers to Zeuzera coffeae
Distribution: Malaysia Sarawak (Ron 1985), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

LEPIDOPTERA DALCERIDAE
Dalcera abrasa (Herrich-Schaffer)
Status: The caterpillar is gelatinous and golden in appearance. Normally found on Lagerstroemia but has been
recorded from young cocoa
Distribution: Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

LEPIDOPTERA EUPTEROTIDAE
Phiala hologramma Aurivillius
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Nigeria (Golding 1946)

LEPIDOPTERA GEOMETRIDAE
Aeschrapteryx sectata Guenee
Status: No record of status, probably a foliage feeder
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Ascotis selenaria reciprocaria Walker
Status: A looper caterpillar around 40-45 mm long, brownish grey in colour with speckling of brown and
black. Feeds on young leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Biston johannaria (Oberthur)
Synonyms: Buzura johannaria Oberthur
Status: Not common
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Catoria olivescens Moore
Status: Caterpillars feed on leaves
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Cleora sp.
Synonyms: Neocleora sp.
Status: Looper caterpillar is green with a brown head. Second abdominal segment with a dark spot anteriorly
and a dark spot above the spiracle. Feeds on young leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Primary parasites: Aleiodes sp. near pallidator (Thunberg), Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA

241

Cleora tulbaghata (Felder)
Synonyms: Neocleora tulbaghata Felder
Status: A looper caterpillar, 35-37 mm long, yellowish green marbled with chestnut and with black spots each
bearing a hair. The third abdominal segment bears a black spot on each side and there are two smaller patches
on the penultimate segment. Damage is not particularly important.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Primary parasites: Peribaea mitis Curran, Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Colocleora divisaria (Walker)
Status: A looper caterpillar around 50 mm long, coloured chestnut. Feeds on young leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Golding 1946)

Colocleora smithi (Warren)
Synonyms: Hyposidra smithi Warren
Status: Looper caterpillar is dark brown with sixth, seventh and eighth abdominal segments paler above. First
four abdominal segments with a pair of black dorsal dots on each segment. Fifth segment with a dark line.
Feeds on young leaves
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Ectropis bhurmitra (Walker)
Synonyms: Boarmia crepuscularia Hubner, Ectropis sabulosa Warren
Status: The caterpillar is grey brown, about 30-40 mm long and resembles a dead twig. Pupation takes place in
the ground. It is principally a pest of shade trees but will move to the crop when the shade is stripped.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New Guinea (Dun 1967)
Primary parasites: Winthemia sp. near sumatrana (Townsend), Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Ectropis crepuscularia (Schiffermuller)
Synonyms: Boarmia crepuscularia Schiffermuller
Status: A looper caterpillar 30-35 mm long with the second thoracic segment somewhat enlarged. The
caterpillars vary in colour from green to brown. Also found on chinchona and tea
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1929)

Ectropis sp. near varians Walker
Status: Larvae bear irritating hairs and feed on flush growth and pods
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Bourke et al 1971)

Glena bipennaria (Guenee)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Hypomecis transcissa (Walker)
Synonyms: Cleora transcissa
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Hyposidra sp.
Status: Caterpillars feed on leaves
Distribution: Indonesia Java (De Haan 1933)

Hyposidra talaca (Walker)
Status: Larvae feeding on flush foliage
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New
Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

Nematocampa completa Warren
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Paragonia procidaria (Herrich-Shaeffer)
Status: Looper caterpillar feeding on leaves
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

LEPIDOPTERA

242

Paragonia sp.
Status: A leaf feeding looper caterpillar
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Paragonia tasima (Cramer)
Status: A leaf feeding looper caterpillar
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Physocleora pauper Warren
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Scopula actuaria Walker
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Scopula sp.
Status: Caterpillar is a looper, thin and elongated, 20-25 mm long and greenish brown with darker brown
markings. It feeds on leaves
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Xenimpia erosa Warren
Status: Caterpillar is a leaf feeder. Uncommon
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Zamarada eogenaria Snellen

Zeuctoboarmia ?smithi (Warren)

LEPIDOPTERA GRACILLARIIDAE
Acrocercops dissotoma Meyrick
Status: Caterpillar bores epidermis of young and maturing pods
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Wood & Chung 1992)

Acrocercops sp.
Status: No record of status. On coffee is a leafminer
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Gauld 1976)
Primary parasites: Sliochia bala Gauld, Malaysia Sabah (Gauld 1976)

Acrocercops sp. near brochogramma Meyrick
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Conopomorpha cramerella (Snellen)
Synonyms: Acrocercops cramerella (Snellen), Gracilaria cramerella Snellen
Status: Caterpillars are extremely serious pod borers about 10-12 mm long and pale green. On hatching, the
larva bores straight into the pod and makes long galleries among the beans feeding on the tissue surrounding
the bean but not the beans themselves. At harvest this results in undersized and poor quality beans and
premature ripening. The insect was the cause of a decline of the industry in Sulawesi.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Koningsberger 1908), Indonesia Kalimantan (Sulistyowati & Junianto 1995),
Indonesia Maluku (Sulistyowati & Junianto 1995), Indonesia Sangihe Is (Entwistle 1972), Indonesia Sulawesi
(FAO 1978), Indonesia Sumatra (Pardede 1988), Indonesia Talaud Is (Entwistle 1972), Indonesia West Irian
(FAO 1978), Malaysia Sabah (Davis 1989), Malaysia Sarawak (Gumbek 1987), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Azhar
& Long 1996), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964), Philippines (Otanes 1937)

LEPIDOPTERA

243

Primary parasites: Acrocerilia pachynervis Van Achterberg, Philippines (Van Achterberg 1989)
Brachymeria sp. , Sarawak (Gumbek 1987)
Chelonus chailini Walker & Huddleston, Malaysia (Walker & Huddleston 1987)
Diaglyptidea roepkei Viereck, Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1929)
Goryphus fasciatipennis (Szepligeti), Indonesia Java (Betrem 1941)
Goryphus mesoxanthus (Brulle), Indonesia Java (Betrem 1941)
Goryphus sp. , Indonesia Maluku (Sulistyowati & Junianto 1995), Philippines (Alba et al 1985)
Mesostenus sp. , Indonesia Java (Roepke 1919)
Ooencyrtus ooii Noyes, Malaysia (Noyes 1991)
Paraphylax erythronota (Viereck), Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1929)
Paraphylax fasciatipennis Ashmead, Philippines (Irshad Vanialingam & Eashaw 1984)
Trichogrammatoidea bactrae fumata Nagaraja, Malaysia Sabah (Lim 1991)
Trichogrammatoidea bactrae Nagaraja, Malaysia Sabah (Lim 1983)
Trichogrammatoidea cojuangcoi Nagaraja, Philippines (Nagaraja 1984)
Trichogrammatoidea sp. , Indonesia Maluku (Sulistyowati & Junianto 1995), Philippines (Alba et al 1985)
Predators: Dolichoderus thoracicus (F.Smith), Malaysia W.Malaysia (See & Khoo 1996)

Marmara isortha (Meyrick)
Status: Larvae mine beneath the surface of pods but damage is at most superficial
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1944a)

Marmara sp.
Status: Larvae mine beneath the surface of pods but damage is at most superficial
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Spulerina sp.
Synonyms: Marmara sp. (West Africa)
Status: The caterpillar is legless, about 5-6 mm long and with each segment with lateral lobes. It mines
beneath the epidermis of green pods but seems to have little effect on the growth of the pod.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Eguagie 1971)
Primary parasites: Ageniaspis sp. , Ghana (Entwistle 1960b)
Bracon sp. , Ghana (Entwistle 1960b)

LEPIDOPTERA HELIODINIDAE
Oedematopoda cypris Meyrick
Status: Larvae are predators
Distribution: India (Fletcher 1920b)
Predator of: Kerria albizziae (Green), India (Fletcher 1920b)

LEPIDOPTERA HEPIALIDAE
Endoclita damor (Moore)
Synonyms: Phassus damor Moore, Phassus sericeus Swinhoe
Status: Larvae live at first in dead twigs on the ground but later move into living trees attacking at ground
level and boring downwards into the root. Also found on coffee and tea
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Roepke 1916b), Indonesia Kalimantan (Dammerman 1929), Indonesia Sumatra
(Dammerman 1929)

Endoclita hosei (Tindale)
Status: Larvae live at first in dead twigs on the ground but later move into living trees attacking at ground
level and boring downwards into the root.
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Anon 1964b), Malaysia Sarawak (Ron 1985)

LEPIDOPTERA

LEPIDOPTERA HESPERIIDAE
Coeliades chalybe (Westwood)

Status: Caterpillars are leaf feeders
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Coeliades forestan Stal
Status: Caterpillars are leaf feeders
Distribution: Nigeria (Golding 1946)

LEPIDOPTERA IMMIDAE
Imma sp.
Status: Larvae feed on flush foliage but not important
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Imma sp. near bilineella Snellen
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

LEPIDOPTERA LASIOCAMPIDAE
Bombycopsis indecora Walker
Status: No record of status but larva presumably feeds on leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Borocera sp.
Status: No record of status but larva presumably feeds on leaves.
Distribution: Zaire (Entwistle 1972)

Gonobombyx angulata Aurivillius
Status: Uncommon on cocoa, the caterpillar is fairly large and hairy.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Gonometa pallens Bethune-Baker
Status: No record of status but larva presumably feeds on leaves.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Lebeda intermedia Holloway
Status: Caterpillar is a leaf feeder
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Holloway 1987)

Leipoxais crenulata Bethune-Baker
Status: No record of status but larva presumably feeds on young leaves.
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Leipoxais peraffinis Holland
Status: No record of status but larva presumably feeds on young leaves.
Distribution: Cameroon (Zacher 1915)

Leipoxais rufobrunnea Strand
Status: Caterpillar is the only green Lasiocampid associated with cocoa and feeds on flush leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

244

LEPIDOPTERA

245

Leipoxais sp.
Status: Similar in appearance to L. sp. near peraffinis except that the membrane between the head and thorax
which is brown in the latter is red. Feeds on young leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Leipoxais sp. near peraffinis Holland
Status: Caterpillar is brown with a pair of thin white dorsolateral lines extending most of the length of the
body. Feeds on young leaves and is common.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Streblote dorsalis (Walker)
Synonyms: Taragama dorsalis Walker
Status: Sometimes attacks cocoa but is primarily a pest of Erythrina shade trees
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Hutson 1925)

Suana concolor Walker
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

LEPIDOPTERA LIMACODIDAE
Acharia sp.
Status: Caterpillar is a leaf feeder
Distribution: Venezuela (Anon 2000)

Afronarosa africana (Hering)
Status: Caterpillar is slug like and pale blue with irregular markings of darker blue. Feeds on mature leaves
and is uncommon.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Afronarosa sp.
Status: Caterpillar is flattened and oval with the integument extended laterally to form a carapace which hides
the head and body. Central area is brown surrounded by lighter brown. Outer part is green and transparent.
Feeds on mature leaves, but is uncommon.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Andrallochroma bicolor Strand
Status: Identity is uncertain and is rare. Caterpillar is green with a pair of flattened pointed processes on the
thorax and a similar pair towards the posterior end of the abdomen. A pair of yellow lines connects the anterior
and posterior processes with a blue spot at the base of each process.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Baria elsa (Druce)
Status: Caterpillar pale blue with a pair of narrow yellow longitudinal stripes. Scoli with long blue hairs. Feeds
on mature leaves and is common but in low numbers.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Birthamula chara Swinhoe
Status: Stinging caterpillars feeding on leaves
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Casphalia flavicollis Walker
Status: Caterpillar whitish with a brown tinge and with brown transverse markings leading into the lateral
scoli. Feed on mature leaves and is common but in small numbers
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Casphalia picta Schaus & Clement
Status: Only occasionally seen
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA

246

Chalcoscelides castaneipars Moore
Synonyms: Altha casteinipars Moore
Status: Caterpillars feed on foliage
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Cherometia lohor (Moore)
Synonyms: Belippa lohor Moore, Nemeta lohor Moore
Status: Caterpillars are green and oval and smooth with short stinging hairs, feeding on leaves. Polyphagous
including coffee and tea
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Van Hall 1914), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)
Primary parasites: Sathon belippae (Rohwer), Indonesia Java (Wilkinson 1928)

Cherometia sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Cosuma rugosa Walker
Status: Caterpillar is green with pairs of transverse yellowish green lines and well developed lateral scoli.
Feeds on mature leaves but is not common.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Ctenolita auribasalis (Holland)
Synonyms: Teinorrhyncha auribasalis (Holland)
Status: Caterpillar similar to C. pyrosomoides. Feeds on mature leaves and is common.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)
Primary parasites: Spilopimpla sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)

Ctenolita pyrosomoides (Holland)
Status: Caterpillar yellow dorsally with three large brown markings the middle one elongate. Scoli mostly
green but with a blue dorsal pair arising from the central brown spot. Well developed lateral scoli. Feeds on
mature leaves and is common.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Darna diducta (Snellen)
Synonyms: Ploneta diduncta Snellen
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Darna trima Moore
Synonyms: Orthocraspeda trima (Moore)
Status: Caterpillars have prominent lateral protruberances covered with stinging hairs
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Koningsberger 1908), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Anon 1953a)
Primary parasites: Apanteles sp. , Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)
Platyplectrus orthocraspedae Ferriere, No country (Entwistle 1972)

Euprosterna elaeasa Dyar
Status: A pest of coconuts, caterpillars occasionally attack cocoa
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)
Primary parasites: Charops sp. , Trinidad & Tobago (Entwistle 1972)

Griseothosea cruda (Walker)
Synonyms: Thosea cruda Walker
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Hyphorma subterminalis Hampson
Status: Caterpillar is white with a pair of black longitudinal stripes separated by a narrow white band. On the
abdomen two sets of black lines extend laterally form the central stripes. Feeds on mature leaves and is
uncommon.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA

247

Hypopta selenophora (Hering)
Synonyms: Niphadolepis selenophora Hering
Status: Caterpillar is flattened and oval with the integument extended laterally to form a white carapace which
hides the head and body with a central grey brown marking. Outer part of the carapace is semi-transparent.
Feeds on mature leaves, but is uncommon.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Latoia sp.
Status: Caterpillar is described as being similar to P. viridissima with two pairs of black eye spots posteriorly
and is green with rows of dorsal and lateral orange markings. Spines green. Not bred to adult. Feeding on
mature leaves
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Latoia viridifascia Holland
Status: Caterpillar is green with pairs of raised black markings dorsally and well developed lateral and dorsal
scoli bearing black spines. Feeds on mature leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Latoia vitilena Karsch
Status: Caterpillar is green with a pair of black eye spots posteriorly. Well supplied with green scoli which
bear pink, purple, blue and black spines. Feeds on mature leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Latoia vivida (Walker)
Synonyms: Parasa vivida Walker
Status: The caterpillar is pale green with a double line of longitudinal blue spots dorsally and a paler blue
interrupted stripe laterally. There are conical projections protruding from the body that bear long hairs which
can inflict a painful sting.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Uganda (Gowdey 1918a), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Limacosilla pirifera Hering
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Mambara inconspicua Bethune-Baker
Status: Caterpillars are leaf feeders, skeletonizing leaves
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)
Predators: Dindymus pyrochrous (Boisduval), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Platynopus melacanthus (Boisduval), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)

Miresa albipuncta Herrich-Shaeffer
Status: Caterpillar is about 26mm long and dark green with longitudinal strips and eight large brushes and
several smaller lateral brushes. Also found on coffee
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Miresa bracteata Butler
Synonyms: Miresa argentifera (Java) Moore
Status: Caterpillar is a leaf feeder
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Narosa hedychroa Bethune-Baker
Synonyms: Afronarosa hedychroa Bethune-Baker
Status: Caterpillar is flattened and oval with the integument extended laterally to form a carapace which hides
the head and body. Central area is brown with yellow markings. Outer part is green and transparent. Feeds on
mature leaves, sometimes in large numbers.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Narosa viridana Talbot
Status: Caterpillar is slug like and pale blue with irregular markings of darker blue. Feeds on mature leaves
and is uncommon.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA

248

Neomocena convergens (Hering)
Synonyms: Omocena convergens Hering
Status: Caterpillar is light brown with a pair of elongated cream coloured spots and other cream markings.
Feeds on mature leaves and is common in small numbers
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Omocena sp.
Status: Caterpillar is dark brown with a pair of white spots towards the anterior end of the abdomen and two
pairs of yellow markings towards the posterior end. Feeds on mature leaves and is common in small numbers.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Parasa carnapi Karsch
Synonyms: Parasa microbasis Hampson
Status: Stinging caterpillars feeding on leaves
Distribution: Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Parasa darma Moore
Status: A stinging caterpillar feeding on leaves
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Parasa lepida Cramer
Status: The caterpillar is pale green with a double line of longitudinal blue spots dorsally and a paler blue
interrupted stripe laterally. There are conical projections protruding from the body that bear long hairs which
can inflict a painful sting.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Koningsberger 1908), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Anon 1953a), Papua New Guinea
(Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964), Sri Lanka (Kalshoven 1950-51)
Primary parasites: Apanteles parasae Rohwer, No country (Entwistle 1972)

Parasa media Cramer
Status: Stinging caterpillars feeding on leaves
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Parasa sp.
Status: Recorded from the Ivory Coast the caterpillars of this species form a group on the underside of
neighbouring leaves. They are green in colour with dorsal chestnut patches and bear stinging hairs laterally.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Parasa viridissima Holland
Synonyms: Latoia viridissima Holland
Status: Caterpillar is green apart from a pair of brown eye-spots posteriorly bearing a short dense tuft of hairs
Scoli are short, evenly distributed and bear stiff spines. Feeding on mature leaves and not common. Also found
on Cola.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Nigeria (Golding 1946)

Perola cardinalli (West)
Synonyms: Phelbodicha cardinalli West
Status: Caterpillar is dull green and has a pair of short protruberances laterally. Feeds on mature leaves and is
uncommon
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Perola secunda (Strand)
Synonyms: Phelbodicha secunda Strand
Status: Caterpillar is dull green and has a pair of short protruberances laterally. Feeds on mature leaves and is
uncommon
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Phobetron hipparchia (Cramer)
Status: The larvae feed on leaves but are of no importance because only a few are to be found on any one tree.
Distribution: Brazil (Da Costa Lima 1936), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)
Primary parasites: Apanteles sp. , Brazil (Da Costa Lima 1936)
Palexorista longiuscula (Walker), Brazil (Da Costa Lima 1936)

LEPIDOPTERA

249

Phobetron sp.
Status: Larva is a foliage feeder
Distribution: Ecuador (Delvare 1992)
Primary parasites: Conura martinezi Delvare, Ecuador (Delvare 1992)
Conura phobetronae Delvare, Ecuador (Delvare 1992)

Pinzulenza kukisch Hering
Status: Larvae feed on hardened leaves leaving them with a peppered appearance and can completely defoliate
tree.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Catley 1960)
Primary parasites: Brachymeria salomonis (Cameron), Papua New Guinea (Anon 1971)
Chetogena sp. , Papua New Guinea (Anon 1971)

Rhypteira sordida Holland
Status: Caterpillar is smooth, oval and domed, green with a reticulate pattern of darker green. Feeds on mature
leaves but is not common,
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Scopelodes dinawa Bethune-Baker
Status: Larvae feed on foliage
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Scopelodes sp.
Status: Larvae feed on foliage
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Scopelodes unicolor Westwood
Status: Caterpillar is polyphagous with a metallic green body and four long backward pointing protruberances
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Scopelodes venosa Walker
Status: Caterpillar is a leaf feeder
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

Semyrilla lineata (Holland)
Status: Caterpillar is greenish brown dorsally with two oval pale green areas, sides are green. Has two anterior
and two posterior horizontal scoli which bear a brush of brown hairs. Larva eat mature leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Setora nitens Walker
Status: Caterpillar is polyphagous and green with lateral extensions carrying irritating hairs. Its stings can be
bothersome to harvest workers
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)
Primary parasites: Aleiodes sp. , Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)
Aroplectrus areolatus (Ferriere), Malaysia (Entwistle 1972)
Buysmana cryptus (Tosq.), Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)
Chaetexorista javana Brauer & Bergenstamm, Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)
Chaetexorista sp. , Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)
Chlorocryptus sp. , Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)
Euplectromorpha malayensis Ferriere, Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)
Euplectrus sp. , Indonesia (Dammerman 1929)
Exorista sorbillans (Wiedemann), Malaysia (Entwistle 1972)
Fornicia sp. , Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)
Goryphus mesoxanthus (Brulle), Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)
Meteorus sp. , Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)
Platyplectrus orthocraspedae Ferriere, Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)
Sarcophaga orientalis Parker, Malaysia (Entwistle 1972)
Spinaria armator (Fabricius), Indonesia Java (Entwistle 1972)

Sibine geyeri Fletcher
Synonyms: Sibine nesea Stal
Status: Feeding on leaves. Also found on castor and citrus

LEPIDOPTERA

250

Distribution: Colombia (De Franco 1958)

Sisyrosea ?diana Druce
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

Stroteroides nigrisignata Strand
Status: The caterpillar is brown marked with a dark green dorsal band bordering a narrow central white band
and bears stinging hairs on lateral scoli. Feeds on mature leaves
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Thosea sinensis (Walker)
Status: Caterpillar is 25 mm long, greyish green with a dorsal yellow stripe and two dorso-lateral rows of
coloured spots. Polyphagous including tea
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Thosea sp.
Status: Caterpillar green with longitudinal yellow lines interrupted by bluish patches. Feeds on mature leaves
and is common but in low numbers.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Trachyptena nigromaculata Hering
Status: Caterpillar is green and yellow with a speckled appearance. Caudal scoli are long. Anterior edge of
thorax maroon. Feeds on mature leaves and is common in small numbers
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Zinara recurvata Hampson
Status: Caterpillar is oval and flattened, green with four rows of white spots. Lateral scoli are green. Feeds on
mature leaves and common but in small numbers
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA LYCAENIDAE
Aslauga vininga Heinrich
Status: The caterpillar is a predator
Distribution: Ghana (Donald 1956), Nigeria (Donald 1955b)
Predator of: Formicococcus njalensis (Laing), Ghana (Donald 1956), Nigeria (Donald 1955b)

Candalides ?tringa Grose-Smith
Status: Larvae feeding on flush foliage. No importance
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Chalodeta lypera Bates
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Emesis cereus (Linnaeus)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Emesis mandana Cramer
Status: Caterpillar spins leaves together in a web
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Hypokopelates eleala Hewitson
Status: Caterpillar green brown. Posterior end of the abdomen expanded and flat. Feeds on young leaves
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)
Primary parasites: Apanteles diparopsidis Lyle, Ghana (Smith 1965)

Jamides celeno (Cramer)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

LEPIDOPTERA

251

Nacaduba berenice dobbensis Roeber
Status: Larvae feeding on flush foliage but doing minimum damage
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Nacaduba normani Eliot
Status: Caterpillar feeds on flush leaves
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Wood & Chung 1992)

Panthiades bitias (Cramer)
Synonyms: Thecla bitias (Cramer)
Status: Larvae feed on leaves
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Pseudolycaena marsyas (Linnaeus)
Synonyms: Thecla marsyas (Linnaeus)
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Spalgis epeus (Westwood)
Status: Caterpillar is a predator
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924), Philippines (Entwistle 1972), Philippines (Entwistle 1972), Sri
Lanka (Carter 1956)
Predator of: Ferrisia virgata (Cockerell), Sri Lanka (Carter 1956)
Planococcus citri (Risso), Sri Lanka (Carter 1956)
Planococcus lilacinus (Cockerell), Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924), Philippines (Entwistle 1972), Sri Lanka
(Carter 1956)

Spalgis lemolea Druce
Status: Caterpillar is a predator of coccids
Distribution: Ghana (Donald 1956), Nigeria (Donald 1955b), Togo (Dufour 1991)
Predator of: Ferrisia virgata (Cockerell), Ghana (Donald 1956), Nigeria (Donald 1955b)
Not recorded -, Togo (Dufour 1991)
Phenacoccus madeirensis Green, Ghana (Donald 1956), Nigeria (Donald 1955b)
Planococcus citri (Risso), Nigeria (Donald 1955b)
Pseudococcus longispinus (Targioni Tozzetti), Ghana (Donald 1956)

Synargis calyce (Felder & Felder)
Synonyms: Nymula calyce Felder
Status: Caterpillars feed on leaves particularly during the dry season
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Thecla hemon (Cramer)
Status: Caterpillars feed on flush leaves
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)
Primary parasites: Conura sp. near amoena (Say), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)
Hyperparasites: Conura sp. near amoena (Say), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Thecla orsina Hewitson
Status: Caterpillars feed on flush leaves
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Thecla sp.
Status: Larvae are gregarious and feed on flush leaves
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

Thecla talayra Hewitson
Status: Caterpillars feed on flush leaves
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Thecla tympania Hewitson
Status: Caterpillars feed on flush leaves
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)
