Theope eudocia Westwood
Status: Caterpillars feed on leaves particularly during the dry season
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Theope foliorum Bates
Status: Caterpillars feed on leaves particularly during the dry season
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

LEPIDOPTERA LYMANTRIIDAE
Argyrostagma niobe (Weymer)
Synonyms: Dasychira niobe Weymer
Status: Caterpillar is dark brown except for a dorsal blue marking on the fifth abdominal segment. Has dorsal
dense tufts of setae on the first four abdominal segements and a pair of lateral tufts pointing forward from the
thorax. Feeds on young leaves and is not common.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Nigeria (Gerard 1966a), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Bembina sp. near atripuncta (Hampson)
Synonyms: Euproctis sp. near atripuncta Hampson
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Calliteara horsfieldii (Saunders)
Synonyms: Dasychira horsfieldii (Saunders)
Status: Larvae are leaf feeders
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Clethrogyna turbata (Butler)
Synonyms: Orgyia turbata Butler
Status: Larvae are leaf feeders
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Crorema mentiens Walker
Status: Caterpillar covered with long black setae, head brown. Feeds on young leaves and is uncommon.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Darna nararia (Moore)
Synonyms: Macroplectra nararia (Moore)
Status: The caterpillar is yellowish to whitish green with a purple stripe dorsally, It has a fringe of long
pointed tubrcles with tufts of stinging spines and is about 12mm long when fully grown. It feeds on the
underside of the leaf.
Distribution: India (Naik Shivayogeshwar & Manjunath 2003)

Dasychira endophaea Hampson
Status: Not common.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Dasychira sp.
Status: Larvae are leaf feeders
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Eudasychira georgiana (Fawcett)
Synonyms: Dasychira georgiana Fawcett
Status: Not common.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Euproctis dewitzi (Grunberg)
Status: Not a serious pest. Feeding by caterpillars takes place on young leaves.
Distribution: Cameroon (Lavabre 1957), Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA

253

Euproctis fasciata Walker
Status: The caterpillar is around 15 mm long dark above and light below with tufts of grey hairs on the thorax.
They feed on leaves or young pods but are not particularly important.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Primary parasites: Megaselia scalaris (Loew), Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Euproctis lepidographa Hampson
Status: Not a serious pest. Feeding by caterpillars takes place on young leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Euproctis lyoma Swinhoe
Status: Not a serious pest. Feeding by caterpillars takes place on young leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Euproctis mediosquamosa Bethune-Baker
Synonyms: Nygmia sp.(Mayne 1917)
Status: Not a serious pest. Feeding by caterpillars takes place on young leaves and pods.
Distribution: Uganda (Gowdey 1918a), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Euproctis melanopholis Hampson
Status: Not a serious pest. Feeding by caterpillars takes place on young leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)
Primary parasites: Meteorus sp. near margaroniae Wilkinson, Ghana (Smith 1965)

Euproctis pygmaea Walker
Status: Caterpillar is around 22 mm long with a black head. Feeding takes place on young leaves but it is not a
serious pest.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Euproctis rufiterga Hampson
Status: Not a serious pest. Feeding by caterpillars takes place on young leaves.
Distribution: Zaire (Entwistle 1972)

Euproctis sp.
Status: Larvae feed on flush leaves and young pods
Distribution: Nigeria (Gerard 1966a), Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969), Sri Lanka (Jepson 1924), Vanuatu
(Risbec 1937)

Euproctis sp. near variana Walker
Status: Caterpillars common on flush growth and occasionally feed on previously damaged pods
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Euproctis subnotata (Walker)
Status: Larva feeds on leaves
Distribution: India (Radha & Rawther 1976)

Euproctis xanthomelaena Holland
Status: Not a serious pest. Feeding by caterpillars takes place on young leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)
Primary parasites: Aleiodes sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)
Glyptapanteles africanus (Cameron), Ghana (Smith 1965)

Lymantria ampla (Walker)
Status: Caterpillar is a leaf feeder
Distribution: India (Ramaseshiah & Bali 1987), Sri Lanka (Senior-White 1919)
Primary parasites: Aleiodes sp. , India (Ramaseshiah & Bali 1987)
Apanteles (glomeratus group) sp. , India (Ramaseshiah & Bali 1987)
Apanteles cacao Wilkinson, Sri Lanka (Senior-White 1919)
Apanteles obliquae Wilkinson, India (Ramaseshiah & Bali 1987)
Blepharipa sp. , India (Ramaseshiah & Bali 1987)
Brachymeria porthetrialis Joseph Narendran & Joy, India (Ramaseshiah & Bali 1987)
Carcelia sp. , India (Ramaseshiah & Bali 1987)
Euplectrus sp. , India (Ramaseshiah & Bali 1987)

LEPIDOPTERA

254

Exorista sp. , India (Ramaseshiah & Bali 1987)
Palexorista sp. , India (Ramaseshiah & Bali 1987)

Lymantria obfuscata Walker
Status: The Indian Gypsy Moth is a pest of a wide range of forest and fruit trees. It has been recorded feeding
on young leaves of cocoa
Distribution: India (Nair & Premkumar 1974)

Naroma signifera Walker
Status: Very uncommon
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Nygmia sp.
Status: Larvae feed on pods
Distribution: Uganda (Gowdey 1920), Zaire (Cotterell 1930a)

Olene inclusa (Walker)
Synonyms: Dasychira inclusa Walker
Status: Polyphagous on a wide range of crops including citrus and cocoa. Caterpillar is 40-50 mm long with
two long black tufts behind the head, and four dorsal brown tufts and copious lateral hairs. Some hairs are
urticating.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Olene mendosa (Hubner)
Synonyms: Dasychira basalis Walker, Dasychira mendosa (Hubner), Orgyia basalis Walker
Status: A grey caterpillar about 28-30 mm long with a reddish head. The prothorax has a pair of dark brown
tufts of hair pointing forward past the head. There are four large tufts of white hair dorsally on the thorax and
first abdominal segment and two pairs of tufts pointing laterally. The last abdominal segment bears grey tufts
pointing backwards. Not particularly important on cocoa but may feed on young plants.
Distribution: Cameroon (Lavabre 1957), China (Li Wang & Waterhouse 1997), Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory
Coast (Alibert 1951), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)
Primary parasites: Carcelia sp. , Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Charops sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)

Orgyia ?osseata (Walker)
Synonyms: Dasychira ?osseata Walker
Status: Larvae feed on leaves
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Orgyia basinigra (Heylaerts)
Synonyms: Dasychira basinigra Heylaerts
Status: Larvae feed on leaves
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Orgyia mixta Snellen
Status: Cterpillar is pale green with a yellow or black midline. First four abdominal segments with yellow tufts
of setae. Thorax with long forwardly pointing setae. Feeds on young leaves and is common.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Orgyia osseata (Walker)
Synonyms: Dasychira osseata Walker
Status: Larva is a foliage feeder
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Orgyia postica (Walker)
Synonyms: Notolophus posticus Walker
Status: The caterpillar has longitudinal bands of black, yellow, white and red with a black brushlike tuft
projecting forward over the head a similar tuft at the tail, two shorter white tufts on the sides and a row of four
yellow tufts on the back. The female moth is wingless and deposits her eggs on the surface of her cocoon.
Distribution: India (Wilkinson 1928), Indonesia Sumatra (Pardede 1986), Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs &
Simon-Thomas 1961), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun
1964), Philippines (Sanchez & Liago 1968), Sri Lanka (De Alwis 1926)
Primary parasites: Apanteles colemani Vierick, India (Wilkinson 1928)

LEPIDOPTERA

255

Telenomus sp. , Indonesia Sumatra (Pardede 1986)

Somena scintillans (Walker)
Synonyms: Porthesia scintillans Walker
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Stracaena fuscivena Swinhoe
Status: Very uncommon
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA MEGALOPYGIDAE
Megalopyge albicollis Walker
Status: Reared from pupae collected on cocoa
Distribution: Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

LEPIDOPTERA METARBELIDAE
Indarbela acutistriata (Mell.)
Synonyms: Arbela dea (Indonesia) Swinhoe, Squamura acutistriata (Indonesia) (Mell.)
Status: The caterpillar bores a hole in the stem or branch as a refuge and from this constructs a sinuous web of
silk to which pieces of bark are attached. The caterpillar feeds off the bark beneath this web and because it
gradually works its way all round the branch can eventually ring bark it.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Van Leeuwen 1910a)

Indarbela disciplaga Swinhoe
Status: The caterpillar bores a hole in the stem or branch as a refuge and from this constructs a sinuous web of
silk to which pieces of bark are attached. The caterpillar feeds off the bark beneath this web and because it
gradually works its way all round the branch can eventually ring bark it.
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Sidhu & Poon 1983), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Indarbela quadrinotata (Walker)
Synonyms: Arbela quadrinotata Walker, Squamura quadrinotata (Walker)
Status: The caterpillar bores a hole in the stem or branch as a refuge and from this constructs a sinuous web of
silk to which pieces of bark are attached. The caterpillar feeds off the bark beneath this web and because it
gradually works its way all round the branch can eventually ring bark it.
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Green 1914)

Indarbela sp.
Status: The caterpillar bores a hole in the stem or branch as a refuge and from this constructs a sinuous web of
silk to which pieces of bark are attached. The caterpillar feeds off the bark beneath this web and because it
gradually works its way all round the branch can eventually ring bark it.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Indarbela tetraonis (Moore)
Synonyms: Arbela teraonis (Moore), Arbela tetraonis Moore, Squamura tetraonis (Moore)
Status: The caterpillar bores a hole in the stem or branch as a refuge and from this constructs a sinuous web of
silk to which pieces of bark are attached. The caterpillar feeds off the bark beneath this web and because it
gradually works its way all round the branch can eventually ring bark it. It is 50-60 mm long when fully grown
and the larval stage is long lasting about 300 days.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Metarbela sp.
Status: Caterpillar feeds on bark most frequently at jorquettes beneath a web of silk with a short tunnel bored
into the wood.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)
Primary parasites: Meteoridea sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA

256

Salagena transversa Walker
Status: Caterpillar feeds on bark most frequently at jorquettes beneath a web of silk with a short tunnel bored
into the wood.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA NOCTUIDAE
Achaea catocaloides Guenee
Status: The caterpillar is a semi-looper 22-25 mm long and grey in colour with whitish speckling and a
brownish lateral band dividing the darker dorsal part with the light ventral surface. The insect is found
primarily on forest trees and only attacks cocoa when its food is exhausted but a massive outbreak occured in
Liberia in 2009 when a wide range of crops were effected.
Distribution: Cameroon (Lavabre 1957), Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Primary parasites: Blepharella lodosi Mesnil, Ghana (Lodos 1968c)

Achaea janata (Linnaeus)
Status: A grey semi-looper caterpillar speckled with white and with rows of white edged black spots dorsally
and a head patterned in black and white. It is primarily a pest of forest trees but at times may attack cocoa and
coffee.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Corbett & Miller 1933), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Ismail & Salim 1982),
Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)
Primary parasites: Apanteles sp. near creatonoti Vierick, Malaysia W. Malaysia (Corbett & Miller 1933)
Exorista sp. near sorbillans Wiedemann, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Telenomus sp. , Papua New Guinea (Dun 1967)
Trichogramma japonicum Ashmead, Papua New Guinea (Dun 1967)
Winthemia ?sumatrana (Townsend), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)

Achaea lienardi Boisduval
Status: Uncommon on cocoa
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Agrotis ipsilon (Hufnagel)
Status: The caterpillar is smooth and grey brown about 25-30 mm long and remains below ground during the
day. At night the caterpillar emerges from the soil and feeds on succulent tissues around the collar region of
seedlings. When mature it pupates in a cocoon beneath the ground.
Distribution: Colombia (De Franco 1958)

Agrotis subterranea (Fabricius)
Synonyms: Feltia annexa (Trietschke)
Status: The caterpillar is smooth and grey brown about 25-30 mm long and remains below ground during the
day. At night the caterpillar emerges from the soil and feeds on succulent tissues around the collar region of
seedlings. When mature it pupates in a cocoon beneath the ground.
Distribution: Colombia (De Franco 1958)

Amyna octo (Guenee)
Synonyms: Ilattia octo (Guenee)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Anomis leona Schaus
Status: The caterpillar is about 36-38 mm long and green in colour with a blue mid dorsal longitudinal line and
two lateral yellow longituditudinal lines on each side. The species is an important defoliator of cocoa through
much of West Africa feeding mainly on young leaves.
Distribution: Cameroon (Lavabre 1957), Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Golding
1946), Sao Tome & Principe (Passos de Carvalho 1968)
Primary parasites: Aleiodes sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)
Brachymeria sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)
Charops sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)
Enicospilus sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)
Euplectrus laphygmae Ferriere, Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

LEPIDOPTERA

Euplectrus leonae Risbec, Ghana (Owusu-Manu 1987)
Euplectrus sp. near fuscipes Ferriere, Ghana (Smith 1965)
Puliciphora borinquensis Wheeler, Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Trichogrammatoidea lutea (Girault), Ivory Coast (Nguyen-Ban 1974)

Anomis sp.
Status: Young caterpillars are dark green and older ones light green 40-43 mm long. They feed on young
leaves
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Argyrogramma signata (Fabricius)
Synonyms: Plusia signata Fabricius
Status: A green semi-looper caterpillar around 40 mm long with longitudinal stripes of darker green. A
polyphagous species but occasionally feeds on flush growth of cocoa.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Sierra Leone (Hargreaves, E. 1937)

Athetis sp.
Synonyms: Elydna sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Autoba lilacina Warren
Synonyms: Eublemma lilacina Warren
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Roepke 1916c)

Autoba rubra Hampson
Synonyms: Eublemma rubra Hampson
Status: Caterpillars feed on flush growth
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Bleptina bifurcata Bethune-Baker
Status: Larvae feeding on foliage
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Bourke et al 1971)

Catephiodes zuelana (Schaus)
Status: A yellow looper caterpillar eating holes in flush leaves
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957), Surinam (Reyne 1920), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Cerynea contentaria Walker
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Chrysodeixis acuta (Walker)
Synonyms: Plusia acuta Walker
Status: A green semi-looper caterpillar feeding on a wide range of crops.
Distribution: Nigeria (Golding 1946)

Chrysodeixis chalcites (Esper)
Synonyms: Phytometra chalcites Esper, Plusia chalcites Esper
Status: Caterpillar is a semi-looper and is green with a pair of lateral longitudinal white lines and many
yellow-green sinuous longitudinal lines. Feeding on young leaves and uncommon
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Sierra Leone (Hargreaves, E. 1932)

Chrysodeixis eriosoma (Doubleday)
Synonyms: Chrysodeixis chalcites (Asia & Pacific) (Esper), Plusia chalcites (Asia & Pacific) Esper
Status: A green semi-looper caterpillar feeding on a wide range of crops and with a wide geographical
distribution.
Distribution: Fiji (O'Connor 1959), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941)

Coccidiphaga scitula (Rambur)
Synonyms: Eublemma scitula Rambur
Status: The larva is a common predator of coccids
Distribution: Nigeria (Lamborn 1914), Uganda (Gowdey 1917)

257

LEPIDOPTERA

Predator of: Parastictococcus multispinosus (Newstead), Nigeria (Lamborn 1914)
Vitrococcus conchiformis (Newstead), Uganda (Gowdey 1917)

Corgatha sp. near leucosticta Hampson
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Deinypena fulvida (Holland)
Synonyms: Anomis fulvida Holland
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Cameroon (Lavabre 1957)

Diopa sp.
Status: Caterpillars feed on leaves
Distribution: Brazil (De Mello-Mendes Zucchi & De Barros-Mendes 1991)

Dorbeta albicauda (Hampson)
Synonyms: Blangmarditia albicauda Hampson
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Eublemma costimacula (Saalmuller)
Status: The larva is a common predator of coccids
Distribution: Uganda (Gowdey 1913)
Predator of: Parastictococcus multispinosus (Newstead), Uganda (Gowdey 1913)

Eublemma ochrochroa Hampson
Status: Caterpillar is a predator
Distribution: Nigeria (Lamborn 1914)
Predator of: Stictococcus sjostedti Cockerell, Nigeria (Lamborn 1914)

Eublemma sp.
Status: Caterpillar is a predator
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Hutson 1922)
Predator of: Kerria albizziae (Green), Sri Lanka (Hutson 1922)

Euclystis plusioides (Walker)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Brazil (De Mello-Mendes Zucchi & De Barros-Mendes 1991)

Eudrapa mollis Walker
Status: Caterpillar feeds on young leaves
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Hampsonodes mastoides (Hampson)
Synonyms: Calymniodes mastoides Hampson
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Helicoverpa armigera (Hubner)
Synonyms: Heliothis armigera conferta Hubner
Status: Occurs on a wide range of field crops. It occurs occasionally on cocoa but is not a serious pest
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Papua New Guinea (Barrett 1967)

Helicoverpa zea Boddie
Synonyms: Chloridea obsoleta Fabricius
Status: Occurs on a wide range of field crops. It occurs occasionally on cocoa but is not a serious pest
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Senior-White 1920)

Hemeroblemma leontia (Stal)
Synonyms: Peosina leontia (Stal)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

258

LEPIDOPTERA

259

Hemeroblemma mexicana (Guenee)
Synonyms: Melanchroia mexicana Guenee, Peosina mexicana Guenee
Status: A looper caterpillar feeding at night on young leaves and shoots but very damaging to young pods
which may be completely destroyed.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1924e), Mexico (Sanchez-Soto 1995)

Hemeroblemma rengus (Poey)
Status: A looper caterpillar feeding on pods
Distribution: Cuba (Dias 2003), Dominican Republic (Feliz 1977), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Lophoruza semiscripta Mabille
Status: Larva feeds on leaves. Rare
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Simplicia caeneusalis Walker
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Simplicia mistacalis Guenee
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Spodoptera androgea (Stal)
Synonyms: Spodoptera litura (Brazil) (Fabricius)
Status: Has been recorded feeding on flush leaves of cocoa but is more a pest of tomato
Distribution: Brazil (Zucchi & Silveira Neto 1984), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Spodoptera dolichos (Fabricius)
Status: Has been recorded feeding on flush leaves of cocoa but is more a pest of field crops such as cotton,
tomato and tobacco
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Spodoptera eridania (Stal)
Status: The caterpillar is dark greenish grey peppered with white spots, with a median and lateral longitudinal
orange yellow stripe. It is more a pest of field crops but has been recorded from time to time feeding on flush
growth of cocoa
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Spodoptera frugiperda (Smith)
Status: Has been recorded feeding on flush leaves of cocoa but is more a pest cruciferous plants
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Spodoptera latifascia (Walker)
Status: Has been recorded feeding on flush leaves of cocoa but is more a pest cruciferous plants
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Spodoptera littoralis (Boisduval)
Synonyms: Prodenia litura (W.Africa) Fabricius
Status: The caterpillar is about 35-38 mm long and smooth, bluey grey dorsally and whitish ventrally. There is
a median and a lateral longitudinal yellow stripe running along the whole body. It is an important pest of cotton
but has been recorded from a very large number of host plants. It is not particularly important as a defoliator of
cocoa
Distribution: Cameroon (Lavabre 1957), Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Golding
1946), Sudan (Schmutterer 1969)
Primary parasites: Apanteles risbeci De Saeger, Senegal (Alibert 1951)
Cotesia ruficrus (Haliday), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Spodoptera litura (Fabricius)
Status: The mature caterpillar is about 30 mm long dark greenish brown dorsally and paler ventrally with dark
and light lontidudinal bands. There is a row of triangular blackish spots running alongside a white dorsal stripe.
It has been recorded as a serious destroyer of flush leaves in nurseries where it feeds at night and hides in the
soil during the day.

LEPIDOPTERA

260

Distribution: Fiji (O'Connor 1959), Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Malaysia W.
Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New Guinea (Froggatt 1938)

Spodoptera sp.
Status: Caterpillars feed on leaves
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (Passos de Carvalho 1968)

Tiracola plagiata (Walker)
Status: Larvae feed on leaves. Severe damage recorded to seedlings in shaded areas.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Froggatt 1938)
Primary parasites: Echthromorpha agrestoria insidiator (Smith), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Exorista xanthaspis Wiedemann, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Predators: Actinus imperialis (Fauvel), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Anoplolepis gracilipes (F.Smith), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Eumenes latreillei petiolaris Schulz, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Helonotus exsugiens Stal, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Hexacentrus unicolor Walker, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Maira sp. , Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Nertha ampliata (Montford), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Pheidole megacephala (Fabricius), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Platynopus melacanthus (Boisduval), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Pristhesancus femoralis Horvath, Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)
Sceliphron laetum (F.Smith), Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)

Zurobata vacillans (Walker)
Synonyms: Oruza vacillans Walker
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

LEPIDOPTERA NOLIDAE
Characoma stictigrapta Hampson
Status: The larva, emerging from an egg laid on the surface of a green pod, bores into the husk of the pod
where it continues to feed. Normally only the husk is effected and there is no damage to the developing beans.
Distribution: Cameroon (Lavabre 1957), Equatorial Guinea Bioko (Cotterell 1930a), Ghana (Patterson 1914),
Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Golding 1946), Sao Tome & Principe (Passos de Carvalho 1968), Sierra
Leone (Hargreaves, E. 1937), Zaire (Cotterell 1930a)
Primary parasites: Agathis sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)
Agrypon sp. , Ghana (Akotoye 1975)
Apanteles sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)
Cadurcia auratocauda (Curran), Ghana (Akotoye 1975)
Carcelia angulicornis Villeneuve, Ghana (Smith 1965)
Charops sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)
Elasmus sp. , Ghana (Akotoye 1975)
Goryphus sp. near braunsii (Kriechbaumer), Ghana (Akotoye 1975)
Netelia sp. , Ghana (Akotoye 1975)
Palexorista amicula Mesnil, Ghana (Smith 1965)
Palexorista sp. near imberbis (Wiedemann), Ghana (Akotoye 1975)
Pristomerus sp. , Ghana (Akotoye 1975)
Zenilliana sp. , Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Hyperparasites: Pediobius minimus Delucchi, Ghana (Akotoye 1975)
Predators: Crematogaster sp. , Ghana (Akotoye 1975)
Oecophylla longinoda (Latreille), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Earias biplaga Walker
Synonyms: Earias citrina Saalmuller
Status: The caterpillar is 15-18 mm long and brown with longitudinal orange stripes. Hairs arise from conical
tubercles on the abdomonal segments. The insect is principally a pest of cotton but does attack young cocoa
plants where it feeds on the terminal buds and flush leaves.

LEPIDOPTERA

261

Distribution: Cameroon (Nguyen-Ban & Mpe 1987), Ghana (Smith 1962), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951),
Nigeria (Lamborn 1914), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964), Sao Tome & Principe (Passos de
Carvalho 1968), Sudan (Schmutterer 1969), Togo (Alibert 1951), Zaire (Alibert 1951)
Primary parasites: Agrypon sp. , Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)
Apanteles (ater group) sp. , Nigeria (Entwistle 1972)
Apanteles (ultor group) sp. , Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)
Apanteles biplagae Fischer, Ivory Coast (Nguyen-Ban 1968)
Apanteles carterus Walker, Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Apanteles diparopsidis Lyle, Uganda (Alibert 1951)
Apanteles sp. , Nigeria (Kumar & Nutsugah 1979)
Bassus aciculatus Brues, Ghana (Smith 1965), Nigeria (Entwistle 1969), Zaire (Alibert 1951)
Brachycoryphus sp. , Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)
Brachymeria minuta (Linnaeus), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Brachymeria sp. , Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)
Bracon brevicornis (Wesmael), Zaire (Alibert 1951)
Bracon lefroyi (Dudgeon & Gough), Zaire (Alibert 1951)
Charops sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)
Exorista sorbillans (Wiedemann), Ghana (Smith 1965)
Microgaster sp. , Nigeria (Pomeroy 1925)
Netelia sp. , Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)
Ophion sp. , Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Peribaea ?mitis Curran, Ghana (Smith 1965)
Peribaea suspecta (Malloch), Zaire (Alibert 1951)
Pristomerus sp. , Nigeria (Entwistle 1969)
Trichogrammatoidea lutea (Girault), Ivory Coast (Nguyen-Ban 1975a), Nigeria (Entwistle 1969), Nigeria
(Kumar & Nutsugah 1979)
Predators: Rhynchium ventrale Saussure, Nigeria (Lamborn 1914)
Vestula lineaticeps (Signoret), Ghana (Smith 1965)

Earias sp.
Status: Caterpillars feed on foliage
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Froggatt 1938)

Lophocrama phoenicochlora Hampson
Status: Caterpillar is dark brown with a row of pale spots dorsally the central one of which is large. The body
tapers posteriorly. Head is paler. The adult has a bright green forewing. Feeds on young leaves and is common
Distribution: Cameroon (Lavabre 1957), Ghana (Smith 1965), Nigeria (Golding 1946)
Primary parasites: Apanteles sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)
Charops sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)
Enicospilus sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)

Maurilia albirivula Hampson
Status: Larva feeds on leaves and is very occasional.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Selepa celtis (Moore)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Selepa leucograpta Hampson
Status: Caterpillar with a light brown thorax and abdomen dark brown laterally and light brown dorsally. Has
clubbed setae which are well developed on the thorax and posterior end of the abdomen. Feeds on young
leaves and is not common.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Selepa sp.
Status: Larva feeds on leaves. Coffee is an alternative host
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

LEPIDOPTERA

262

LEPIDOPTERA NOTODONTIDAE
Epidonta variegata (Aurivillius)
Synonyms: Alenophalera variegata Aurivillius
Status: Caterpillar feeds on leaves. Uncommon
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Lirimiris meridionalis (Schaus)
Status: Caterpillars feed on leaves
Distribution: Belize (Young 1983a)
Predators: Forcipomyia fuliginosa (Meigen), Belize (Young 1983a)

Neostauropus alternus (Walker)
Synonyms: Stauropus alternus Walker
Status: Known from tea as ‘lobster caterpillar’, the larva is dark red brown with a pale line along the back and
streaks of grey on several sections. The hind somite is swollen and carried over the back and the two prolegs
on that section stick upward looking like antennae. It only feeds at night sitting perfectly still during the day.
An important pest of tea.
Distribution: India (Siddappaji Reddy & Pattanshetti 1974), Indonesia Java (Dammerman 1929), Indonesia
Sumatra (Menzel 1923), Sri Lanka (Rutherford 1914b)
Primary parasites: Cotesia taprobanae (Cameron), Indonesia Java (Menzel 1923), Indonesia Sumatra (Menzel
1923)

Scalmicauda sp.
Synonyms: Graphidura sp.
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)

Scalmicauda sp. near argenteomaculata (Aurivillius)
Synonyms: Graphidura sp. near argenteomaculata Aurivillius
Status: Caterpillar feeds on mature leaves and is common but in small numbers.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA NYMPHALIDAE
Acraea alciope Hewitson
Status: The caterpillars bear long black spines on all the thoracic and abdominal segments which in turn have
stout horizontally pointing hairs arranged along them. They are polyphagous but will at times feed on cocoa
leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Acraea lycoa Godart
Status: The caterpillars bear long black spines on all the thoracic and abdominal segments which in turn have
stout horizontally pointing hairs arranged along them. They are polyphagous but will at times feed on cocoa
leaves.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Acraea pharsalus Ward
Status: The caterpillars bear long black spines on all the thoracic and abdominal segments which in turn have
stout horizontally pointing hairs arranged along them. They are polyphagous but will at times feed on cocoa
leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Acraea rogersi Hewitson
Status: The caterpillars bear long black spines on all the thoracic and abdominal segments which in turn have
stout horizontally pointing hairs arranged along them. They are polyphagous but will at times feed on cocoa
leaves.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA

263

Acraea zetes Linnaeus
Status: The caterpillars bear long black spines on all the thoracic and abdominal segments which in turn have
stout horizontally pointing hairs arranged along them. They are polyphagous but will at times feed on cocoa
leaves.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Archeoprepona demophon muson (Fruhstorfer)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Colombia (Valencia Gil & Constantino 2005)

Brassolis isthmia Bates
Status: Primarily a pest of coconut and other palms has been known to feed on cocoa
Distribution: Costa Rica (Anon 1924)

Brassolis sophorae Linnaeus
Status: Primarily a pest of palms it has been known to feed on cocoa
Distribution: Brazil (Zanetti et al 1999), Trinidad & Tobago (Urich 1921)

Callicore sp.
Status: Caterpillars feed on leaves
Distribution: Colombia (De Franco 1958)

Diaethria clymene meridionalis Bates
Synonyms: Callicore meridionalis Staudinger
Status: Caterpillars feed on leaves but do little damage
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1924e)

Euploea leucostictos Gmelin
Synonyms: Euploea nemertes ssp. near ulagona Ribbe
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

Euriphene plautilla Hewitson
Synonyms: Euryphura plautilla Hewitson
Status: Not common on cocoa
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Hypolimnas alimena (Linnaeus)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

Hypolimnas misippus Linnaeus
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (Entwistle 1972)

Junonia pelarga (Fabricius)
Synonyms: Precis pelarga Fabricius
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Nigeria (Golding 1946)

Phalanta eurytis Doubleday
Synonyms: Atella columbina Cramer
Status: Caterpillar feeds on leaves and is uncommon on cocoa
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA OECOPHORIDAE
Anadasmus porinodes (Meyrick)
Status: Caterpillars are shoot borers of a number of forest trees and bore into cocoa pods
Distribution: Venezuela (Jimenez 2003)

LEPIDOPTERA

264

Athrypsiastis symmetra Meyrick
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Cerconota carbonifer (Busck)
Status: Caterpillar is a leaf feeder
Distribution: Venezuela (Anon 2000)

Cerconota dimorpha Duckworth
Status: Caterpillars hide during the day between two leaves fastened together and feed at night on young
leaves which they skeletonize
Distribution: Brazil (De Mello-Mendes Zucchi & De Barros-Mendes 1991)

Nephantis serinopa Meyrick
Status: The species is an important pest of coconut and other palms. Its status on cocoa is not recorded
Distribution: India (Kerrich 1973)
Primary parasites: Pediobius imbreus Walker, India (Kerrich 1973)

Odites sp.
Status: Caterpillar feeds between two leaves fastened together with silk.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Pansepta teleturga Meyrick
Status: Larvae feed on cambium of stems and branches and may completely ring bark them
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany &
Dun 1964)
Primary parasites: Brachymeria sp. , Papua New Guinea (Bailey 1978)
Curriea sp. , Papua New Guinea (Quicke 1983)
Ipobracon sp. , Papua New Guinea (Entwistle 1972)

Stathmopoda sp. near trichopeda Lower
Status: Caterpillar is a predator
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Williams & Watson 1990)
Predator of: Drepanococcus chiton (Green), Papua New Guinea (Williams & Watson 1990)

Stenoma baliandra (Meyrick)
Synonyms: Zetesima baliandra Meyrick, Zetesima theobromae Busck
Status: The caterpillars are dark brown and feed in groups between two leaves fastened together leaving only
the veins and the epidermis intact. The ad ult has a wing span of 18 mm.
Distribution: Brazil (De Mello-Mendes Zucchi & De Barros-Mendes 1991), Peru (Entwistle 1972), Surinam
(Busck 1920)
Primary parasites: Conura sp. , Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

Stenoma decora Zeller
Status: Caterpillars feed on bark beneath a web shelter. Also on pods
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1944a)
Primary parasites: Arachnophaga hirtibasis Gahan, Brazil (Silva & Heinrich 1947)
Winthemia pinguoides (Townsend), Brazil (Silva 1944b)

Stenoma sp.
Status: Larva probably feeding on bark
Distribution: Colombia (De Franco 1958)

Stenoma strigivenata (Butler)
Status: No record of status. Larva probably feeding on bark
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1988a)

LEPIDOPTERA

265

LEPIDOPTERA PAPILIONIDAE
Papilio demodocus Esper
Status: Caterpillars are well known as defoliators of citrus, not common on cocoa
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (Entwistle 1972)

Papilio nurettini Kocak
Synonyms: Papilio bromius Doubleday
Status: Caterpillars feed on leaves and are not common on cocoa
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (Entwistle 1972)

LEPIDOPTERA PIERIDAE
Delias hyparete metarete Butler
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

LEPIDOPTERA PSYCHIDAE
Acanthoecia laminati (Heylaerts)
Synonyms: Heylaertsia larminati Joannis
Status: Feeding on leaves from within a case
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Acanthopsyche entwistlei Bourgogne
Status: Feeding on leaves from within a case
Distribution: Nigeria (Bourgogne 1962a)

Acanthopsyche melanoleuca Bourgogne
Status: Feeding on leaves from within a case
Distribution: Nigeria (Entwistle 1972)

Acanthopsyche sierricola (White)
Synonyms: Chalia sierricola (White), Metisa sierricola (White), Oiketicoides sierricola (White), Thyridopteryx
sierricola (White)
Status: Larvae feed on leaves from within a tubular case of leaf fragments
Distribution: Nigeria (Bourgogne 1961)

Acanthopsyche sp.
Status: The larva is a leaf feeder and lives within a silken tube onto which small pieces of dried leaves have
been attached
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Acanthopsyche tristoides Bourgogne
Status: Feeding on leaves from within a case
Distribution: Nigeria (Bourgogne 1965)

Amatissa sp.
Status: Caterpillar feeding on foliage
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Bourgognea obscurior (Bourgogne)
Synonyms: Manatha obscurior Bourgogne
Status: Caterpillars feed fron within a case
Distribution: Nigeria (Bourgogne 1962a)

LEPIDOPTERA

266

Brachycyttarus griseus Joannis
Status: Caterpillars feed on leaves from within a larval case
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Brachycyttarus reijnvaanii (Leeuwen)
Synonyms: Pteroma reynvaani Heylaerts
Status: Caterpillars feed on leaves from within a larval case covered with long protruding fibres and
sometimes leaf fragments hanging from a thread 3-10 mm long.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Chalioides sumatrensis (Heylaerts)
Synonyms: Animula sumatrensis Heylaerts
Status: Caterpillars feed from within a felted fusiform whitish bag, 27 mm long for males and 60 mm for
females. Not common on cocoa
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Clania sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: India (Emmanuel Sujatha & Gautam 2010b), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Dappula tertia (Templeton)
Synonyms: Oiketicus tertia Templeton
Status: Caterpillar feeds on leaves from within a conical case coated with fine plant fragments
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Diaphanopsyche rogenhoferi (Heylaerts)
Synonyms: Monda rogenhoferi Heylaerts
Status: Caterpillar feeds from within a case
Distribution: Nigeria (Entwistle 1972)

Dichromopsyche sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Nigeria (Entwistle 1972)

Eumeta cervina Druce
Status: Caterpillars feed from within a bag adorned with petioles of leaves
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Nigeria (Entwistle 1963b)

Eumeta crameri (Westwood)
Synonyms: Clania crameri Hampson, Cryptothelia crameri (Westwood), Eumeta layardi Walker, Oiketicus
crameri Westwood
Status: The caterpillar lives within a case constructed from short lengths of twig which are parallel to one
another and run more or less the whole lenght of the case which can be up to 75mm long. It not only feeds on
leaves but also eats bark and can do considerable damage to a tree from this habit.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Roepke 1915), Indonesia Sumatra (Rhainds Gries & Saleh 1997), Indonesia
West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Eumeta rougeoti Bourgogne
Status: Caterpillar lives within a bag and feeds on leaves
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Nigeria (Entwistle 1963b)
Primary parasites: Exorista ?ebneri (Villeneuve), Nigeria (Entwistle 1972)

Eumeta sp. near variegata (Snellen)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Eumeta variegata (Snellen)
Synonyms: Clania variegata (Snellen), Clania wallacei Swinhoe, Oiketicus variegata (Snellen)
Status: The caterpillar lives within a bag about 75mm long using one or two leaves resting flat on the bag and
attached throughout their length.Like It not only feeds on leaves but also eats bark and can do considerable
damage to a tree from this habit.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (De Haan 1933), Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961),
Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Corbett & Miller 1933)

LEPIDOPTERA

267

Primary parasites: Nealsomyia rufella (Bezzi), Malaysia (Corbett & Miller 1933)
Sarcophaga caudagalli Boettcher, Malaysia (Corbett & Miller 1933)

Kophene cuprea Moore
Status: Larva feeds on leaves
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Kophene sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Kotochalia junodi (Heylaerts)
Status: Feeding on leaves from within a case
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Nigeria (Entwistle 1963b)

Kotochalia sp.
Synonyms: Chalia sp.
Status: The caterpillar feeds from within a pyramidal and twisted case of transversely laid pieces of twig. It
ring barks shoots from which the severed ends fall and can cause much deformation of the tree.
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)
Primary parasites: Exorista thomasi Mesnil, Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Mahasena corbetti Tams
Status: Feeds from within a case covered with untidy fragments of leaf and twig
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Kalshoven 1950-51), Indonesia Sumatra (Kalshoven 1950-51), Malaysia W.
Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Mahasena sp. near aurea (Butler)
Synonyms: Plateumeta sp. near aurea Butler
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Melasena sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Metisa plana Walker
Status: Caterpillar is a leaf feeder
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Metura elongata (Saunders)
Status: Caterpillars feed from within a bag covered at first with bits of leaf and later with short twigs.
Distribution: Vanuatu (Risbec 1937)

Narycia sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971)

Oiketicoides javana Heylaerts
Synonyms: Clania sp. near destructor Dudgeon, Cryptothelia destructor Dudgeon
Status: Caterpillars feed from within a bag
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Oiketicoides sp. near javana Heylaerts
Status: Caterpillars feed from within a bag
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Oiketicus angulatus Gaede
Status: Caterpillars feed from within a bag
Distribution: Nigeria (Entwistle 1972)

Oiketicus gigantea (Dudgeon)
Synonyms: Clania gigantea Dudgeon
Status: Caterpillars feed from within a bag

LEPIDOPTERA

268

Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Oiketicus kirbyi (Guilding)
Status: Caterpillar feeds from within a silken bag 35-50 mm long. It is polyphagous on a range of plants
including coffee, avocado and banana
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Pagodiella hekmeyeri (Heylaerts)
Synonyms: Clania hekmeyeri (Heylaerts), Eumeta hekmeyeri (Heylaerts), Pagodia hekmeyeri (Heylaerts)
Status: The caterpillar builds a case from overlapping sections of leaf in the form of a pagoda Circular holes
are scraped on both surfaces of the leaf. Also on cocoa and tea
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Bernard 1919), Indonesia Sumatra (Van Heurn 1919), Indonesia West Irian
(Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961), Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho
1980)

Pseudometisa aemula (Bourgogne)
Synonyms: Metisa aemula Bourgogne
Status: Caterpillar feeds on leaves from within a case
Distribution: Nigeria (Bourgogne 1962b)

Pteroma pendula (De Joannis)
Synonyms: Crematopsyche pendula De Joannis
Status: Caterpillar feeds from within a case
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Pteroma plagiophleps (Hampson)
Status: The caterpillar lives within a more or less cylindrical case tapering towards the hind end and around 20
mm long with a few leaf fragments firmly attached to it. and suspended by a silken thread.
Distribution: India (Emmanuel Sujatha & Gautam 2010b), Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas
1961), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

LEPIDOPTERA PTEROPHORIDAE
Michaelophorus nubilus (Felder & Rogenhofer)
Synonyms: Oxyptilus sp , Platyptilia sp
Status: The larva is about 8-10 mm long, pale green with a brownish head. It attacks flush leaves initially
eating round holes near the midrib but later devouring the whole leaf.
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1980), Ecuador (Matthews & Miller 2010), Honduras (Matthews & Miller 2010),
Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)
Primary parasites: Actia panamensis Curran, Brazil (Silva 1980), Trinidad & Tobago (Entwistle 1972)
Conura sp. , Honduras (Matthews & Miller 2010)

Sphenarches anisodactylus (Walker)
Status: Larva feeds on leaves
Distribution: India (Fletcher 1920a)

Sphenarches caffer Zeller
Status: Larva is pale green with a pair of longitudinal red green lines and about 1cm long. Common
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Sri Lanka (Senior-White
1920)

LEPIDOPTERA PYRALIDAE
Amyelois transitella (Walker)
Synonyms: Myelois duplipunctata Ragonot, Paramyelois duplipunctella (Ragonot)
Status: Larvae feed on pods
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a)

LEPIDOPTERA

269

Apomyelois muriscis (Dyar)
Synonyms: Spectrobates muriscis (Dyar)
Status: Recorded boring into a pod of Theobroma simiarum
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

Assara albicostalis (Walker)
Synonyms: Ephestia albicostalis (Walker), Hyphantidium albicostalis (Walker)
Status: Larvae feed by boring in pods
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Miller 1941)

Assara sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Bocchoropsis phraxalis Druce
Synonyms: Bocchoris phraxalis Druce
Status: Caterpillar feeds on flush leaves abd shoots
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1988a), Colombia (Urueta Sandino 1975b), Cuba (Tur & Vazquez 1991),
Dominican Republic (Wolcott 1922)

Bocchoropsis plenelinealis (Dyar)
Synonyms: Bocchoris plenelinealis Dyar
Status: The green larvae roll up the young leaves of cocoa and feed within them
Distribution: Surinam (Reyne 1920)

Cadra cautella (Walker)
Synonyms: Ephestia cautella Walker
Status: An important warehouse pest feeding on produce such as cocoa or coffee beans in many tropical
locations but in Europe cannot survive the winter. The larva is about 15 mm long and pale pinkish brown with
dark brown spots. The head and last abdominal segment are black.
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1974), Ecuador (Knoche 1963), Equatorial Guinea Bioko (Alvarez Aparicio 1943),
Ghana (Nicol 1941), Grenada (Nicol 1941), Indonesia (Dharmaputra et al 2000), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951),
Ivory Coast (Finkelman et al 2003), Jamaica (Ritchie 1917), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980),
Nigeria (Golding 1941b), Papua New Guinea (Froggatt 1937), Sao Tome & Principe (De Gouveia & Da Sousa
1968), Sri Lanka (Fernando 1939), Trinidad & Tobago (Nicol 1941), Venezuela (Knoche 1963)
Primary parasites: Bracon hebetor Say, Ghana (Rawnsley 1968), Nigeria (Cotterell 1952)

Conogethes punctiferalis (Guenee)
Synonyms: Dichocrocis punctiferalis Guenee
Status: Larvae feed by boring in pods
Distribution: India (Mohanan & Kumar 1976), Indonesia Java (Kalshoven 1923), Malaysia W. Malaysia
(Miller 1941), Sri Lanka (Jepson 1924)
Primary parasites: Brachymeria sp. , Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)

Corcyra cephalonica (Stainton)
Status: A pest of tropical warehouses where it feeds principally on stored grain but has been recorded feeding
on stored cocoa and coffee beans. The larva is about 12 mm long with a dark head and prothorax. The body is
cream coloured with raised black spots.
Distribution: Brazil (Da Costa Lima 1936), Dominican Republic (Gómez-Menor 1934), Fiji (Simmonds
1924), Ghana (Nicol 1941), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Sivapragasam et al 1992),
Nigeria (Mbata 1989), Sri Lanka (Hutson 1920), Venezuela (Nicol 1935)

Doloessa viridis (Zeller)
Status: Caterpillars feed on beans in store
Distribution: Malaysia Sabah (Conway 1971), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Ectomyelois muriscus (Dyar)
Status: Bred from pods of Theobroma simiarum
Distribution: Costa Rica (Young 1986a)

LEPIDOPTERA

270

Ephestia elutella (Hubner)
Status: An important warehouse pest feeding on produce such as cocoa or coffee beans It ius very similar to
Cadra cautella but unlike that species it is found mostly in Europe and not usually in tropical situations. The
larva is about 15 mm long and pale pinkish brown with dark brown spots. The head and last abdominal
segment are black
Distribution: Brazil (Nicol 1941), Ghana (Anon 1932), Indonesia Java (Van Hall 1914), Jamaica (Edwards
1932), Sri Lanka (Van Hall 1914), Venezuela (Nicol 1941)
Primary parasites: Bracon hebetor Say, Ghana (Waters 1933)

Ghesquirellana hirtusalis (Walker)
Synonyms: Polygrammodes hirtusalis Walker
Status: Not common on cocoa
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Hyolobathra miniosalis Guenee
Status: Caterpillar feeds on leaves. Uncommon
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Mussidia nigrivenella Ragonot
Status: The larva is 16-17 mm long with a light brown head and prothorax. The abdomen is whitish with rows
of brownish spots. It feeds on the beans within old decaying pods left on the tree.
Distribution: Ghana (Hurlock 1959), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Pomeroy 1921), Tanzania (Waiyaki
1973), Zaire (Mayne 1917)

Mussidia pectinicornella (Hampson)
Synonyms: Myelois pectinicornella Hampson
Status: The larva is 16-17 mm long with a light brown head and prothorax. The abdomen is whitish with rows
of brownish spots. It feeds on the beans within old decaying pods left on the tree.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Sri Lanka (Fletcher 1920a)

Pilocrocis melastictalis Hampson
Status: Very occasional
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Plodia interpunctella (Hubner)
Status: Caterpillars attack cocoa beans in store
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Finkelman et al 2003)

Stenia minorales Snellen
Synonyms: Stenia spodinopa Meyrick
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Syllepte prorogata (Hampson)
Synonyms: Sylepta prorogata Hampson
Status: Body of the larva is green and the head shining black, 22-24 mm long. Older larvae live within a tent
of leaves fastened together and skeletonize the leaves.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1924e), Colombia (De Franco 1958), Dominican Republic (Schmutterer 1990),
Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954), Venezuela (Anon 2000)
Primary parasites: Leurus caeruliventris (Cresson), Brazil (Anon 1983)
Microgaster sp. , Brazil (Anon 1983)
Perilampus sp. , Brazil (Anon 1983)

Syllepte retractalis (Hampson)
Synonyms: Sylepta retractalis Hampson
Status: Body of the larva is green and the head shining black, 22-24 mm long. Older larvae live within a tent
of leaves fastened together and skeletonize the leaves. The young larvae feed on leaves at first in a group and
later spreading out so that only a single larva is found per leaf. Cola is an alternative host plant
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Nigeria (Golding 1946)
Primary parasites: Cardiochiles sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)
Cenocoelius sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Pristomerus sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA

271

Terastia meticulosalis Guenee
Status: Found principally on Erythrina shade
Distribution: Brazil (Anon 1985), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

LEPIDOPTERA SATURNIIDAE
Arsenura armida (Cramer)
Synonyms: Automeris armida (Fabricius), Automeris armida erythrinae (Fabricius)
Status: Caterpillars are at first grey yellow but at later stages change to a rusty orange colour. Mature
caterpillars are 10-11 cm long. The species is primarily a pest of Erythrina shade trees but mature caterpillars
will descend to feed on cocoa
Distribution: Brazil (Silva 1944a), Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)
Primary parasites: Winthemia pinguoides (Townsend), Brazil (Silva 1944b)

Automeris janus Cramer
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Lamont 1917)
Primary parasites: Belvosia aldrichi (Townsend), Trinidad & Tobago (Lamont 1917)

Automeris liberia Cramer
Synonyms: Automeris erisichton Boiduval
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Dirphia tarquinia (Cramer)
Synonyms: Hyperdirphia tarquinia Cramer
Status: Caterpillars only once recorded from cocoa
Distribution: Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

Eacles imperialis (Drury)
Status: Caterpillar up to 10mm feeding on leaves
Distribution: Ecuador (Paredes et al 2011)

Imbrasia dione (Fabricius)
Synonyms: Nudaurellia dione Fabricius
Status: The caterpillar is 45-50 mm long and black in colour. From the second thoracic segment to the eighth
abdominal segment each segment bears four tubercles armed with backward pointing yellow spines. The
caterpillars keep together in a group and feed on leaves and small shoots. It is a polyphagous species and feeds
on a number of forest trees.
Distribution: Cameroon (Zacher 1915), Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Primary parasites: Solindenia sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Imbrasia epimethea Drury
Status: Occasionaly feeds on cocoa
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)
Primary parasites: Senometopia evolans Wiedemann, Ghana (Smith 1965)

LEPIDOPTERA SESIIDAE
Aegeria sp.
Status: Caterpillars bore into pods and bark of stems
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Van Leeuwen 1910b), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Thomas 1960)
Primary parasites: Elasmus nephantidis Rohwer, Malaysia (Thomas 1960)
Telenomus sp. , Malaysia (Thomas 1960)

Carmenta chrysophanes (Meyrick)
Synonyms: Conopia chrysophanes (Meyrick)
Status: Larvae bore in trunks and branches just under the bark
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Bourke et al 1971)
Primary parasites: Apanteles (grandiculus group) sp. , Papua New Guinea (Bourke et al 1971)

LEPIDOPTERA

272

Carmenta foraseminis Eichlin
Status: Caterpillars bore into pods and feed on beans
Distribution: Panama (Eichlin 1995), Venezuela (Jimenez 2003)

Carmenta sp. near chrysophanes (Meyrick)
Synonyms: Conopia sp. near chrysophanes (Meyrick)
Status: Caterpillars bore into pods
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)
Primary parasites: Apanteles sp. near abdominalis Fabricius, Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Carmenta theobromae Linnaeus
Status: Caterpillars bore into pods and feed on beans
Distribution: Venezuela (Marin Narvaez & Spinelli 1999)

Isothamnis sp.
Status: Larva tunnels within the bark of old or moribund trees.
Distribution: Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)

Synanthedon cirrhozona Diakonoff
Status: Larvae feed on pods
Distribution: Philippines (Nagaraja et al 1987)

Synanthedon hector (Butler)
Synonyms: Aegeria hector Butler
Status: Feeding in shells of pods
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Paerels 1924)

Synanthedon sp near theobromae (Busck)
Synonyms: Conopia sp. near theobromae Busck
Status: Caterpillar bores into pods
Distribution: Colombia (Moncayo 1958)

Synanthedon theobromae (Busck)
Synonyms: Aegeria theobromae (Busck), Conopia theobromae Bradley
Status: Caterpillar bores into dry pods
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961), Trinidad & Tobago (Busck 1910)
Primary parasites: Apanteles sp. near abdominalis Fabricius, Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

LEPIDOPTERA SPHINGIDAE
Daphnis nerii (Linnaeus)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919d)

Hippotion eson Cramer
Status: The caterpillar is 50-60 mm long and variable in colour, but in general brown dorsally and paler
ventrally and with darker brown triangular markings along the sides. There is a large blackish brown eyespot
on either side of the thorax. The tail at the rear of the abdomen is relatively short. The caterpillar sometimes
moves from its herbaceous host and feeds on cocoa at the end of the dry season.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Polyptychus carteri Butler
Status: Caterpillar is 40-45 mm long and green with a dark dorsal line and V shaped marks on each abdominal
segment. A tail arises from the last abdominal segment. The larva is uncommon on cocoa and is also found on
kola
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

LEPIDOPTERA

LEPIDOPTERA THYRIDIDAE
Iscalina mediosecta Warren
Synonyms: Striglina vulpina Warren
Status: Larvae feed on flush foliage but not important
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Iscalina rufocastanea (Rothschild)
Synonyms: Striglina rufocastanea Rothschild
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Striglina asinina Warren
Status: Larvae feed on flush foliage but not important
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

Striglina sp.
Status: Larvae feed on flush foliage but not important
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

LEPIDOPTERA TINEIDAE
Haplotinea insectella (Fabricius)
Synonyms: Setomorpha insectella (Fabricius)
Status: No record of status, probably in store
Distribution: Brazil (Da Costa Lima 1936)

Moerarchis anomogramma (Meyrick)
Synonyms: Endothetis anomogramma Meyrick
Status: No record of status. Possibly in store
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

Opogona sp.
Status: Feeding on bark
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Opogona theobroma Bradley
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Phthoropoea oenochares (Meyrick)
Synonyms: Plemyristis oenochares Meyrick
Status: Feeding on pods, possibly dry ones
Distribution: Nigeria (Meyrick 1920-21)

Trachycentra sp. near chlorogramma Meyrick
Status: Adults bred from dead branch
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

LEPIDOPTERA TORTRICIDAE
Adoxophyes aurantiana Bradley
Status: Feeding on leaves between leaves spun together
Distribution: Solomon Is (Lever 1968)

273

LEPIDOPTERA

274

Adoxophyes fasciculana Walker
Status: Larvae feed on flush foliage
Distribution: Fiji (O'Connor 1959), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New Guinea (Anon
1969)

Adoxophyes privatana (Walker)
Status: Larvae are leaf feeders
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Sri Lanka (Hutson 1922)
Primary parasites: Brachymeria sp. near apicicornis (Cameron), Malaysia (Khoo Ooi & Ho 1991)

Adoxophyes sp.
Status: Caterpillars feed within leaves spun together. Can cause outbreaks
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New Guinea (Anon 1971), Vanuatu (Risbec
1937)
Primary parasites: Apanteles sp. , Vanuatu (Entwistle 1972)
Exorista sp. , Vanuatu (Entwistle 1972)

Archips epicyrta Meyrick
Synonyms: Cacoecia epicyrta Meyrick
Status: The larvae feed within a shelter made by webbing two leaves together. Once the leaves have been
consumed they prepare a new shelter and pupation takes place within the last shelter.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Archips machlopis Meyrick
Synonyms: Cacoecia machlopis Meyrick
Status: The larvae feed within a shelter made by webbing two leaves together. Once the leaves have been
consumed they prepare a new shelter and pupation takes place within the last shelter.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Archips occidentalis (Walsingham)
Status: The larvae feed within a shelter made by webbing two leaves together. Once the leaves have been
consumed they prepare a new shelter and pupation takes place within the last shelter.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)

Archips sp.
Synonyms: Cacoecia sp.
Status: The larvae feed within a shelter made by webbing two leaves together. Once the leaves have been
consumed they prepare a new shelter and pupation takes place within the last shelter.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Cryptophlebia encarpa Meyrick
Status: Caterpillars feed on the skin of ripe pods which may lead to fungal infection
Distribution: Malaysia Sarawak (Gumbek 1986), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Ubaidillah 1996), Papua New
Guinea (Baker 1976a)
Primary parasites: Brachymeria encarpae Ubaidillah, Malaysia (Ubaidillah 1996)

Cryptophlebia sp. near encarpa Meyrick
Status: Caterpillars feed on the skin of ripe pods which may lead to fungal infection
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963)

Eccopsis sp. near praecedens (Walsingham)
Synonyms: Argyroploce sp. near praecedens Walsingham, Olethreutes sp. near praecedens Walsingham
Status: Larva is green with a dark brown head and black first thoracic segment. It fastens flush leaves together
with silk and feeds within this shelter.
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965)
Primary parasites: Atrometus sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)
Cadurcia auratocauda (Curran), Ghana (Smith 1965)

Ecdytolopha aurantianum (Da Costa Lima)
Status: Caterpillars bore into pods. The species is also a pest of citrus
Distribution: Venezuela (Jimenez 2003)

LEPIDOPTERA

Ecdytolopha punctidiscanum Dyar
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Kirkpatrick 1954)

Homona aestivata (Walker)
Synonyms: Adoxophyes aestivata Walker
Status: The larvae feed within a shelter made by webbing two leaves together. Once the leaves have been
consumed they prepare a new shelter and pupation takes place within the last shelter.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Homona coffearia (Nietner)
Status: The larvae feed within a shelter made by webbing two leaves together. Once the leaves have been
consumed they prepare a new shelter and pupation takes place within the last shelter.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1971)

Homona nubiferana Walker
Status: The larvae feed within a shelter made by webbing two leaves together. Once the leaves have been
consumed they prepare a new shelter and pupation takes place within the last shelter.
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Kalshoven 1950-51)

Homona picrostacta Meyrick
Status: The larvae feed within a shelter made by webbing two leaves together. Once the leaves have been
consumed they prepare a new shelter and pupation takes place within the last shelter.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Homona salaconis Meyrick
Synonyms: Archips spilotoma Meyrick
Status: The larvae feed within a shelter made by webbing two leaves together. Once the leaves have been
consumed they prepare a new shelter and pupation takes place within the last shelter.
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Homona sp.
Status: The larvae feed within a shelter made by webbing two leaves together. Once the leaves have been
consumed they prepare a new shelter and pupation takes place within the last shelter.
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Papua New Guinea (Anon 1969)

Homona trachyptera Diakonoff
Status: The larvae feed within a shelter made by webbing two leaves together. Once the leaves have been
consumed they prepare a new shelter and pupation takes place within the last shelter.
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Laspeyresia sp.
Status: The caterpillar of the species recorded from the Ivory Coast bores into the end of young branches
making a gallery 3-4 cm long and killing the shoot and may kill seedlings outright. It is 9-10 mm long and
yellowish brown with a smooth head capsule. Pupation takes place within the gallery.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Olethreutes sp.
Status: Larvae observed boring into mesocarp of ripening pods but not penetrating deeply
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

Russograptis callopista (Durrant)
Synonyms: Tortrix callopista Durrant
Status: The larva is a predator
Distribution: Nigeria (Lamborn 1914)
Predator of: Stictococcus sjostedti Cockerell, Nigeria (Lamborn 1914)

Tortrix dinota Meyrick
Status: Larvae feed on leaves particularly the petioles. This species is an important pest of tea
Distribution: Ghana (Smith 1965), Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)
Primary parasites: Cadurcia auratocauda (Curran), Ghana (Smith 1965)
Sjoestedtella sp. , Ghana (Smith 1965)

275

Stenopyga ziela Roy
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Ghana (Majer 1975)

Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Ghana (Marchart 1968)
Predator of: Distantiella theobroma (Distant), Ghana (Marchart 1968)

Distribution: Ghana (Lodos 1968b)

ORTHOPTERA

ORTHOPTERA
ORTHOPTERA ACRIDIDAE
Acrida turrita (Linnaeus)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Aiolopus thalassinus tamulus (Fabricius)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Apalachris varicornis Walker
Status: Adults feed on leaves
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (FAO 1961)

Caryanda diminuta (Walker)
Synonyms: Oxya diminuta (Walker)
Status: Occurs mainly in rice fields. Its status on cocoa is not recorded
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Chondracris rosea (De Geer)
Status: Most serious as a pest of citrus but feeds on leaves of a range of crops.
Distribution: Taiwan (Sonan 1940), Thailand (Roffey 1979)

Coscineuta sp.
Status: A green grasshopper with yellow and black markings.
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Urich 1921)

Coscineuta virens (Thunberg)
Status: A green grasshopper with yellow and black markings. Attacks foliage of coffee and cocoa
Distribution: Trinidad & Tobago (Anon 1982)

Desmopterella explicata (Karsch)
Status: A grasshopper living on the forest floor. It is a minor pest of cocoa
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Erucius apicalis Westwood
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Gastrimargus marmoratus (Thunberg)
Synonyms: Gastrimargus transversus (Malaysia) Thunberg
Status: Usually found in tall grassland. Status on cocoa not recorded
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Locusta migratoria migratorioides (Reiche & Fairmaire)
Status: The migratory locust during swarming will devour any green part of a plant and cocoa has been no
exception in the past.
Distribution: Guinea (Chevalier 1931)

Orphulella concinnula (Walker)
Status: A green and brown grashopper 12-17 mm long. Damage is minimal
Distribution: Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

Oxya japonica vitticollis (Blanchard)
Synonyms: Oxya gavisa (Walker)
Status: The grasshopper is principally a pest of rice
Distribution: Solomon Is (Lever 1968)

282

ORTHOPTERA

283

Oxycatantops spissus spissus (Walker)
Synonyms: Catantops spissus spissus (Walker)
Status: The grasshopper feeds on leaves
Distribution: Nigeria (Golding 1948)

Parapropacris notatus (Karsch)
Synonyms: Anacatantops notatus (Karsch)
Status: Principally a pest of bananas
Distribution: Nigeria (Golding 1940)

Phlaeoba antennata Brunner von Wattenwyl

Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Phlaeoba sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Prionolopha serrata (Linnaeus)
Status: A green grasshopper up to 80 mm long. Damage is minimal
Distribution: Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

Schistocerca cancellata paranensis (Burmeister)
Synonyms: Schistocerca paranensis Burmeister
Status: A swarming caterpillar which strips the foliage from a range of crops during outbreaks, including
coffee and cocoa
Distribution: Venezuela (Freeman 1915)

Schistocerca flavofasciata (De Geer)
Status: A brown grasshopper 50-55 mm long with a yellowish band along the margin of the fore wing.
Damage is minimal
Distribution: Brazil (Da Costa Lima 1936), Surinam (Van Dinther 1960), Trinidad & Tobago (Kevan 1943)

Stenocatantops angustifrons (Walker)
Status: Polyphagous, feeding on various weeds and shrubs and is a minor pest of coffee and cocoa
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Stenocatantops splendens (Thunberg)
Synonyms: Catantops splendens Thunberg
Status: Males 30-35 mm, females 40-45 mm, brown grasshoppers with reddish legs and speckled wings
Distribution: Indonesia (Willemse 1957), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Taeniophora sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

Trilophidia annulata (Thunberg)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

Valanga gohieri Le Guillou
Status: Feeds on foliage but does not cause much damage
Distribution: Indonesia West Irian (Schreurs & Simon-Thomas 1961)

Valanga nigricornis melanocornis (Serville)
Status: A brown grasshopper with females 60-70 mm long which feed on the foliage of a range of trees and
can produce swarms which do a considerable amount of damage but do not move from their original feeding
sites
Distribution: Indonesia Java (Kalshoven 1950-51)

ORTHOPTERA

284

Valanga nigricornis nigricornis (Burmeister)
Status: A brown grasshopper with females 60-70 mm long which feed on the foliage of a range of trees and
can produce swarms which do a considerable amount of damage but do not move from their original feeding
sites
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Sarawak (Wan 1970)

Valanga papuasica (Finot)
Status: A tree living grasshopper feeding on foliage
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Vilerna aenooculata (De Geer)

Distribution: Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

ORTHOPTERA GRYLLACRIDIDAE
Afrogryllacris africana (Brunner)
Status: Recorded from canopy by knockdown
Distribution: Ghana (Majer 1975)
Predator of: Not recorded -, Ghana (Gibbs & Leston 1970)

Gryllacris sp.
Status: These insects excavate underground tunnels from which they come out at night to feed. They attack a
wide range of plants and on coffee tend to be a problem in nurseries where they cut off seedlings just above
ground by chewing through the stem.
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957)

ORTHOPTERA GRYLLIDAE
Acheta sp.
Status: Collected from interplanted cocoa
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Bourke et al 1971)

Anaxipha sp.
Status: The insect is a predator
Distribution: Costa Rica (Weber 1957), Ghana (Majer 1975)

Brachytrupes membranaceus (Drury)
Status: The insect lives in a subterranean burrow and emerges at night to feed, damaging the plants in the
collar region. Attack takes place particularly to newly planted trees in cleared land where the insect runs short
of the grasses on which it normally feeds.
Distribution: Ivory Coast (Alibert 1951)

Cardiodactylus novaeguineae (De Haan)
Status: A brown cricket with yellow dorsal markings feeding on leaves and shoots
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1961)

Euscyrtus bivittatus Guerin-Meneville
Status: Probably feeds on bark
Distribution: Ghana (Gibbs & Leston 1970)

Gryllus bimaculatus De Geer
Status: These insects excavate underground tunnels from which they come out at night to feed. They attack a
wide range of plants and on coffee tend to be a problem in nurseries where they cut off seedlings just above
ground by chewing through the stem.

Scapteriscus didactylus (Latreille)
Status: These insects excavate underground tunnels from which they come out at night to feed. They attack a

ORTHOPTERA PYRGOMORPHIDAE
Atractomorpha crenaticeps (Blanchard)
Status: A rather elongated grasshopper. No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Kevan 1971)

Atractomorpha psittacina (De Haan)
Status: A very elongate grasshopper feeding on leaves
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (FAO 1961)

Aularches miliaris (Linnaeus)
Status: Feeding on young leaves
Distribution: Sri Lanka (Green 1906)

Zonocerus elegans (Thunberg)
Status: A yellowish green grasshopper with darker green/blue patches about 30-50 mm long. The grasshoppers
are generalist feeders on a wide range of crops and weeds hatching at the onset of the rainy season and do not
move onto coffee until they are older and their alternative food is exhausted.
Distribution: Zaire (Schouteden 1914)

Zonocerus variegatus (Linnaeus)
Status: A black and yellow grasshopper about 40mm long feeding on leaves which is an occasional pest of
many plants.
Distribution: Cameroon (Aulmann & La Baume 1912), Ghana (Jago 1968), Ivory Coast (Chevalier 1931),
Kenya (Le Pelley 1959), Nigeria (Lamborn 1914), Sierra Leone (Entwistle 1972), Tanzania (Le Pelley 1959),
Uganda (Le Pelley 1959), Zaire (Schouteden 1914)

Status: Predatory on other thrips

Predator of: Heliothrips haemorrhoidalis (Bouche), Trinidad & Tobago (Callan 1943)
Selenothrips rubrocinctus (Giard), Surinam (Reyne 1922), Trinidad & Tobago (Williams 1918)

Franklinothrips vespiformis (Crawford)
Status: Predatory on other thrips
Distribution: Dominican Republic (Russo 1936), Mexico (Johansen 1976), Surinam (Reyne 1922), Trinidad
& Tobago (Williams 1918)
Predator of: Heliothrips haemorrhoidalis (Bouche), Mexico (Johansen 1976), Trinidad & Tobago (Callan

Selenothrips rubrocinctus (Giard), Dominican Republic (Russo 1936), Surinam (Reyne 1922), Trinidad &

Frankliniella brevicaulis Hood
Status: Feeding in flowers
Distribution: Brazil (Bovi Coral & Parra 1977)

Frankliniella parvula Hood
Status: Adults feed on flowers.
Distribution: Costa Rica (Knoke & Saunders 1966), Mexico (Johansen 1974), Trinidad & Tobago (Billes
1941)

Helionothrips aulmanni (Karny)
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964)

THYSANOPTERA

292

Heliothrips haemorrhoidalis (Bouche)
Status: The adult is uniformly dark brown, 1.5-2mm long. Mature larvae are yellow with the end of the
abdomen brown.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1939a), Colombia (De Franco 1958), Dominican Republic (Russo 1936),
Indonesia (Kalshoven 1950-51), Indonesia West Irian (Entwistle 1972), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho
1980), Mexico (Johansen 1976), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany 1963), Surinam (Reyne 1919), Trinidad &
Tobago (Williams 1918)
Primary parasites: Goetheana shakespearei Girault, Trinidad (Callan 1943)
Predators: Franklinothrips tenuicornis Hood, Trinidad & Tobago (Callan 1943)
Franklinothrips vespiformis (Crawford), Mexico (Johansen 1976), Trinidad & Tobago (Callan 1943)

Heliothrips sp.
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Ecuador (Campos 1933b)

Leucothrips theobromae (Priesner)
Status: Sometimes common on flush leaves
Distribution: Mexico (Johansen 1974), Surinam (Van Dinther 1960)

Neohydatothrips inversus Hood
Synonyms: Sericothrips inversus Hood
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Mexico (Johansen 1974)

Selenothrips rubrocinctus (Giard)
Synonyms: Heliothrips rubrocinctus Giard, Selenothrips decolor Karny
Status: Adults are black and 1.1 -1.4 mm long. Nymphs are transparent yellowish white with a red band
around the base of the abdomen. They feed in groups on the underside of newly hardened leaves causing these
to become yellow. Heavy attack can defoliate the tree and may eventually lead to the death of the tree.
Distribution: Brazil (Bondar 1922), Cameroon (Woin Nguyen-Ban & Mpe 1995), Caroline Is (Entwistle
1972), Colombia (Entwistle 1972), Dominican Republic (Russo 1930), Equatorial Guinea Bioko (Cotterell
1930a), Ghana (Cotterell 1928), Grenada (Ballou 1915), Guyana (Entwistle 1972), Ivory Coast (Paulin Decazy
& Coulibaly 1983), Jamaica (Ritchie 1916), Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980), Mexico (SanchezSoto & Lagunas 1995), Nigeria (Entwistle 1972), Papua New Guinea (Szent-Ivany & Dun 1964), Peru (Wille
1952), Puerto Rico (Entwistle 1972), Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919c), Solomon Is (Lever 1968), St
Lucia (Watts 1916), St Vincent (Anon 1922), Sudan (Schmutterer 1969), Surinam (Reyne 1920), Trinidad &
Tobago (Williams 1918), Zaire (Cotterell 1930a)
Primary parasites: Goetheana shakespearei Girault, Ghana (Cotterell 1927b), Grenada (Pickles 1938), Puerto
Rico (Bartlett 1938), Trinidad & Tobago (Adamson 1936)
Megaphragma sp. , Sao Tome & Principe (Mateus et al 2002)
Predators: Azteca chartifex Forel, Brazil (Torrend 1927)
Azteca chartifex spiriti Forel, Brazil (Delabie et al 2007)
Chrysopa sp. , Trinidad & Tobago (Callan 1943)
Ectatomma tuberculatum (Olivier), Brazil (Delabie et al 2007)
Exochomus flavipes Thunberg, Sao Tome & Principe (De Seabra 1919a)
Franklinothrips sp. , Surinam (Reyne 1920)
Franklinothrips tenuicornis Hood, Surinam (Reyne 1922), Trinidad & Tobago (Williams 1918)
Franklinothrips vespiformis (Crawford), Dominican Republic (Russo 1936), Surinam (Reyne 1922), Trinidad
& Tobago (Williams 1918)
Leucochrysa varia Schneider, Trinidad & Tobago (Callan 1943)
Ninyas torvus Distant, Trinidad & Tobago (Callan 1943)
Termatophylidea maculata Usinger, Trinidad & Tobago (Callan 1943)
Termatophylidea opaca Carvalho, Surinam (Van Doesburg 1964)
Termatophylidea pilosa Reuter & Poppius, Jamaica (Myers 1935)
Wasmannia auropunctata (Roger), Trinidad & Tobago (Williams 1918)

Thrips ?minor Bagnall
Status: No record of status
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)

THYSANOPTERA

Thrips hawaiiensis (Morgan)
Status: Feeding on leaves
Distribution: Malaysia W. Malaysia (Yunus & Ho 1980)
